#tr.en: ... that are near (at hand), they will give ... 
#tr.en: To my lord speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Baḫdi-Addu, 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: The Hanean rear contingent has arrived; 
#tr.en: The Hanean lead and rear contingents are well. 
#tr.en: No sickness, nothing, 
#tr.en: whatever losses are none, 
#tr.en: and the expeditionary force is well. 
#tr.en: May the heart of my lord not fear at all. 
#tr.en: Another thing: during all of the expeditions, 
#tr.en: I am all ears, and 
#tr.en: (there are) many worries. 
#tr.en: Now, in this expedition 
#tr.en: I am listening, and 
#tr.en: worries or anything, 
#tr.en: there is none; 
#tr.en: there is jesting and playing, 
#tr.en: like staying in their own households, 
#tr.en: their hearts are sweet; 
#tr.en: of the endeavor: doing 
#tr.en: weapons and killing the enemy, 
#tr.en: the heart of the servants of my lord is speaking. 
#tr.en: May my lord be happy! 
#tr.en: To my lord 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Meptum, your servant: 
#tr.en: (There are) 4 tablets 
#tr.en: of the governor of Susa in Elam, 
#tr.en: whom they killed—the carriers 
#tr.en: whom they in a campaign war captured— 
#tr.en: those tablets I opened, and 
#tr.en: thus I: “Perhaps 
#tr.en: a report of field and land 
#tr.en: in the tablets is recorded; 
#tr.en: if they did not open and hear, 
#tr.en: if to my lord I were not to send, 
#tr.en: and if I would not myself seize my report, 
#tr.en: (then it is as if) a report in them 
#tr.en: there was none.” Concerning the report 
#tr.en: of field and land, 
#tr.en: now these tablets to my lord 
#tr.en: I have sent. May my lord hear them. 
#tr.en: To Asqur-Addu, my lord, 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Meptum, your servant: 
#tr.en: Earlier this my tablet I sent to you, on the 4th day, 
#tr.en: ten thousand troops of Babylon, from Sippar 
#tr.en: crossed over. The leader of those troops 
#tr.en: (is) Mutu-adgim. Ḫulālum 
#tr.en: to Allaḫada for kingship 
#tr.en: in place of Atamrim they will lead. 
#tr.en: Now the report that I heard 
#tr.en: to you I have sent. 
#tr.en: Take action! 
#tr.en: And this report, that I sent to you, 
#tr.en: quickly to the king let it arrive! 
#tr.en: to ... for ... 
#tr.en: Since the confirmation ... 
#tr.en: sending I will send you. 
#tr.en: Now, the report that I heard 
#tr.en: I have sent you. 
#tr.en: Take action! 
#tr.en: A confirmation of this report 
#tr.en: they took from me, and 
#tr.en: to my lord quickly 
#tr.en: I am sending. 
#tr.en: To my lord 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Yasim-Sumû, 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: Of the 42 men, 2 donkeys, 
#tr.en: sons of Ekallatum 
#tr.en: who arrived here, 
#tr.en: 1 female servant of ...-ḫu 
#tr.en: and 1 female servant of ... 
#tr.en: who in the palace 
#tr.en: they gave to them, 
#tr.en: I saw, and I held them back. 
#tr.en: And Awīl-Nanna in the following way spoke, 
#tr.en: thus (he): “If really 
#tr.en: the blinkers(?) that to the craftsmen 
#tr.en: you all gave, you held back, 
#tr.en: so there the same my lord will do. 
#tr.en: Now perhaps as to the two female servants 
#tr.en: that I held back, anger will arise. 
#tr.en: Either way, my lord should write to me. 
#tr.en: To my lord 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Iddin-Numušda, 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: Previously 
#tr.en: my lord concerning the holding back 
#tr.en: of the expedition of Qaṭanum 
#tr.en: spoke to me, and 
#tr.en since five days 
#tr.en: the men I have held back; 
#tr.en: in extispicy 
#tr.en: have been used up. 
#tr.en: If it pleases my lord, 
#tr.en: my lord should write me, and
#tr.en: these men should not be held back! 
#tr.en: Let them go! 
#tr.en: The men are continuously distressed. 
#tr.en: On the 3rd day, 
#tr.en: a caravan will go out. 
#tr.en: With the caravan, 
#tr.en: the later one, 
#tr.en: may the messengers 
#tr.en: go out. 
#tr.en: To my lord 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Mukannišum, 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: “Concerning the report of Addu, about which my lord gave me instructions, 
#tr.en: the report, about which my lord gave me instructions, 
#tr.en: for Inib-Šamaš 
#tr.en: and Ilšu-nāṣir, diviners, 
#tr.en: I dug out, and 4 lamb(-extispicie)s 
#tr.en: they performed, and their extispicies 
#tr.en: to my lord I had brought. 
#tr.en: A complete report 
#tr.en: may my lord send. 
#tr.en: Herewith, 6 bronze knives with silver plated, 
#tr.en: 3 large axes 
#tr.en: 1 ax of 1 1/2 mina, 
#tr.en: one large agasilikku (ax), 
#tr.en: ... piercers of 1 mina, 
#tr.en: ... engraving tools of 10 shekels, 
#tr.en: 1 drawing tool of bronze, 
#tr.en: ... bronze pegs of 5 mina; 
#tr.en: total: 21 1/3 mina, 
#tr.en: their weight; 1 (linen) garment, nalbašu 
#tr.en: ... (linen) garments, 
#tr.en: ... bed: 
#tr.en: these utensils 
#tr.en: to my lord 
#tr.en: I have dispatched.” 
#tr.en: To my lord, 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: thus Kibrī-Dagan, 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: Dagan and Yakrub-El are well. 
#tr.en: The city of Terqa and the district are well. 
#tr.en: Another thing: the day this tablet 
#tr.en: to my lord I sent. 
#tr.en: the ecstatic of Dagan 
#tr.en: came and 
#tr.en: a word in the following way spoke to me, 
#tr.en: thus: 
#tr.en: The god sent me. 
#tr.en: Come quickly! To the king 
#tr.en: write, and 
#tr.en: funerary offerings to the spirit 
#tr.en: of Yaḫdun-Lim 
#tr.en: they must dedicate. 
#tr.en: This that ecstatic 
#tr.en: said to me, and to my lord 
#tr.en: I have written. 
#tr.en: My lord what is pleasing to him 
#tr.en: must do. 
#tr.en: To my lord 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Kibrī-Dagan 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: Dagan and Ikrub-Il are well. 
#tr.en: The city of Terqa and the district are well. 
#tr.en: In harvesting the grain of my district 
#tr.en: and piling up in the threshing floors 
#tr.en: I have not been negligent. 
#tr.en: Another thing: concerning the making of the new city gate, 
#tr.en: previously 
#tr.en: ..., the ecstatic, 
#tr.en: came to me, and 
#tr.en: he was in constant distress. 
#tr.en: Thus he: 
#tr.en: The work on that city gate 
#tr.en: begin! 
#tr.en: Now the day this, my tablet, 
#tr.en: to my lord I dispatched. 
#tr.en: That ecstatic returned here and 
#tr.en: in the following way spoke to me, 
#tr.en: and gave strong orders, thus: 
#tr.en: If this city gate 
#tr.en: you all do not construct, 
#tr.en: a ‘pile-up’ will occur. 
#tr.en: You all will not be successful! 
#tr.en: This, that ecstatic 
#tr.en: said to me. And in the harvest 
#tr.en: I am occupied. Diverting 
#tr.en: my servants I cannot do. 
#tr.en: If my lord commands, 
#tr.en: let help come here, and  
#tr.en: ...

#tr.en: Yakūn-Hammu, 
#tr.en: servant of Būnu-Eštar. 
#tr.en: Anum created her, Ea reared her, 
#tr.en: a face of a lioness Enlil alloted her.

#tr.en: long, her forearms are hidden. 
#tr.en: By the door of the house she entered, 
#tr.en: slipping past the door-pivot. 
#tr.en: she slipped past the door pivot and has seen the child. 
#tr.en: In his abdomen seven times seized. 
#tr.en: Remove your nails, 
#tr.en: make limp your arms, 
#tr.en: before he has reached you, 
#tr.en: the wise man of craft, Ea, the hero! 
#tr.en: Wide for you is the door pivot, open are the doors. 
#tr.en: Go and wander about the steppe! 
#tr.en: With dust, your mouth, 
#tr.en: with a dust cloud, your face, 
#tr.en: with cress seeds, finely ground, 
#tr.en: I will fill your eyes. 
#tr.en: I conjure you by the curse of Ea. 
#tr.en: Verily go away! 
#tr.en: “Come now, cleaner, I’ll give you an order—clean my clothes! 
#tr.en: What I instruct you, do not lay aside, 
#tr.en: Your own (ideas), you should not do! 
#tr.en: As for the hem of the garment, you will lay down the selvage, 
#tr.en: You will stitch the outer side to the inside, 
#tr.en: You will pick up the thread of the (shorter) border. 
#tr.en: You will soak the delicate part (of the cloth) in beer, 
#tr.en: You will strain it through a sieve. 
#tr.en: You will loosen the hem with the selvage. 
#tr.en: You will spray it with clear water, 
#tr.en: You will wipe it like a kimdum cloth, and you will ... : 
#tr.en: To the weft yarns you will [brush?] so that the warp yarns ... 
#tr.en: You will ... in a basin(?), 
#tr.en: ... you will mix alkali with gypsum (to prepare fuller’s earth?). 
#tr.en: You will beat(?) it on/with/under a stone. 
#tr.en: ... in a vessel. 
#tr.en: In case you have applied a (laundry) mark, (then) you must ... and you will have to comb (the fabric). 
#tr.en: You will tap (the garment) repeatedly with an e’ru-wood stick (to felt or smooth the fabric). 
#tr.en: You will arrange the fleece on the washer’s stool. 
#tr.en: You will sew/repair the work, the (damaged) warp, with a needle. 
#tr.en: You will spread and cool the hem. 
#tr.en: You will dry (the garment) in the break of evening, 
#tr.en: so that the fabric will not dry (and wrinkle). 
#tr.en: (Afterwards) you will place it in a box (and that) in a chest. 
#tr.en: No cause for concern! Bring (it) to me; I will make you very happy—promptly! 
#tr.en: You will bring (the garment) to the house, (one) will pour a seah of barley into your lap.” 
#tr.en: The fuller answers him: “By Ea, lord of the washbowl, who gives me life! 
#tr.en: Drop it! Not me! What you are saying—only my creditor and my tax collector 
#tr.en: have the nerve (to talk) like you! 
#tr.en: Nobody’s hands could manage this work! 
#tr.en: What you have instructed me I cannot repeat, 
#tr.en: utter or reiterate! 
#tr.en: Come upstream of the city, in the environs of the city— 
#tr.en: let me show you a washing-place! 
#tr.en: The great work you have in your hands set yourself (to do)! 
#tr.en: The meal time should not pass—go in there, and 
#tr.en: the many threads of the fuller unravel! 
#tr.en: If you don’t calm yourself down 
#tr.en: a fuller who will bother for you will be none. 
#tr.en: They will mock you. Your heart 
#tr.en: will burn, and a rash(?) 
#tr.en: on your body you will impose.” 
#tr.en: The lines, their count: 41.

#tr.en: Basket-of-tablets: 
#tr.en: sealed documents of dab, various, 
#tr.en: are here. 
#tr.en: The tomb of Šamaš-ibni, son of Dakuri. Assur-etel-ilāni, king of the land of Assyria, 
#tr.en: the merciful one bequeathed to him, and from ... 
#tr.en: Nergal from headache 
#tr.en: may he not spare, his life ... . 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: the merciful one bequeathed to him, and from the middle of the mountains to ... 
#tr.en: he brought to him and in the tomb within his estate at the fortress of Ladini he laid him to rest. 
#tr.en: Whoever you are—governor or administrator or judge 
#tr.en: or prince who in the land has been appointed, to this tomb and bones 
#tr.en: to it do no harm, its place guard, 
#tr.en: good protection over it extend! 
#tr.en: On this account may Marduk, the great lord, your reign lengthen, 
#tr.en: his good protection over you may he establish! 
#tr.en: your name, your seed, and life of your long days for all time may he bless! 
#tr.en: If that prince or official or administrator or judge 
#tr.en: or governor who is in the land  
#tr.en: this tomb and bones harms, 
#tr.en: from its place alienates it, to another place taking it, 
#tr.en: or if another person unto evil purpose causes him to speak and he listens, 
#tr.en: [may Marduk,] the great lord, his name, his seed, his fruit, and his offspring 
#tr.en: from the mouth of the people abolish. 
#tr.en: To Dadâ 
#tr.en: and Sîn-uselli 
#tr.en: speak, 
#tr.en: thus Šēp-Sîn: 
#tr.en: “May Šamaš and Ašnan 
#tr.en: for my sake forever 
#tr.en: keep you well!” 
#tr.en: Thus I wrote you, 
#tr.en: thus me: 
#tr.en: “Both of you, you and Sîn-uselli, 
#tr.en: tin sweepings and their powder, 
#tr.en: leeks, perfumed oils, juniper, 
#tr.en: and 2 talents of copper 
#tr.en: gather for me. 
#tr.en: Even a short day do not delay! 
#tr.en: And one son of Susa 
#tr.en: as your partner 
#tr.en: with you 
#tr.en: should go.” 
#tr.en: Thus I wrote you. 
#tr.en: What you yourselves, 
#tr.en: thus you: 
#tr.en: ‛We shall have it brought.’ 
#tr.en: On the day my letter, 
#tr.en: you see, 
#tr.en: both of you, do not delay! 
#tr.en: I heard your words. 
#tr.en: together with the king’s soldiers 
#tr.en: and the king’s letter, 
#tr.en: up to Larsa, 
#tr.en: for you 
#tr.en: of non-interference 
#tr.en: in al-Aḫa-nūta. 
#tr.en: I will be ready. From now,
#tr.en: 5 days hence, I shall see you.
#tr.en: 10 talents of juniper and 1 talent resin 
#tr.en: may he give. 
#tr.en: One the other ... 
#tr.en: must not hinder. 
#tr.en: Both of you together, 
#tr.en: you and Sîn-uselli, 
#tr.en: directly your faces I shall see. 
#tr.en: While in al-Aḫa-nūta 
#tr.en: together with the kings soldier(s) 
#tr.en: I am staying, 
#tr.en: directly your faces I shall see.”

#tr.en: From Irisagrig

#tr.en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Išme-Dagan, your brother: 
#tr.en: Concerning the country Šušarrâ 
#tr.en: (about) which you wrote me, 
#tr.en: since this country is in confusion 
#tr.en: and we are unable to hold it back, 
#tr.en: let Išar-Lim speak to you; 
#tr.en: Lidaya, the Turukkean, 
#tr.en: and the Turukkean with him 
#tr.en: who in that country reside, 
#tr.en: became hostile, and two cities finished off.
#tr.en: I came to help, and 
#tr.en: to the heart of the mountains they entered. 
#tr.en: We reflected, and 
#tr.en: since that country 
#tr.en: for keeping back would not be led, 
#tr.en: that country 
#tr.en: I attacked, and 
#tr.en: from the country Arrapḫum 
#tr.en: and from the country Qabrâ 
#tr.en: up to... let colonize(?).
#tr.en: Troops of the heart of the country 
#tr.en: will be freed. 
#tr.en: I am well; your heart at all 
#tr.en: may not fear. 
#tr.en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Išme-Dagan, your brother: 
#tr.en: Since with the troops to aid 
#tr.en: and support Samu-Addu 
#tr.en: to Karanaya I went, 
#tr.en: certainly earlier 
#tr.en: I wrote to you; 
#tr.en: the man of Ešnunna with the ensemble of his troops,
#tr.en: together with administrative staff 
#tr.en: and notables, 
#tr.en: gathered, and in Opis
#tr.en: sat, and 
#tr.en: further to the man of Babylon 
#tr.en: to meet up with him 
#tr.en: in Mankisi 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: kept writing, but  
#tr.en: the man of Babylon 
#tr.en: did not agree, and 
#tr.en: although the man of Babylon did not agree, 
#tr.en: in his shamelessness he rose up against me, and 
#tr.en: to Maškulliya he went, and 
#tr.en: in Maškulliya 
#tr.en: to waterway dredging his hand set. 
#tr.en: The city Maškulliya 
#tr.en: above Dūr-ipiq-Addu 
#tr.en: at a distance of a double-hour set. 
#tr.en: As I Maškulliya approached, 
#tr.en: Samu-Addu wrote and with troops 
#tr.en: to the city I hastened, in the city arrived, and  
#tr.en: since matters were remarkable, the man of Ešnunna 
#tr.en: to do evil his face  
#tr.en: had set, to the heart of the land  
#tr.en: returned; Samu-Addu wrote me, and  
#tr.en: to the troops who with me came,  
#tr.en: report of dispatch,  
#tr.en: to Samu-Addu  
#tr.en: I sent; further, the remainder of the troops  
#tr.en: who in the heart of the land had dispersed;  
#tr.en: further, ...  
#tr.en: I ...,  
#tr.en: you need not be at all anxious. 
#tr.en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Išme-Dagan, 
#tr.en: your brother: 
#tr.en: Concerning your messengers you wrote me. 
#tr.en: If this my tablet 
#tr.en: to you arrives, and 
#tr.en: it will be many days; from Madaraya 
#tr.en: go, a strong village 
#tr.en: is there. 
#tr.en: Go straight in, and 
#tr.en: house! 
#tr.en: Further, the next morning, early, 
#tr.en: to me come. 
#tr.en: Further, let your servant before you go along, 
#tr.en: let him be quick, so that to you 
#tr.en: at Tušḫum 
#tr.en: I can approach. If not thus 
#tr.en: you spent the night, but in Madaraya 
#tr.en: housed, as early as possible 
#tr.en: come, and your servant 
#tr.en: let go along, and just me 
#tr.en: let him notify. 
#tr.en: When the city 
#tr.en: I approach, 
#tr.en: and the gods 
#tr.en: like their messengers 
#tr.en: let them come. 
#tr.en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Išme-Dagan, 
#tr.en: your brother: 
#tr.en: The extisipicies of the sacrifice 
#tr.en: you sent here, and I saw them; 
#tr.en: further, in the following way you wrote me, thus: 
#tr.en: The fat of the center 
#tr.en: to the right is black; 
#tr.en: The heart itself 
#tr.en: to the right and left is dark. 
#tr.en: Further, a thick scar is there. 
#tr.en: The dark spot of the left 
#tr.en: might not concern you. 
#tr.en: Now, these extispicies 
#tr.en: I have sent back to you. 
#tr.en: Read them! 
#tr.en: With the dark spots, 
#tr.en: the contradictory (patches), 
#tr.en: further a thick scar is there. 
#tr.en: There is nothing to be concerned about. 
#tr.en: To Yasmaḫ-Addu  
#tr.en: speak!  
#tr.en: Thus Aplaḫanda,  
#tr.en: your brother: Now good wine  
#tr.en: I have sent you; so drink! 
#tr.en: Now bread of Carchemish;   
#tr.en: so eat! Now 1 ... ; 
#tr.en: now 1 bracelet ... ;  
#tr.en: now 1 sūnu(-garment), further now  
#tr.en: 1 š(-garment) of dušûm(-stone color) 
#tr.en: I have sent you.  
#tr.en: Further, for the sake of all the terms  
#tr.en: to me keep sending!  
#tr.en: Further, as for me, to whom
#tr.en: will I look? 
#tr.en: This ..., the house of ...  
#tr.en: ... of Šamšī-Addu, my father, 
#tr.en: per your needs write me, and  
#tr.en: I have sent to you.  
#tr.en: and for ... something why  
#tr.en: do you not send to me?
#tr.en: Further, my father in ... 
#tr.en: is staying; ...   
#tr.en: One way or the other,  
#tr.en: write to me, and ...   
#tr.en: I will send to you. 
#tr.en: To Išme-Dagan 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus Išḫi-Addu, your brother: 
#tr.en: This word is unspeakable, 
#tr.en: yet now may I speak, and 
#tr.en: further may my heart relax! 
#tr.en: A great king are you. Two horses 
#tr.en: as your request you requested from me, and 
#tr.en: But as for you, 20 minas of tin 
#tr.en: you sent to me. To not act 
#tr.en: straight with me 
#tr.en: may you not desire! This little tin 
#tr.en: you sent! If but 
#tr.en: you were not sending me anything! 
#tr.en: On account of the god of my father, 
#tr.en: if but my heart were ill! 
#tr.en: The price of horses, 
#tr.en: the aforementioned, 
#tr.en: with us in Qatna 
#tr.en: is 6 hundred (shekels) of silver, 
#tr.en: but you, 20 minas of tin 
#tr.en: you sent me. Further, the one who hears, 
#tr.en: will say what? “He has not dealt so with us.” 
#tr.en: This house is your house. 
#tr.en: In your house, what is missing? 
#tr.en: Does brother to brother 
#tr.en: a wish not grant? 
#tr.en: If but tin 
#tr.en: you were not sending to me! 
#tr.en: My heart 
#tr.en: would not have been sick at all. 
#tr.en: Not a great king are you. 
#tr.en: Why have you done this? 
#tr.en: This house is your house. 
#tr.en: To my lord Yasmaḫ-Addu 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: thus Asqudum, 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: At my arrival 
#tr.en: in Terqa, 
#tr.en: Tarim-šakin 
#tr.en: arrived, and in the following way 
#tr.en: I asked him, thus I: 
#tr.en: “The extispicies to the well-being of the land, 
#tr.en: and the fortresses, 
#tr.en: did Zunan perform (them)?” 
#tr.en: That one in the following way answered me,  
#tr.en: thus: “He did not perform (them).” 
#tr.en: In the ‘cleansing’ 
#tr.en: of that month with him 
#tr.en: to Saggaratum I returned, and 
#tr.en: extispicies to the well-being of the city 
#tr.en: Saggaratum to the 6th month 
#tr.en: I performed, and the extispicies 
#tr.en: were favorable; further, prior 
#tr.en: to my (departure) at the Wall of my lord, 
#tr.en: Terqa, Ṣuprum 
#tr.en: and Mari, I shall perform (them), and 
#tr.en: a full report 
#tr.en: promptly 
#tr.en: to my lord 
#tr.en: I will send; 
#tr.en: further, in Saggaratum 
#tr.en: for the offering of the month 
#tr.en: and for the offering of my lord 
#tr.en: I performed (extispicies), and  
#tr.en: an extispicy I saw, and the left of the finger 
#tr.en: was loose; the middle finger of the lungs 
#tr.en: to the right approached; an omen of fame, my lord may be happy. 
#tr.en: To my lord 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: Thus La’um 
#tr.en: your servant: 
#tr.en: It is the month of Kinūnum, the 12th day expired, and 
#tr.en: Reš-Ninbala, 
#tr.en: in Mari arrived. 
#tr.en: Extispicies for his journey 
#tr.en: I had performed, and 
#tr.en: they were very unfavorable. 
#tr.en: ..., and 
#tr.en: ... him.
#tr.en: My lord should know! 
#tr.en: Mari is well; 
#tr.en: the land is well.

#tr.en: xxx 
#tr.en: The earth, they say, the earth 
#tr.en: bore the mud; 
#tr.en: the mud  
#tr.en: bore the stalk; 
#tr.en: the stalk bore 
#tr.en: the spike; 
#tr.en: the spike 
#tr.en: bore the seed. 
#tr.en: They say in the field of Enlil, 
#tr.en: the square one, 
#tr.en: the barley of the field 
#tr.en: Sin was harvesting, 
#tr.en: Šamaš was gathering together. 
#tr.en: They say into the eye of the man 
#tr.en: did enter 
#tr.en: the seed. 
#tr.en: Whom should I send 
#tr.en: and instruct 
#tr.en: to the daughters of An, 7-7? 
#tr.en: Let them take 
#tr.en: a stand of carneol, 
#tr.en: a pot of chalcedony; 
#tr.en: let them ladle out 
#tr.en: water of the sea, 
#tr.en: pure, the seed 
#tr.en: let them lift out 
#tr.en: from the eye of the man. 
#tr.en: 57 (lines?).
#tr.en: The dragon-face (is) the dragon-face of a man, 
#tr.en: the dragon-face of a man causing evil 
#tr.en: approached heaven (and) the clouds bring (no) rain. 
#tr.en: He approached the earth, and the plants do not grow. 
#tr.en: He approached the ox, and its yoke does not open.
#tr.en: He approached the stall and smashes its cheese-pot. 
#tr.en: Utterances have passed by.
#tr.en: He approached the lad and sapped his (sexual) energies, 
#tr.en: he approached the maiden and tossed away her towel. 
#tr.en: He approached the nurse with the child - her arms were torn apart.
#tr.en: He approached the vegetables - lettuce and cress became bad.
#tr.en: He approached the garden, the fruit became bad.
#tr.en: The eye of the mountain came out from the mountain,
#tr.en: The wild ram let its shining horns come out.
#tr.en: May the evil eye (like?) the sick eye be cut off.
#tr.en: May it split open like a leather bag.

#tr.en: Holy An, the great words of his mouth are not to be abrogated. 
#tr.en: The great gods bow down to him, like a curved staff, in approval of and in prayer to him.  
#tr.en: What you command is just. (Like) what a prince or lord has uttered, what you have commanded is obeyed. 
#tr.en: An, your lofty command takes precedence, who would say No to you? 
#tr.en: Father of the gods, your word, the foundation of heaven and earth, no god fails to heed it.  
#tr.en: Lord, you are the leader who takes only his own counsel, what should be our counsel? 
#tr.en: Grant your strength to the maiden Ištar, whom you have loved.   
#tr.en: Your reliable approval, weighty as heaven, make known (to her) in our assembly.  
#tr.en: Give to the mistress, whom you have loved, your combined divine powers.   
#tr.en: Let Kišar truly be the spouse equal with you, may she rise to the (equivalent) authority of your name.  
#tr.en: Moreover, in addition let her carry out herself the decrees of Enlil and Enki.    
#tr.en: When she alone has taken hold of the nose-rope of heaven and earth, she shall be our strength! 
#tr.en: For An, the pleasant conversation produced happiness.
#tr.en: He in his goodness of heart treated holy Inanna well.   
#tr.en: The commands of my Anu-ship are the complex fundament(?) of heaven which cannot be equaled.  
#tr.en: My fixed boundaries whose exteriors are fearsome and know no approaching, 
#tr.en: I am Anšar/Anu, the king's helper, do take hold of their band.   
#tr.en: Do take for yourself the entire extent of their territory, exercise alone the ruling of them!
#tr.en: Come, rise up to my dais of kingship and dwell in the heights!
#tr.en: Corresponding to my called name, may Exalted Kišar/Antu be your called name! 
#tr.en: My faithful vizier, whose lips are prized, who is aware of my secrets, 
#tr.en: Ninšubur, my fitting vizier, shall exercise the status of father with you. 
#tr.en: May he (standing) before you constantly present auspicious words from (every) god and goddess. 
#tr.en: At the eternal foundation of heaven and earth and by the enduring designs of the gods,  
#tr.en: when, in the beginning, Anu, Enlil and Ea allotted the shares, 
#tr.en: for the two gods, the watchmen of heaven and netherworld, the ones who open the door of Anu,
#tr.en: for moon-god and sun-god the night and day were made in equal parts, 
#tr.en: and from the bottom of heaven to the top of heaven they assign them their tasks: 
#tr.en: to keep all the stars of heaven on course as in a furrow, 
#tr.en: to make the leading gods keep to their paths like oxen. 
#tr.en: Up into that place, Inanna, rise to the rulership of them all! 
#tr.en: Lady, you be the brightest of them, so may they call you Ištar of the Stars!  
#tr.en: May your high position (relative to them) alternate between the two sides (east and west) triumphantly!
#tr.en: May your splendor be as abundant as that of the moon and sun in (their) watches. 
#tr.en: May the flaring glow of your torch shine high in the sky!  
#tr.en: May the people marvel at you as one for whom among the gods there is none to check up on her.
#tr.en: After the lord had bestowed (these) great powers upon the daughter of Sîn, 
#tr.en: he did not keep her away from the shrine Eanna, her sacred chamber.
#tr.en: After king Anu had bestowed the great powers upon her, 
#tr.en: they presented to her the shrine Eanna, her sacred chamber. 
#tr.en: He covered her figure with the ceremonial garment of Anu-hood, the brilliant splendor of Sîn.
#tr.en: He made her appear like the day with superb ornaments, the ornaments of divinity. 
#tr.en: He enhanced her arm with the scepter of kingship, the fierce wood (staff), the unsparing weapon.   
#tr.en: A glorious crown which is like (that on) the head of Nanna he set (firmly) upon her head.  
#tr.en: O Hierodule, my important decisions, divine powers which could not be asked for (by anyone else) I have assigned to you. 
#tr.en: Like me, may Enlil, king of all the lands, treat you well!  
#tr.en: Because of this Lord Nunamnira became happy, his liver surged with joy.

#tr.en: Inanna, after you have made fighting and battle flip about(?) like a skip-rope, 
#tr.en: O lady of battle, make them clash together like a ball(?) and driving stick. 
#tr.en: Goddess of contention, make battle be pursued like puppets=dolls being manipulated. 
#tr.en: Lady, at the place of clashing of weapons, strike with chaos like the banging down of astragals. 
#tr.en: Inanna, when like an overwhelming storm you are consolidating the contingents of battle, 
#tr.en: when you demonstrate your great ability with the divine mace, the double-headed ax, the big sword and arrows,  
#tr.en: when you put on the fierce armor, let the deluge rage. 
#tr.en: When you make ready your bow/throw-stick(?) and shield of battle, may the storms whirl about for you. 
#tr.en: May your raging divine weapon strike the evil person with lightning like (the plague god) Erra. 
#tr.en: Lady, at the place of clashing of weapons and planting of standards, no one can get away from the opening of your arms. 
#tr.en: My daughter, wherever it is pleasing to you to extend upwards, to extend downwards, to pull taut or to loosen, 
#tr.en: Having no limits at the place where destinies are decided, your pronouncements are indeed as great as my pronouncements. 
#tr.en: At festivals, offerings, banquets, prostration(?), making obeisance, and invoking the name (of the god), 
#tr.en: a human being whose god has gotten very angry with him, whose goddess has become soured/jealous towards him, 
#tr.en: as long as he does not seek out the place of reconciliation with your divinity, no god will be agreeable to his petition. 
#tr.en: At my city, the mountain of Sumer and Akkad, the shade of the world quarters, 
#tr.en: at Duranki, the bond of heaven and earth, the foundation of all constructed settlements,  
#tr.en: at my royal dais reposing like a horned bull (or elephant?) at the obeisances of the gods, 
#tr.en: at my sanctuary Nippur, the shrine of Enlil-ship, the mainstay/great wall of the nation, 
#tr.en: the sanctuary, the relaxing dwelling place which is called by my name, 
#tr.en: may your ladyship also be manifested in that place, may your name be called Queen of Nippur! 
#tr.en: The good protective spirit, (my) eloquent god who is standing in front of me, 
#tr.en: the craftsman of the centerpoint of the Ekur temple, discoverer of advice and planning, the finest oil, 
#tr.en: let be your guardian be he against whom your wrath was great and whom your divine fury has overcome. 
#tr.en: May wise Nin-imma'imma cool your heart with pleasant conversations. 
#tr.en: Lady, I have established for you my weighty commands, divine powers that should not be demanded by anyone; 
#tr.en: as I (have done), may Ea, king of the Apsu, treat you well.

#tr.en: Year: “The high-priestess of Eridu was hired.” 
#tr.en: Inim-Šara 
#tr.en: son of Ur-nigar. 
#tr.en: To Shamash-hazir
#tr.en: speak,
#tr.en: thus Hammurapi.
#tr.en: Ili-ippalsam the shepherd
#tr.en: thus informed me, as follows:
#tr.en: A field of three bur, which through a sealed document of my lord
#tr.en: is given (lit. sealed) to me,
#tr.en: - four years ago Etel-pî-Marduk took it away from me and
#tr.en: takes its barley regularly.
#tr.en: I informed Sîn-iddinam,
#tr.en: but it was not returned to me.
#tr.en: Thus he (Ili-ippalsam) informed me.
#tr.en: I (now) have written to Sîn-iddinam. 
#tr.en: If, as that Ili-ippalsam 
#tr.en: told,
#tr.en: a field of three bur, which through a sealed document in the palace
#tr.en: is given (lit. sealed) to him,
#tr.en: Etel-pî-Marduk took away four years ago and
#tr.en: has the usufruct (on it),
#tr.en: then a worse case
#tr.en: does not exist.
#tr.en: Deal with this matter
#tr.en: well and
#tr.en: have the field according to the sealed document,
#tr.en: which was sealed for him in the palace,
#tr.en: returned to Ili-ippalsam. 
#tr.en: Furthermore, the barley, which for four years
#tr.en: on that field Etel-pî-Marduk
#tr.en: has taken regularly,
#tr.en: investigate through the divine weapon and
#tr.en: to Ili-ippalsam the shepherd
#tr.en: give!
#tr.en: A report regarding this litigation
#tr.en: send!
#tr.en: [When ...] ... 
#tr.en: [... of the four] quarters 
#tr.en: ... an incompetent person [i.e., Nabonidus] was installed to exercise lordship over his country. 
#tr.en: and? [...] he imposed upon them. 
#tr.en: An ersatz of Esagila he made, [and ...] ... for Ur and the rest of the cultic centers, 
#tr.en: a ritual which was improper to them, an [unholy] display [offering x x x without] fear he daily recited. Irreverently, 
#tr.en: he put an end to the regular offerings (and) he interfered [in the cultic centers; ... he] established in the sacred centers. By his own plan, he did away with the worship of Marduk, the king of the gods, 
#tr.en: he continually did evil against Marduk’s city. Daily, [...] without interruption, he imposed the corvee upon its inhabitants unrelentingly, ruining them all. 
#tr.en: Upon hearing their cries, the lord of the gods became furiously angry and [...] their borders; the gods who lived among them forsook their dwellings, 
#tr.en: angry that he [sc. Nabonidus] had brought them to Babylon. Marduk, the exalted, [the lord of the gods], turned towards all the habitations that were abandoned and 
#tr.en: all the people of Sumer and Akkad, who had become corpses. He was reconciled and had mercy upon them. He examined and checked all the entirety of the lands, all of them, 
#tr.en: he searched everywhere and then he took a righteous king, his favorite, by the hand, he called out his name: Cyrus, king of Anshan; he pronounced his name to be king all over the world. 
#tr.en: He made the land of Gutium and all the Umman-manda [i.e., the Medes] bow in submission at his feet. And he [i.e., Cyrus] shepherded with justice and righteousness all the black-headed people, 
#tr.en: over whom he [i.e., Marduk] had given him victory. Marduk, the great lord, guardian of his people, looked with gladness upon his good deeds and upright heart. 
#tr.en: He ordered him to go to his city Babylon. He set him on the road to Babylon and like a companion and a friend, he went at his side. 
#tr.en: His vast army, whose number, like water of the river, cannot be known, marched at his side fully armed. 
#tr.en: He made him enter his city Babylon without fighting or battle; he saved Babylon from hardship. He delivered Nabonidus, the king who did not revere him, into his hands. 
#tr.en: All the people of Babylon, all the land of Sumer and Akkad, princes and governors, bowed to him and kissed his feet. They rejoiced at his kingship and their faces shone. 
#tr.en: Lord by whose aid the dead were revived and who had all been redeemed from hardship and difficulty, they greeted him with gladness and praised his name. 
#tr.en: I am Cyrus, king of the world, great king, mighty king, king of Babylon, king of Sumer and Akkad, king of the four quarters, 
#tr.en: the son of Cambyses, great king, king of Anshan, grandson of Cyrus, great king, king of Anshan, descendant of Teispes, great king, king of Anshan, 
#tr.en: of an eternal line of kingship, whose rule Bel and Nabu love, whose kingship they desire fot their hearts’ pleasure. When I entered Babylon in a peaceful manner, 
#tr.en: I took up my lordly abode in the royal palace amidst rejoicing and happiness. Marduk, the great lord, established as his fate for me a magnanimous heart of one who loves Babylon, and I daily attended to his worship. 
#tr.en: My vast army marched into Babylon in peace; I did not permit anyone to frighten the people of [Sumer] and Akkad. 
#tr.en: I sought the welfare of the city of Babylon and all its sacred centers. As for the citizens of Babylon, [... upon] whom he [i.e., Nabonidus] imposed a corvee which was not the gods’ wish and not befitting them, 
#tr.en: I relieved their weariness and freed them from their service. Marduk, the great lord, rejoiced over [my good] deeds. 
#tr.en: He sent gracious blessing upon me, Cyrus, the king who worships him, and upon Cambyses, the son who is [my] offspring, [and] upon all my army, 
#tr.en: and in peace, before him, we moved around in friendship. [By his] exalted [word], all the kings who sit upon thrones 
#tr.en: throughout the world, from the Upper Sea to the Lower Sea, who live in the districts [far-off], the kings of the West, who dwell in tents, all of them, 
#tr.en: brought their heavy tribute before me and in Babylon they kissed my feet. From [Babylon] to Assur and (from) Susa, 
#tr.en: Agade, Eshnunna, Zamban, Me-Turnu, Der, as far as the region of Gutium, the sacred centers on the other side of the Tigris, whose sanctuaries had been abandoned for a long time, 
#tr.en: I returned the images of the gods, who had resided there [i.e., in Babylon], to their places and I let them dwell in eternal abodes. I gathered all their inhabitants and returned to them their dwellings. 
#tr.en: In addition, at the command of Marduk, the great lord, I settled in their habitations, in pleasing abodes, the gods of Sumer and Akkad, whom Nabonidus, to the anger of the lord of the gods, had brought into Babylon. 
#tr.en: May all the gods whom I settled in their sacred centers ask daily 
#tr.en: of Bel and Nabu that my days be long and may they intercede for my welfare. May they say to Marduk, my lord: “As for Cyrus, the king who reveres you, and Cambyses, his son, 
#tr.en: [...].” The people of Babylon blessed my kingship, and I settled all the lands in peaceful abodes. 
#tr.en: I [daily increased the number offerings to n] geese, two ducks, and ten turledoves above the former offerings of geese, ducks, and turtledoves. 
#tr.en: [...] Dur-Imgur-Enlil, the great wall of Babylon, its defense, I sought to strengthen 
#tr.en: [...] The quay wall of brick, which a former king had built, [but had not] completed its construction, 
#tr.en: [...who had not surrounded the city] on the outside, which no former king had made, (who) a levy of workmen? [had led] into Babylon, 
#tr.en: [... with bitumen] and bricks, I built anew [and completed] their [job]. 
#tr.en: [... magnificent gates of cedar] with a bronze overlay, thresholds and door-sockets [cast in copper, I fixed in all] their [doorways]. 
#tr.en: [...] an inscription with the name of Assurbanipal, a king who had preceded [me, I] saw [in its midst]. 
#tr.en: [...] 
#tr.en: [...] for eternity. 
#tr.en: To Zinu 
#tr.en: speak, 
#tr.en: thus Iddin-Sin: 
#tr.en: May Shamash, Marduk, and Ninshubur 
#tr.en: for my sake forever 
#tr.en: sustain you! 
#tr.en: The garments of others 
#tr.en: year for year 
#tr.en: are improving, 
#tr.en: but as for you, my garments 
#tr.en: year for year 
#tr.en: you reduce! 
#tr.en: In my garments 
#tr.en: reducing and ...-ing, 
#tr.en: you have become rich! 
#tr.en: With respect to the wool in our estate, 
#tr.en: which like bread is being consumed, 
#tr.en: my garments you reduce! 
#tr.en: The son of Adad-iddinam, 
#tr.en: whose father is an underling of my father, 
#tr.en: two new garments, 
#tr.en: wears, but as for you, about my single garment 
#tr.en: you keep obsessing! 
#tr.en: Although you to me 
#tr.en: gave birth, 
#tr.en: and as to him, his mother 
#tr.en: in adoption
#tr.en: adopted him, 
#tr.en: yet although as to him, 
#tr.en: his mother loves him, 
#tr.en: you, you do not really love me. 
#tr.en: 15 mana 
#tr.en: 2 shekels, firm, of Ibni-... .

#tr.en: your servant. 
#tr.en: I, Untaš-Napiriša, son of Humbanumena, king of Anšan 
#tr.en: and of Susa, anxious for my life to be continually prosperous, 
#tr.en: so that I may noy be granted the extinction of my prosperous lineage, 
#tr.en: a temple of baked bricks and a sanctuary of glazed bricks I built; 
#tr.en: I gave it to Inšušinak of the Siyan-kuk and I a temple tower 
#tr.en: erected. May what I made and toiled for, as a gift on my behalf, be acceptable to Inšušinak!

#tr.en: at a well found, 
#tr.en: from the street rescued: 
#tr.en: Simat-Adad, the nugig, 
#tr.en: from the mouth of a dog has snatched , 
#tr.en: from the beak of a raven has made drop. 
#tr.en: Simat-Adad, the nugig, 
#tr.en: him as her son has adopted (and) 
#tr.en: him as her heir has established. 
#tr.en: In the future, if  
#tr.en: Simat-Adad, the nugig, 
#tr.en: “You are not my son!” says to him, 
#tr.en: house, field, orchard, female and male slaves, 
#tr.en: possessions and utensils, 
#tr.en: as much as there may be 
#tr.en: she shall forfeit.

#tr.en: King, Sargon, king
#tr.en: of Agade of the broad squares,
#tr.en: strong king, who negotiates with the
#tr.en: gods. Adad gave him strength,
#tr.en: and from east
#tr.en: to west
#tr.en: I seized the land. 
#tr.en: In one day 
#tr.en: I fought against 70 cities;
#tr.en: their princes I took prisoner and
#tr.en: their cities I destroyed. By Adad, the lord of strength,
#tr.en: and Ishtar, the lade of battle,
#tr.en: I swear (to it). I saw a gazelle and 
#tr.en: I threw a brick into the river. During 
#tr.en: my running the inscription was loosened,
#tr.en: I set up the inscription. I ran and  
#tr.en: caught the gazelle. (Then) I raised the brick
#tr.en: from the water. By Adad and Ishtar
#tr.en: I swear (to it). 1000 oxen and 6000 
#tr.en: sheep I did indeed slaughter daily.
#tr.en: 7000 of my heroes who daily eat
#tr.en: breast-meat before me,
#tr.en: 3000 of my scouts,
#tr.en: who eat rump-meat,
#tr.en: 1000 of my cupbearers, who
#tr.en: daily eat the top part 
#tr.en: of the lower leg up to 
#tr.en: the roasted part
#tr.en: ... invited.
#tr.en: 7000 of my heroes
#tr.en: ate breast-meat.
#tr.en: There was not enough breast-meat 
#tr.en: for the rear. His ox, 
#tr.en: the ... of his throne,
#tr.en: he slaughtered and he gave the breast-meat 
#tr.en: to the rear. My cook
#tr.en: distributed the cuts of meat.
#tr.en: As a punishment 100 oxen
#tr.en: and 200 sheep he slaughtered,
#tr.en: and he fed it to my servants. By Adad
#tr.en: and Ishtar I swear (to it). For seven years, one month
#tr.en: and 15 days I stayed with 
#tr.en: my creditors at the meal. 
#tr.en: Upon my leaving, I did indeed bind
#tr.en: a rod of carnelian and lapis lazuli, and
#tr.en: I did distribute it over the land.
#tr.en: At mount Amanum, which
#tr.en: I defeated twice, i set up a statue
#tr.en: like a foundation peg in its middle.
#tr.en: The prince
#tr.en: of Tukrish I dressed with a skin.  
#tr.en: In Hutura, I placed ... on their heads.
#tr.en: I covered their heads like
#tr.en: that of a woman 
#tr.en: with an Alasian (cloth). Those of Amurru,
#tr.en: like their fathers, 
#tr.en: their ... of the land, I finished. Those of Kilaru
#tr.en: I bound their heads
#tr.en: in a bundle. Again, the people of Kanesh
#tr.en: their ... I let loose. 
#tr.en: Those of Hatu, the midst of their heads I skinned. Of Luhme 
#tr.en: the toggle-pin I sharpened, the Gutian one. Lullum and Hahhum, their ... I made rich.
#tr.en: The four posts of heaven I touched with hand. Why should I enlarge 
#tr.en: what is on the tablet? Anum does not know how I am king, (and) how I
#tr.en: took the lower and the upper country. 
#tr.en: May Adad, the king, make my offering abundant.

#tr.en: 417 workdays, male laborers: 
#tr.en: leveled, sheaves piled, grain harvested 
#tr.en: in New Field and Priests Field;

#tr.en: under seal of Inim-Inanna; 
#tr.en: year after: “Amar-Suen is king.” 
#tr.en: Inim-Inanna, 
#tr.en: son of Lugal-itida. 
#tr.en: A’anzu. 
#tr.en: 105 beams 
#tr.en: from the docks 
#tr.en: (to) the Emaš 
#tr.en: delivered; 
#tr.en: month: “House-month-6,” 
#tr.en: year: “Šu-Suen is king.” 
#tr.en: There was a young man, a son of Nippur, destitute and poor; 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta was his name, a miserable man, 
#tr.en: in his city Nippur exhausted he was living, and 
#tr.en: he had no silver fitting of his people, 
#tr.en: gold he had none fitting of the citizens; 
#tr.en: his storehouse thirsted for pure Nisaba (grain), 
#tr.en: for craving of bread his gut burned, 
#tr.en: for craving of meat and fine beer, miserable was his countenance. 
#tr.en: Daily with nothing to eat hungry he was lying; 
#tr.en: and he wore a garment without change, 
#tr.en: with his miserable heart he took counsel: 
#tr.en: “Let me strip off my garment without change, and 
#tr.en: in the square of my city Nippur a ram buy!” 
#tr.en: He stripped off his garment without change and 
#tr.en: in the square of his city Nippur a three year old nanny goat bought. 
#tr.en: with his miserable heart that one took counsel: 
#tr.en: “Perhaps in my courtyard I will slaughter the nanny goat, 
#tr.en: but there would be no banquet: where is the beer? 
#tr.en: They will hear of it, the neighbors of my gate, and will be enraged; 
#tr.en: kith and kin will be angry with me. 
#tr.en: Let me take and to the house of the mayor bring the nanny, 
#tr.en: a good and fair thing let me make delicious for his stomach!” 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta grasped the nape of the nanny, 
#tr.en: to the gate of the mayor of Nippur that one approached, 
#tr.en: to Tukulti-Enlil, the keeper of the gate, words he speaks: 
#tr.en: “Speak!, that I may enter and see the mayor.” 
#tr.en: The doorman to his lord words speaks: 
#tr.en: “My lord, a son of Nippur waits at your gate, 
#tr.en: and as a greeting gift he brought you a nanny.” 
#tr.en: The mayor is angry with the doorman Tukulti-Enlil: 
#tr.en: “Why is a son of Nippur waiting at the gate?” 
#tr.en: the doorman to ... 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta in the fullness of his heart entered before the mayor. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta before the mayor entering, 
#tr.en: in his left hand grasped the nape of his nanny, 
#tr.en: he raised his right hand greeting the mayor: 
#tr.en: “May Enlil and Nippur bless the mayor! 
#tr.en: May Adad and Nusku cause to flourish his seed!” 
#tr.en: The mayor to the son of Nippur the words speaks: 
#tr.en: “What is your loss, that a gift you are carrying?” 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta to the mayor of Nippur his order relates: 
#tr.en: “Daily with nothing to eat hungry I was lying; 
#tr.en: so I tore off my garment of no change and 
#tr.en: in the square of my city Nippur I bought a three year old goat, 
#tr.en: to my miserable heart I thus spoke: 
#tr.en: “Perhaps in my courtyard I will slaughter the nanny, 
#tr.en: but there would be no banquet: where is the beer? 
#tr.en: they will hear of it, the neighbors of my gate, and will be enraged;
#tr.en: kith and kin will be angry with me; 
#tr.en: let me take and to the mayor bring the nanny!” 
#tr.en: Thus I spoke to my heart. 
#tr.en: ... the butcher was crying out at night(?); 
#tr.en: ... may they be captured(?); 
#tr.en: ... may it be overflowing, the table, 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... he cried, and 
#tr.en: ... .
#tr.en: “Give to the son of Nippur bone and gristle, 
#tr.en: let him drink from your flask third-rate beer, and 
#tr.en: send him away and let him go out from the gate!” 
#tr.en: He gave him, the son of Nippur, bone and sinew, 
#tr.en: let him drink from his flask third-rate beer, and 
#tr.en: sent him away and let him leave through the gate. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta, through the gate leaving, 
#tr.en: to the doorman, the gatekeeper, the words speaks: 
#tr.en: “To your lord the blessings of the gods thus say to him! 
#tr.en: Because of the one burden you imposed on me,  
#tr.en: for the one, three I will repay you.” 
#tr.en: The mayor heard this and all day long laughed. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta to the palace of the king directed his face:
#tr.en: “On instruction of the king, prince and governor reach just judgment.” 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta, before the king entering, 
#tr.en: bowed down, and kissed the ground before him. 
#tr.en: He raised his hands, the king of the universe greeting: 
#tr.en: “Ruler, life of the people, king strengthened by a guardian spirit, 
#tr.en: one chariot by your command let them give me, 
#tr.en: that for 1 day, whatever I wish I may achieve! 
#tr.en: For my day, my repayment shall be one mina of red gold.” 
#tr.en: He did not ask him, the king, “Your desire is what, 
#tr.en: that one chariot you would ride all day?” 
#tr.en: they gave to him a new chariot, fitting for grandees, 
#tr.en: they girded him with a new sash, fitting for ..., 
#tr.en: he mounted the new chariot, fitting for grandees, 
#tr.en: to his city, Duranki, he set his face. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta two birds caught, 
#tr.en: stuck in a box and sealed with his seal; 
#tr.en: to the gate of the mayor of Nippur that one went. 
#tr.en: The mayor before him went outside: 
#tr.en: “Who are you, my lord, that you drove here at dusk?” 
#tr.en: “The king, your lord, sent me to Duranki: 
#tr.en: “To Ekur, the house of Enlil, gold take!” 
#tr.en: The mayor, to offer an extravagant meal, slaughtered a pasillu; 
#tr.en: ditto (the mayor) before him “O, am I ever tired!” said to him. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta at the head of the mayor for the watch of the night (=first watch) sat; 
#tr.en: the mayor in his weariness was overcome by sleep; 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninura in that of the night (=second watch) like a thief got up, and 
#tr.en: opened the gate of that same box, and the birds flew out to the heavens. 
#tr.en: The mayor, at the break of dawn, was shocked, ... 
#tr.en: “Open is the gate of the box, carried off is the gold!” 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta, in the anguish of his heart, rent his garments. 
#tr.en: he set upon and the mayor let beg (for mercy), 
#tr.en: from his head to the soles of his feet 
#tr.en: his limbs he beat, vexation he imposed upon him. 
#tr.en: The mayor beneath him in dread was crying out: 
#tr.en: “My lord, a son of Nippur do not destroy! 
#tr.en: They gave him as his present two minas of red gold; 
#tr.en: instead of his garment that he rent, a second one he gave him. 
#tr.en: Gimil Ninurta through the gate exiting 
#tr.en: to Tukulti-Enlil, the gatekeeper, the words speaks: 
#tr.en: “To your lord the abundance of the gods, thus speak to him: 
#tr.en: “For the one load that you imposed upon me, 
#tr.en: one I have repaid you, two remain.” 
#tr.en: The mayor heard this, and all day wept. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta before the barber entered; 
#tr.en: he cut off all the hair on the left and ...; 
#tr.en: an n-vessel with the deposit of fire he filled, ..., 
#tr.en: to the gate of the mayor of Nippur that one went, 
#tr.en: to the doorman, the keeper of the gate, the words speaks: 
#tr.en: “Speak, that I would enter and see your lord.” 
#tr.en: “Who are you, that you would see him?” 
#tr.en: “A doctor, native of Isin, an examiner, am I! 
#tr.en: Where sickness and suffering in the body ...”. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta, before the mayor entering, 
#tr.en: where he (Gimil-Ninurta) his body had thrashed, he (GN) his bruises uncovered for him. 
#tr.en: The mayor to his eunuchs, “The doctor is able,” said. 
#tr.en: “My lord, in darkness do my cures make whole, 
#tr.en: where foot-traffic is removed, too dark for a pathway.” 
#tr.en: He let him enter ... a chamber, a place of no access, 
#tr.en: where friend or associate will not have pity on him; 
#tr.en: the n-vessel he threw into the heart of the fire. 
#tr.en: He drove into the hard earth five pegs, 
#tr.en: on hands, feet and head he bound him; 
#tr.en: from head to the sole of his feet his limbs he beat, vexation he imposed upon him. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta, through the gate exiting, 
#tr.en: to Tukulti-Enlil, the gatekeeper, the words speaks: 
#tr.en: “To your lord the abundance of the gods, thus speak to him: 
#tr.en: “For the 1 load that you imposed upon me, 
#tr.en: 2 I have repaid you, 1 remains.” 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta was troubled, like a dog he lifted up his ears. 
#tr.en: he looked at the collective black-headed ones, observing all the young men; 
#tr.en: he caught one man ... of Nippur,
#tr.en: gave him as a gift ... a nanny:
#tr.en: “Go to the gate of the mayor of Nippur and set up a cry; 
#tr.en: at your cry let gather all the broad young men!” 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta under the bridge crouched, like a dog. 
#tr.en: The mayor at the cry of the young man came outside, 
#tr.en: sent out the people of his house, female and male; 
#tr.en: they flew off in their entirety searching for the man; 
#tr.en: while they in their entirety ditto (were searching for the man), 
#tr.en: the mayor went outside alone. 
#tr.en: Gimil-Ninurta from below the bridge sprang, and seized the mayor. 
#tr.en: he put upon him, and the mayor caused to beg (for mercy);
#tr.en:  from his head to the soles of his feet 
#tr.en: his limbs he beat, vexation he imposed upon him: 
#tr.en: “Because of the one burden you imposed on me,
#tr.en:  3 I paid you back.” 
#tr.en:  He left him behind, and went out into the countryside; 
#tr.en: The mayor, crawling, entered the city.

#tr.en: and placing foot on his head,

#tr.en: axes of iron and gold ore, caressed ..., 
#tr.en: like a roof-snake, may my mouth bring forth venom.

#tr.en: I shall ... from his strength.

#tr.en: I shall catch them like gazelles in the woods.

#tr.en: like ... from above having ... 
#tr.en: like steppe asses I trap them violently in a hole outfitted with a net. 
#tr.en: Against their glorified one, I shall set ... in battle, 
#tr.en: May my fierce weapons give him venom like a gnawing serpent.

#tr.en: the man coiling like a ...-snake 
#tr.en: like a sick, ... bull, I shall make his head sink in the soil. 
#tr.en: The little ones who escaped with their lives, 
#tr.en: as long as they live, like the all-covering locust, I shall make eat bitter soil.” 
#tr.en: “My lance against the ... I shall grow, 
#tr.en: my emblems at the border of the foreign lands I shall station. 
#tr.en: I fill my quiver to overflowing. 
#tr.en: May my bow, like a raging snake, ever gnash for me; 
#tr.en: may barbed arrows continually flash before me like lightning; 
#tr.en: may barbar-arrows, like flying bats, 
#tr.en: continually fly for me into the mouth of battle;

#tr.en: “Those who lie on the roofs of the foreign lands, on the roofs I shall kill; 
#tr.en: those who lie on the city walls I shall grind up on the city walls. 
#tr.en: Whoever stood with me, I shall let stand on his feet; 
#tr.en: whoever did not stand with me, I shall grind up on the spot. 
#tr.en: The young ones of the foreign lands I shall let ride off on ships, 
#tr.en: the big ones I shall “send back from old age”. 
#tr.en: To those who did not return and spread out, the days will not be long!” 
#tr.en: “I, the king, shall avenge my city. 
#tr.en: Whatever was destroyed in Sumer, in the foreign lands I shall destroy. 
#tr.en: The gods of their cities I shall cause to “get into shoes”; 
#tr.en: their pretty-face udug and lamma protective deities I shall let step out.

#tr.en: their small trees I shall uproot;

#tr.en: their trees of wealth I shall “cross over” at the crown.

#tr.en: may ... plants and ... herbs continually break through the earth.”

#tr.en: With a big wild bull of the mountains with uplifted horns 
#tr.en: with a sheep led by the hand of an en priest at his right side, 
#tr.en: with a reddish kid and a bearded kid doubled up on the breast, 
#tr.en: before Inanna in the shrine of E-anna he enters. 
#tr.en: Good shepherd Šulgi, loving heart, dressed himself in a ma garment, 
#tr.en: put a ḫili wig as a crown on his head. 
#tr.en: Inanna marveled, 
#tr.en: and spontaneously struck up a song, 
#tr.en: singing the lyrics: 
#tr.en: “When for the king, for the lord, 
#tr.en: I have bathed, 
#tr.en: when for the shepherd Dumuzi I have bathed, 
#tr.en: when I have adorned my sides with clay, 
#tr.en: when with resin I have colored my nose, 
#tr.en: when with kohl I have covered my face, 
#tr.en: when with hands of his fairness, 
#tr.en: he has covered my hips, 
#tr.en: when the lord who lies down beside silver Inanna, 
#tr.en: the shepherd Dumuzi, 
#tr.en: (has said) ‘I would loosen that of the lap’, 
#tr.en: when in my radiant arms he has grown calm, 
#tr.en: when ... like choice beer 
#tr.en: ... had touched, 
#tr.en: when my lap-wool has ..., 
#tr.en: my pa-wool he has played, 
#tr.en: when he has put hand to my vulva, 
#tr.en: when on my sweet stomach he has lain, 
#tr.en: like his night boat ..., 
#tr.en: like his thin boat he has finished, 
#tr.en: when on the bed he has caressed me, 
#tr.en: then the lord I shall caress, 
#tr.en: I shall decree him a good destiny; 
#tr.en: the good shepherd Šulgi I shall caress, 
#tr.en: decree him a good destiny. 
#tr.en: his thick arms I shall caress, 
#tr.en: shepherdship of all lands 
#tr.en: as his destiny I shall decree.” 
#tr.en: The lady, the mountain-crystal of heaven, 
#tr.en: delight of the black-headed, 
#tr.en: youthful woman who excels her mother, 
#tr.en: by her father granted divine powers, 
#tr.en: Inanna, daughter of Suen, 
#tr.en: for Šulgi, son of Ninsun, 
#tr.en: decrees a destiny: 
#tr.en: “Your ‘walking to the fore in battle’ am I! 
#tr.en: Your ‘weapon carrier in combat like an attendant’ am I! 
#tr.en: Your ‘advocate in the assembly’ am I! 
#tr.en: Your ‘breath-giver in the campaign’ am I! 
#tr.en: Shepherd chosen by ... silver are you! 
#tr.en: King, good provider of Eanna are you. 
#tr.en: carneol of An’s Irigal are you! 
#tr.en: fir for running, 
#tr.en: fit to lift head in the august dais are you! 
#tr.en: fit to take a seat on the lapis throne, 
#tr.en: your head fit to wear a colorful, 
#tr.en: as to your body, fit to spread out a the fleece-garment, 
#tr.en: fit for stomach-hanging of the garment of royalty, 
#tr.en: fit to lift to the side the mitum-weapon, 
#tr.en: fit to open knees with mace, 
#tr.en: fit to send off straight the broad arrows, 
#tr.en: fit for throwing stick and shield bound to the hips, 
#tr.en: as to your hands, fit for silver staff, 
#tr.en: as to your feet, fit for silver sandals, 
#tr.en: You have knees! On the campaign, fit for running, 
#tr.en: fit for playing, like a calf of lapis, on my silver breast; 
#tr.en: May your loving stomach be lasting! 
#tr.en: An has doned this for you, may he never alter it! 
#tr.en: May Enlil, the decreer of fates, never change it!” 
#tr.en: So did Inanna caress him. 
#tr.en: He who knows the joyful heart of Ninegal 
#tr.en: sheared a black kid 
#tr.en: bathed a white kid; 
#tr.en: wild bulls of the mountains by their noses tied up 
#tr.en: —house of the august breeding bull roars— 
#tr.en: up to the young man Utu into the temple E-babbar brings, 
#tr.en: up to the young man Utu raising his radiant forehead, 
#tr.en: For Šulgi, good shepherd of Sumer, he decress a fate: 
#tr.en: “King, colorful words, sweet face, 
#tr.en: mighty hero, born to be a lion, 
#tr.en: young cow standing firm in its vigor, 
#tr.en: valiant, unbound in his strength, 
#tr.en: whose feet trample great mountains: 
#tr.en: the heroes of the foreign lands you have brought down, 
#tr.en: you have trampled upon all the thrones, 
#tr.en: your name to the edge of heaven you have established. 
#tr.en: Your king—to Ašimbabbar go in peace.” 
#tr.en: And so at Enegir, city built in splendor, 
#tr.en: did he not moor the boat? 
#tr.en: “Seed placed by the prince in the silver womb, born on the bright mountain, 
#tr.en: Ninazu, like a wild bull lowing in drink, 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ...” 
#tr.en: “... like date syrup, ghee ... 
#tr.en: your are hero! Come down from the revolting lands ... 
#tr.en: King, the lord of prayers and supplications chooses you by heart; 
#tr.en: shepherd Šulgi, the lord of prayers and supplications chooses you by heart; 
#tr.en: Who sets a king given strength by Enlil? 
#tr.en: Who enters to your ...? 
#tr.en: Who exits to your ...? 
#tr.en: ... who knows your stomach should not desire your strength. 
#tr.en: Having desired ... battle with you 
#tr.en: what escapes your outstretched arms? 
#tr.en: When like the thunder bird you shriek, who stands before you? 
#tr.en: When like the storm you howl, 
#tr.en: the foreign lands, open reeds ablaze, mountains trembling like reeds, 
#tr.en: in the houses of the foreign lands watching, 
#tr.en: Tidnum well marveled. 
#tr.en: Like Utu, your terror radiates in battle. 
#tr.en: Like Nergal, your mace drools in death 
#tr.en: your lance reaches into the blood of the Land. 
#tr.en: The great door of the city are you, the great wall of the Land are you! 
#tr.en: A net piled up over heaven and earth are you, lead-jenny positioned with Sumer are you, 
#tr.en: May your ... call in abundance! 
#tr.en: May the words of Enlil, enormous things, create shade on your head! 
#tr.en: May the loving heart Inanna never abandon you!” 
#tr.en: After Ninazu had called ... blessings again and again, 
#tr.en: he let ewes goodly produce endless lambs, 
#tr.en: let jennies goodly produce endless kids, 
#tr.en: let white cows set up calves, 
#tr.en: then before Nanna in his E-temen-ni-guru he enters with them, 
#tr.en: head held high in the most fitting house of the the royal household, in its royal offering place, the silver place. 
#tr.en: His king Ašimbabbar casts a joyous glance at him, 
#tr.en: for Šulgi, the good shepherd of Sumer, decreed a fate: 
#tr.en: “Hero, lord, mighty one of the foreign lands, right arm of the Land, 
#tr.en: you have achieved victory for me, have carried out the commandeds. 
#tr.en: The houses of the rebel lands that I have cursed you have reduced to ruin mounds. 
#tr.en: May you never grow weary of perfecting the divine powers for me every month at new moon! 
#tr.en: Like Ašnan, may your name be as sweet in the mouth of the Land and in the mouths of all the countries! 
#tr.en: May silver Ningal, lady of the Enunna, like the wooden frame of a waterskin spread out her lap for you! 
#tr.en: Thus did Suen decree a good fate. 
#tr.en: In the Egal-maḫ of Ninegal, he took his seat on the silver throne. 
#tr.en: The Ištaran of Sumer, omniscient from the womb, 
#tr.en: renders the judgments of the Land in due order, 
#tr.en: makes decisions for the Land in due order 
#tr.en: lets no strong man wrong the weak, 
#tr.en: lets mother speak sweetly to her child 
#tr.en: lets child answer truthfully to his father. 
#tr.en: Sumer is filled with abundance, 
#tr.en: Ur prolonged in splendor, 
#tr.en: ... establishes. 
#tr.en: Because the king exulted in his triumph and let his might radiate, 
#tr.en: his heroism set well, 
#tr.en: made the rebellious lands bow, 
#tr.en: made our city Ur raise neck in prosperity; 
#tr.en: king, adorned with a face of colorful lapis, son of Enlil; 
#tr.en: lifting up head to heaven in broad crown, 
#tr.en: with An in his lofty place taking counsel, sitting with Uraš on a big throne, 
#tr.en: manth and passing days making the Land of Sumer and all the foreign lands play joyously— 
#tr.en: praise be to Lord Ašimbabbar! 
#tr.en: praise be to Nisaba!

#tr.en: When great An, 
#tr.en: the father of the gods, 
#tr.en: and Enlil, 
#tr.en: king of all the lands, 
#tr.en: the lord who was to determine the fates, 
#tr.en: to Ninisina, 
#tr.en: the daughter of An, 
#tr.en: the humble lady 
#tr.en: who in her own authority 
#tr.en: delighted, 
#tr.en: their regard towards her shining brow 
#tr.en: they having directed, 
#tr.en: and to Isin, 
#tr.en: her demarcated area 
#tr.en: established by An, 
#tr.en: a favorable reign 
#tr.en: and the kingship 
#tr.en: of Sumer and Akkad 
#tr.en: they having given— 
#tr.en: At that time, 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, 
#tr.en: the obediant shepherd, 
#tr.en: with a name chosen 
#tr.en: by Nunamnir, 
#tr.en: in order that justice 
#tr.en: might be established in the country, 
#tr.en: that complaints 
#tr.en: be eliminated from mouths, 
#tr.en: that evil and violence 
#tr.en: be turned aside by weaponry, 
#tr.en: that Sumer and Akkad’s 
#tr.en: substance might be made pleasing, 
#tr.en: when by An 
#tr.en: and by Enlil 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar 
#tr.en: for the princeship of the country 
#tr.en: had been chosen, 
#tr.en: then 
#tr.en: I, Lipit-Ištar, 
#tr.en: the humble shepherd 
#tr.en: of Nippur, 
#tr.en: the faithful farmer 
#tr.en: of Ur, 
#tr.en: the unceasing supporter 
#tr.en: of Eridu, 
#tr.en: a proper lord 
#tr.en: of Uruk, 
#tr.en: the king of Isin 
#tr.en: and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
#tr.en: the one fit for the heart 
#tr.en: of Inanna, 
#tr.en: at the command of Enlil 
#tr.en: justice 
#tr.en: in Sumer and Akkad 
#tr.en: I instituted. 
#tr.en: At that time, 
#tr.en: the sons and daughters 
#tr.en: of Nippur, 
#tr.en: the sons and daughters 
#tr.en: of Ur, 
#tr.en: the sons and daughters 
#tr.en: of Isin, 
#tr.en: the sons and daughters 
#tr.en: of Sumer and Akkad, 
#tr.en: those upon whose necks 
#tr.en: the yoke of servitude 
#tr.en: had been imposed, 
#tr.en: their freedom 
#tr.en: I brought about, 
#tr.en: and I had them taken back to their cities. 
#tr.en: From the first, 
#tr.en: the fathers their children 
#tr.en: I made support, 
#tr.en: and the children their fathers 
#tr.en: I made support. 
#tr.en: The fathers by their children 
#tr.en: I made stand, 
#tr.en: and the children by their fathers 
#tr.en: I made stand. 
#tr.en: The household of the father 
#tr.en: and the household of the brothers 
#tr.en: all of them 
#tr.en: I made do service. 
#tr.en: I, Lipit-Ištar, 
#tr.en: the son of Enlil, 
#tr.en: the household of the father 
#tr.en: and the household of the brothers 
#tr.en: I made do service 70 (days per year), 
#tr.en: and the household of a single dependent worker 
#tr.en: I made do service 10 days per month.

#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ...

#tr.en: the son of a man [...] 
#tr.en: ...

#tr.en: which was ..., 
#tr.en: ...

#tr.en: its ...

#tr.en: and the son of the overseer, 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: the boat ... 
#tr.en: and the boat ... 
#tr.en: he shall replace the boat. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: hired a boat, 
#tr.en: and a stated route 
#tr.en: one had established for him, 
#tr.en: but he himself that route 
#tr.en: did change, 
#tr.en: and in that place the cabin-boat 
#tr.en: was subjected to a robbery, 
#tr.en: the man who hired the boat 
#tr.en: shall replace the boat. 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: as(?) his gift 
#tr.en: he shall give(?) to it. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: his orchard 
#tr.en: to an orchardman 
#tr.en: as an orchard rental 
#tr.en: to be brought up(?) 
#tr.en: he has given to him, 
#tr.en: and the orchardman 
#tr.en: for the owner of the orchard 
#tr.en: date palms(?) 
#tr.en: has been able to plant, 
#tr.en: of those date palms 
#tr.en: from 1/10 of them 
#tr.en: their dates 
#tr.en: he can have the usufruct of. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man to another man 
#tr.en: in order to plant trees for an orchard 
#tr.en: has given empty land, 
#tr.en: but upon that empty land 
#tr.en: the planting of trees for a orchard 
#tr.en: he did not finish, 
#tr.en: to the man who planted the orchard, 
#tr.en: included in his allotted share 
#tr.en: the empty land which was left (unplanted) 
#tr.en: shall be given to him. 
#tr.en: If a man 
#tr.en: went down into another man’s orchard 
#tr.en: and was seized for stealing, 
#tr.en: he shall pay 10 shekels of silver. 
#tr.en: If a man 
#tr.en: in another man’s orchard 
#tr.en: cut down a tree, 
#tr.en: 1/2 mina of silver 
#tr.en: he shall pay. 
#tr.en: If next to a man’s 
#tr.en: house located adjacently 
#tr.en: another man leaves abandoned empty land, 
#tr.en: and the owner of the house 
#tr.en: to the owner of the empty land: 
#tr.en: ‘Your empty land is left neglected, 
#tr.en: someone will break into my house; 
#tr.en: strengthen your estate!’ 
#tr.en: has said, 
#tr.en: and a contractual agreement with him to that effect 
#tr.en: he has proved, 
#tr.en: the owner of the empty land 
#tr.en: to the owner of the house 
#tr.en: anything that he has lost 
#tr.en: he shall replace. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man’s female or male slave 
#tr.en: has fled within a city 
#tr.en: and that in another man’s house 
#tr.en: for 1 month 
#tr.en: (that slave) has lived 
#tr.en: he has confirmed, 
#tr.en: a slave like a slave 
#tr.en: he shall give. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: he has no slave, 
#tr.en: 15 shekels of silver 
#tr.en: he shall pay. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man’s slave 
#tr.en: to his master 
#tr.en: his slave status 
#tr.en: has contested, 
#tr.en: when to his master 
#tr.en: his slave status 
#tr.en: 2 times 
#tr.en: he has proved, 
#tr.en: that slave 
#tr.en: shall be released. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a miqtum(-person) 
#tr.en: is a gift of the king, 
#tr.en: he cannot be taken away. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a miqtum(-person) 
#tr.en: of his own accord 
#tr.en: has gone to (serve?) another man, 
#tr.en: that man 
#tr.en: shall not be touched; 
#tr.en: wherever he wishes 
#tr.en: he may go. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man by another man 
#tr.en: heedlessly(?) 
#tr.en: of something about which he had no knowledge 
#tr.en: has been accused, 
#tr.en: and that other man 
#tr.en: has not proved it, 
#tr.en: in the matter of which he accused him 
#tr.en: its assessed penalty he shall bear. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: the master of an estate 
#tr.en: or mistress of an estate 
#tr.en: on the taxes of the estate 
#tr.en: has defaulted, 
#tr.en: and another person has borne them, 
#tr.en: until the 3rd year 
#tr.en: he shall not be evicted; 
#tr.en: the person who the estate taxes 
#tr.en: has borne 
#tr.en: shall take the estate, 
#tr.en: and the owner of the estate 
#tr.en: may make no claims. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: the owner of the house 
#tr.en: he can ... 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: a child from a well 
#tr.en: has pulled out, 
#tr.en: on his feet ... 
#tr.en: the day ... the foster-child. 
#tr.en: If a man 
#tr.en: cannot raise a foster-child according to his abilities(?), 
#tr.en: when this has been confirmed before the judges 
#tr.en: he shall be returned to his birth-mother. 
#tr.en: If a man 
#tr.en: a daughter as a foster-child [...] 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: If ... he married, 
#tr.en: (regarding) the gift of her father’s house 
#tr.en: which was presented to her 
#tr.en: as his heir 
#tr.en: she may take it away. 
#tr.en: If ... he gave it to the wife, 
#tr.en: the gift of her father’s house 
#tr.en: which was presented to her 
#tr.en: by the brothers 
#tr.en: shall not be divided, 
#tr.en: and/but ... 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: while the father is still living 
#tr.en: if his daughter, 
#tr.en: be she an ugbabtu priestess, a cloistered nadītu 
#tr.en: or a qadištu woman, 
#tr.en: considering her as an (equal) heir 
#tr.en: they (all) shall distribute the estate. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a daughter, when she was still living in her father’s house, 
#tr.en: he did not give to a husband, 
#tr.en: her brothers 
#tr.en: shall give her to a husband. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: he took a slave, 
#tr.en: and [...] has died 
#tr.en: ... a stranger(?) 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: when ... shall marry 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a later wife 
#tr.en: whom he married 
#tr.en: has born him children, 
#tr.en: the (marriage) gifts 
#tr.en: which from her father’s house 
#tr.en: she had brought 
#tr.en: belong to her children; 
#tr.en: the children of the equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: and the children of the later wife 
#tr.en: the property of their father 
#tr.en: equally 
#tr.en: they shall divide. 
#tr.en: If a man 
#tr.en: married a wife, 
#tr.en: and she bore him a child, 
#tr.en: and that child lived, 
#tr.en: and a slave woman for her master 
#tr.en: also bore him a child, 
#tr.en: the father the slave woman 
#tr.en: and her children 
#tr.en: shall bring about their freedom; 
#tr.en: the children of the slave woman 
#tr.en: with the children of the master 
#tr.en: shall not share the estate. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: his equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: has died, 
#tr.en: and after (the death of) his wife 
#tr.en: his slave woman into the status of wife 
#tr.en: he shall take, 
#tr.en: the children of his equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: are his heirs; 
#tr.en: a child of the slave woman 
#tr.en: whom to her master 
#tr.en: she has born, 
#tr.en: will be a child equal to a free child; 
#tr.en: his (share of the) estate shall be made good. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: whose wife 
#tr.en: has not born him a child, 
#tr.en: but a prostitute 
#tr.en: from the town square 
#tr.en: has born him a child, 
#tr.en: that prostitute’s 
#tr.en: grain ration, oil ration, 
#tr.en: and wool ration 
#tr.en: he shall provide to her; 
#tr.en: the child 
#tr.en: that she has born to him 
#tr.en: shall be his heir; 
#tr.en: however long his wife 
#tr.en: is alive, 
#tr.en: the prostitute 
#tr.en: with the equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: shall not reside in the house. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man’s 
#tr.en: equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: her eyes have changed(?), 
#tr.en: or she has become paralyzed, 
#tr.en: she shall not be evicted from the house; 
#tr.en: her husband 
#tr.en: a 2nd wife 
#tr.en: may marry; 
#tr.en: the later wife must 
#tr.en: the equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: support. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a son-in-law 
#tr.en: the house of his father-in-law 
#tr.en: has entered, 
#tr.en: and he has made the betrothal gift, 
#tr.en: and afterward 
#tr.en: they have evicted him 
#tr.en: and his wife to his friend 
#tr.en: they have given, 
#tr.en: his bethroval gift 
#tr.en: which he brought 
#tr.en: they shall double for him; 
#tr.en: that wife his friend 
#tr.en: shall not marry. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a young man having a wife 
#tr.en: a prostitute in the town square 
#tr.en: has had, 
#tr.en: and that to that prostitute 
#tr.en: he should not return 
#tr.en: the judges have told him, 
#tr.en: and afterwards his equal-ranking wife 
#tr.en: he has divorced, 
#tr.en: when he has paid her his divorce money, 
#tr.en: he may not marry that prostitute. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a father while living 
#tr.en: to a son favored in his eyes 
#tr.en: has presented a gift 
#tr.en: and has written him a sealed document, 
#tr.en: after the father has died, 
#tr.en: the heirs 
#tr.en: shall divide the father’s estate, 
#tr.en: but they shall not divide the (already) allotted share; 
#tr.en: the word of their father 
#tr.en: they shall not say ... . 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a father who is still living 
#tr.en: to his eldest son 
#tr.en: has given a betrothal gift, 
#tr.en: and while the father is alive 
#tr.en: he has married a wife, 
#tr.en: after the father has died 
#tr.en: the heirs 
#tr.en: the house ... 
#tr.en: from the estate of the father 
#tr.en: the betrothal gift 
#tr.en: they(?) shall make, 
#tr.en: and the betrothal gift ... 
#tr.en: they shall ... 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: about a man’s daughter, 
#tr.en: who was unmarried, ‘You had sexual relations,’ 
#tr.en: another man has said, 
#tr.en: when that she had not had sexual relations 
#tr.en: she has proved, 
#tr.en: he shall pay 10 shekels of silver. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: rented an ox 
#tr.en: and cut the hoof tendon on it, 
#tr.en: 1/3 of its value he shall pay. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: rented an ox and damaged its eye, 
#tr.en: one-half its value he shall pay. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: rented an ox amd cut off its horn, 
#tr.en: 1/4 of its value he shall pay. 
#tr.en: If 
#tr.en: a man 
#tr.en: rented an ox 
#tr.en: and damaged its tail, 
#tr.en: 1/4 of its value he shall pay. 
#tr.en: he did ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... he shall pay. 
#tr.en: By the true command of Utu, 
#tr.en: Sumer and Akkad 
#tr.en: I made hold to fair judical procedures. 
#tr.en: By the utterance of Enlil 
#tr.en: I, Lipit-Ištar 
#tr.en: the son of Enlil, 
#tr.en: evil and violence 
#tr.en: I sent back to the source. 
#tr.en: Weeping, wailing, and making cries for justice 
#tr.en: I made taboo. 
#tr.en: Righteousness and truth I made appear resplendently. 
#tr.en: I made pleasant the substance of Sumer and Akkad. 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... and precious 
#tr.en: the [...] in their ..., the black-headed ones 
#tr.en: in their ... . 
#tr.en: When justice in Sumer and Akkad 
#tr.en: I established, 
#tr.en: this stela I planted out upon the ground. 
#tr.en: A man who a command of evildoing 
#tr.en: does not issue regarding this, 
#tr.en: and does not efface my creation, 
#tr.en: who does not erase my inscription 
#tr.en: and does not write his name upon it, 
#tr.en: may a life of long existence 
#tr.en: be granted (to him). 
#tr.en: May he lift his neck up high in the Ekur, 
#tr.en: and may the shining brow of Enlil 
#tr.en: turn down from heaven. 
#tr.en: But a person who issues an order of evil-doing, 
#tr.en: who effaces my creation, 
#tr.en: or who has it taken into a storehouse, 
#tr.en: or who changes its standing place, 
#tr.en: or who erases its inscription 
#tr.en: and writes his own name upon it, 
#tr.en: or because of the curse incites a stranger to do it, 
#tr.en: that man, be he a king, 
#tr.en: be he an en, or be he a governor, 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: the firstborn son of Enlil, 
#tr.en: shall not let(?) him come near with him, shall not let him ... seed. 
#tr.en: They the many(?) ..., the strong, progeny 
#tr.en: ... shall take from him by armed force. 
#tr.en: After he has been allowed to enter his house, 
#tr.en: may there be no heirs for him. 
#tr.en: The ... Ašnan and Šakkan, 
#tr.en: the lords of abundance, 
#tr.en: shall strip it away from him in sky and on earth. 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... of Enlil 
#tr.en: his allotments carried to the Ekur 
#tr.en: may he revoke. 
#tr.en: May Utu, the judge of heaven and earth, 
#tr.en: with exalted testimony 
#tr.en: make it be taken away from him. 
#tr.en: With his ..., 
#tr.en: his ... its base 
#tr.en: removed from(?) his ..., 
#tr.en: let him write(?) there. 
#tr.en: Its cities as ruined mounds 
#tr.en: may he reckon. 
#tr.en: The foundation of his land may he not keep secure. 
#tr.en: May there not be a king of it. 
#tr.en: May Ninurta, 
#tr.en: the mighty warrior 
#tr.en: of Enlil, 
#tr.en: be the unalterable bailiff of this, 
#tr.en: for time eternal.

#tr.en: Temple of ... 
#tr.en: O holy reed, 
#tr.en: O reed of the reed bed of the underground waters, 
#tr.en: O reed, (with) your branches 
#tr.en: growing luxuriantly, 
#tr.en: (with) your roots 
#tr.en: by Enki 
#tr.en: made to be in holes in the earth, 
#tr.en: your branches 
#tr.en: pray to the sun. 
#tr.en: Your beard 
#tr.en: is (of) lapis lazuli. 
#tr.en: Reed brought from the shining mountains, 
#tr.en: O reed, may the lords of the earth and the princes of the earth 
#tr.en: kneel (to you). 
#tr.en: When by Enki 
#tr.en: the decision 
#tr.en: has been made, 
#tr.en: onto the holy reed-posts of the corners, 
#tr.en: amidst praise, 
#tr.en: by Enki the hoops 
#tr.en: will thereupon be dropped. 
#tr.en: Ningirsu 
#tr.en: be praised! 
#tr.en: By Šul-MUŠxPA, 
#tr.en: the (personal) god of the king, 
#tr.en: the holy earth-carrying basket 
#tr.en: was carried.

#tr.en: king 
#tr.en: of Lagaš,

#tr.en: he committed against it, 
#tr.en: and into Lagaš, 
#tr.en: because of its own possessions, 
#tr.en: up to its frontier 
#tr.en: he again pressed. 
#tr.en: The ... Lion 
#tr.en: of the Heart of the Princely Way, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: in his (own) voice 
#tr.en: he made a claim(?) within the wind: 
#tr.en: Umma 
#tr.en: my hay, 
#tr.en: my own possessions, 
#tr.en: in the field

#tr.en: she extended to him.

#tr.en: with great joyfulness
