#tr.en: king of all the lands, 
#tr.en: father of all the gods, 
#tr.en: by his righteous command 
#tr.en: for Ningirsu 
#tr.en: and Šara, 
#tr.en: the (border) ground demarcated. 
#tr.en: Mesilim, 
#tr.en: king of Kiš, 
#tr.en: by the command of Ištaran, 
#tr.en: the measuring line upon it struck, 
#tr.en: and on that place a stele he erected. 
#tr.en: Uš, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Umma, 
#tr.en: something greatly beyond words (?) 
#tr.en: he did. 
#tr.en: That stele 
#tr.en: he tore out, 
#tr.en: and into the plain of Lagaš 
#tr.en: he entered. 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: the hero of Enlil, 
#tr.en: by his (Enlil’s) just command, 
#tr.en: with Umma 
#tr.en: battle 
#tr.en: did. 
#tr.en: By the word of Enlil 
#tr.en: (his) big battle-net upon it he cast, 
#tr.en: and its many tumuli 
#tr.en: in the plain he built up. 
#tr.en: Eanatum, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: uncle 
#tr.en: of Enmetena, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: with Enakale, 
#tr.en: the governor 
#tr.en: of Umma, 
#tr.en: the (border) ground demarcated, 
#tr.en: and its levee from Princely Canal 
#tr.en: to the Gu’edina 
#tr.en: he extended. 
#tr.en: Of Ningirsu’s field 
#tr.en: 215 rope-ninda 
#tr.en: under the control of Umma 
#tr.en: he left 
#tr.en: and into a field with no owner 
#tr.en: made it. 
#tr.en: On that levee steles 
#tr.en: he inscribed, 
#tr.en: and the stele 
#tr.en: of Mesilim 
#tr.en: he restored. 
#tr.en: Into the plain of Umma 
#tr.en: he did not pass. 
#tr.en: On the boundary mound 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: (named) Namnunda-kigara, 
#tr.en: a dais of Enlil, 
#tr.en: a dais of Ninḫursag, 
#tr.en: a dais of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: and a dais of Utu 
#tr.en: he constructed. 
#tr.en: Of the barley of Nanše 
#tr.en: and the barley of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: one grain-heap measure
#tr.en: the Man of Umma 
#tr.en: as an interest-bearing loan consumed. 
#tr.en: The ‛cut’ was imposed, 
#tr.en: and 144,000 (gur measured in) grain-heaps 
#tr.en: were to be brought in. 
#tr.en: Because that barley he was unable to repay, 
#tr.en: Urlumma, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Umma, 
#tr.en: the levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: and the levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Nanše 
#tr.en: with water removed. 
#tr.en: To its steles 
#tr.en: fire he set, 
#tr.en: and he tore them out. 
#tr.en: The set daises of the gods 
#tr.en: which on the Namnunda-kigara (mound) 
#tr.en: had been constructed, 
#tr.en: he demolished. 
#tr.en: Foreign countries he hired, 
#tr.en: and over the levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: he crossed. 
#tr.en: Enanatum, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: in the field Ugiga, 
#tr.en: the field of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: had (previously) fought with him, 
#tr.en: but Enmetena, 
#tr.en: the beloved son 
#tr.en: of Enanatum, 
#tr.en: defeated him. 
#tr.en: Urlumma 
#tr.en: fled 
#tr.en: into the middle of Umma 
#tr.en: and was killed. 
#tr.en: His donkeys, sixty teams, 
#tr.en: on the bank of the Lummagirnunta (canal) 
#tr.en: were left behind, 
#tr.en: and their personnel’s 
#tr.en: bones 
#tr.en: on the plain were all left out. 
#tr.en: Their tumuli 
#tr.en: in five places 
#tr.en: he heaped up. 
#tr.en: At that time, Il, 
#tr.en: who was the temple administrator of Zabala, 
#tr.en: from Girsu 
#tr.en: to Umma 
#tr.en: slithering 
#tr.en: went. 
#tr.en: Il 
#tr.en: the governorship 
#tr.en: of Umma 
#tr.en: seized. 
#tr.en: The levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: the levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Nanše, 
#tr.en: and the boundary mound 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: which on the of bank of the Tigris was located 
#tr.en: in the region of Girsu, 
#tr.en: the Namnunda-kigara of Enlil, Enki, 
#tr.en: and Ninḫursag, 
#tr.en: with water he removed. 
#tr.en: The barley of Lagaš, (with only) 3,600 (gur measured in a) grain-heap, 
#tr.en: he repaid. 
#tr.en: When Enmetena, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: because of those levees, 
#tr.en: to Il 
#tr.en: envoys had sent, 
#tr.en: Il, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Umma, 
#tr.en: field-thief, 
#tr.en: with hostility speaking, 
#tr.en: “The levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: and the levees of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Nanše 
#tr.en: are mine!” 
#tr.en: he declared. 
#tr.en: “From the Antasura (temple) 
#tr.en: to the temple of Dimgalabzu 
#tr.en: the earth I shall remove from them!” 
#tr.en: he declared. 
#tr.en: But Enlil 
#tr.en: and Ninḫursag 
#tr.en: did not give it to him. 
#tr.en: Enmetena, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: nominated 
#tr.en: by Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: by the just word of Enlil, 
#tr.en: the just word of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: and the just word of Nanše, 
#tr.en: that levee from the Tigris River 
#tr.en: to Princely Canal 
#tr.en: he constructed.

#tr.en: base in stone he built for him,

#tr.en: Nanše,

#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: scepter given 
#tr.en: by Enlil, 
#tr.en: wisdom given 
#tr.en: by Enki,

#tr.en: big-governor 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: the man who the words of the gods held (dear),

#tr.en: Šul-MUŠ×PA 
#tr.en: for the life 
#tr.en: of Enmetena 
#tr.en: unto distant days 
#tr.en: before Ningirsu 
#tr.en: and Nanše 
#tr.en: stand (interceding) for him! 
#tr.en: A Man of Umma 
#tr.en: who, over the levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: or over the levee of the boundary territory 
#tr.en: of Nanše 
#tr.en: in order by violence 
#tr.en: fields to carry off,
#tr.en: might (in the future) cross, 
#tr.en: a man of Umma be he, 
#tr.en: or a man of a foreign land be he, 
#tr.en: may Enlil 
#tr.en: annihilate him! 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: when his big battle-net 
#tr.en: has cast over him, 
#tr.en: his great hands and great feet 
#tr.en: from above may he bring down (upon him)! 
#tr.en: When the people in his city 
#tr.en: a hand against him have raised, 
#tr.en: in the middle of his city 
#tr.en: may they grind him up! 
#tr.en: For Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: the hero of Enlil, 
#tr.en: Enmetena, 
#tr.en: ruler 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: chosen by the heart 
#tr.en: of Nanše,

#tr.en: of Ningirsu,

#tr.en: he constructed.

#tr.en: for his master who loved him,

#tr.en: For Lugalemuš, 
#tr.en: Enmetena, 
#tr.en: ruler

#tr.en: he built 
#tr.en: and made fitting for him.

#tr.en: whose fearsomeness is of the heart of the mountains, 
#tr.en: he fashioned for him.

#tr.en: he built for him.

#tr.en: he built.

#tr.en: he built 
#tr.en: and made fitting for her. 
#tr.en: A remission of the obligations of Lagaš 
#tr.en: he instituted. 
#tr.en: He returned the mother to the child 
#tr.en: and returned the child to the mother, 
#tr.en: and a remission of interest-bearing barley loans 
#tr.en: he instituted. 
#tr.en: At that time, Enmetena 
#tr.en: for Lugal-emuš 
#tr.en: the Emuš of Pa-tibira, 
#tr.en: his beloved temple, 
#tr.en: he built 
#tr.en: and restored. 
#tr.en: The citizens of Uruk, 
#tr.en: the citizens of Larsa, 
#tr.en: and the citizens of Pa-tibira, 
#tr.en: a remission of their obligations 
#tr.en: he instituted. 
#tr.en: For Inanna, 
#tr.en: back to Uruk, 
#tr.en: to her control he returned them. 
#tr.en: For Utu,

#tr.en: For Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: the hero of Enlil, 
#tr.en: Enanatum, 
#tr.en: ruler 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: chosen by the heart 
#tr.en: of Nanše, 
#tr.en: chief ruler

#tr.en: ruler 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: for Ningirsu 
#tr.en: his brewery 
#tr.en: he restored. 
#tr.en: Enanatum, 
#tr.en: the man who the brewery 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: restored, 
#tr.en: his (personal) god 
#tr.en: is Šul-MUŠxPA. 
#tr.en: Geme-Baba, 
#tr.en: daughter of Enentarzi 
#tr.en: the temple administrator of Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: chosen by the heart 
#tr.en: of Nanše, 
#tr.en: given an exalted scepter 
#tr.en: by Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: son born 
#tr.en: by Baba, 
#tr.en: (ruler) of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: for his master who loved him, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: a stele 
#tr.en: he erected for him, 
#tr.en: and Ningirsu is the Lord Forever Exalted in Nippur 
#tr.en: he named it for him. 
#tr.en: a statue of himself 
#tr.en: he created, 
#tr.en: and Lugalanda-nuḫunga is Untiring Regarding the Princely Way 
#tr.en: he named it for him. 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: For Ningirsu,

#tr.en: king

#tr.en: he built,

#tr.en: he built.

#tr.en: he built for her,

#tr.en: he built for her.

#tr.en: her beloved canal, 
#tr.en: he dug, 
#tr.en: and its outlet 
#tr.en: into the center of the sea 
#tr.en: he extended. 
#tr.en: The wall of Girsu 
#tr.en: he built for him (Ningirsu). 
#tr.en: From distant times, 
#tr.en: from when the seed (of life first) came forth, 
#tr.en: in those days 
#tr.en: by the chief of the boatmen 
#tr.en: boats were seized, 
#tr.en: donkeys by the head herdsman 
#tr.en: were seized, 
#tr.en: sheep by the head herdsman 
#tr.en: were seized, 
#tr.en: fish stores 
#tr.en: by the fisheries inspector 
#tr.en: were seized, 
#tr.en: and by the lustration priests 
#tr.en: grain taxes 
#tr.en: in (the locality) Ambar 
#tr.en: were measured out. 
#tr.en: The shepherds of wool-bearing sheep 
#tr.en: instead of a pure(?) sheep 
#tr.en: put silver. 
#tr.en: The surveyor, 
#tr.en: the chief lamentation singer, 
#tr.en: the steward, 
#tr.en: the brewer, 
#tr.en: and all the foremen 
#tr.en: instead of a young lamb 
#tr.en: put silver. 
#tr.en: The oxen of the gods 
#tr.en: the garlic plots 
#tr.en: of the ruler 
#tr.en: did plow, 
#tr.en: and in the best fields 
#tr.en: of the gods 
#tr.en: were where the garlic plots 
#tr.en: and cucumber plots 
#tr.en: of the ruler 
#tr.en: were located. 
#tr.en: Team donkeys 
#tr.en: and unblemished oxen 
#tr.en: were the ones that for the temple administrators 
#tr.en: were harnessed, 
#tr.en: and the barley of the temple administrators 
#tr.en: to the teams of the ruler 
#tr.en: was distributed.

#tr.en: a ... garment,

#tr.en: (the preceding) by the temple administrators

#tr.en: The ... administrator 
#tr.en: in the orchard of the poor 
#tr.en: cut down trees, 
#tr.en: and with reed twine 
#tr.en: tied them (in bundles).

#tr.en: his beer was seven jugs,

#tr.en: a person was brought,

#tr.en: the bread for the Raised Hand (rituals) 
#tr.en: did get, 
#tr.en: and it was paired-workmen who 
#tr.en: the ferry toll for the main gate (of the netherworld) 
#tr.en: did get. 
#tr.en: The household of the ruler 
#tr.en: and the fields of the ruler, 
#tr.en: the household of the Woman’s House

#tr.en: and the household of the (royal) children 
#tr.en: and the fields of the children 
#tr.en: were all set side by side(?). 
#tr.en: From the border territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: to the waters of the sea 
#tr.en: ones who served as (court) officers 
#tr.en: were present (everywhere). 
#tr.en: When a royal subordinate 
#tr.en: on the narrow side of his field 
#tr.en: built his well, 
#tr.en: blind workers 
#tr.en: were appropriated for it, 
#tr.en: and for the irrigation channels(?) 
#tr.en: located within the field 
#tr.en: blind workers 
#tr.en: were (also) appropriated. 
#tr.en: As the customs were 
#tr.en: in former times 
#tr.en: it was. 
#tr.en: When Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: the hero of Enlil, 
#tr.en: to URU-KA-gina 
#tr.en: the kingship 
#tr.en: of Lagaš 
#tr.en: had given, 
#tr.en: and from the myriad people 
#tr.en: had grasped his hand, 
#tr.en: the fates 
#tr.en: of former times 
#tr.en: he restored, 
#tr.en: and the commands which his master 
#tr.en: Ningirsu 
#tr.en: had spoken to him 
#tr.en: he seized upon. 
#tr.en: From the boats 
#tr.en: the chief of the boatmen 
#tr.en: he removed,

#tr.en: and from the sheep

#tr.en: he removed,

#tr.en: he removed,

#tr.en: the granary supervisor 
#tr.en: he removed, 
#tr.en: for the instead of pure(?) sheep 
#tr.en: and instead of young lambs 
#tr.en: silver that had to be paid 
#tr.en: the officers (responsible) for it 
#tr.en: he removed, 
#tr.en: and as for the taxes which the temple administrators 
#tr.en: to the palace 
#tr.en: had delivered, 
#tr.en: the officers (responsible) for them 
#tr.en: he removed. 
#tr.en: Over the household of the ruler 
#tr.en: and the fields of the ruler 
#tr.en: Ningirsu 
#tr.en: as their master 
#tr.en: he assigned.

#tr.en: he assigned.

#tr.en: as their master 
#tr.en: he assigned. 
#tr.en: From the border territory 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: to the waters of the sea 
#tr.en: no persons shall serve as (court) officers. 
#tr.en: For a corpse being brought to the grave, 
#tr.en: his beer will be 3 jugs 
#tr.en: and his bread eighty loaves.

#tr.en: and one lead goat

#tr.en: shall take away. 
#tr.en: When to the reeds of Enki 
#tr.en: a person has been brought, 
#tr.en: his beer will be 4 jugs 
#tr.en: and his bread 240 loaves. 
#tr.en: One barig of barley 
#tr.en: the undertaker 
#tr.en: shall take away,

#tr.en: the person(s) of ... 
#tr.en: shall take away. 
#tr.en: One woman’s head band(?), 
#tr.en: and one sila3 of princely fragrance 
#tr.en: the ereš-dingir priestess 
#tr.en: shall take away. 
#tr.en: 420 loaves of bread that have sat 
#tr.en: are the bread duty, 
#tr.en: 40 loaves of hot bread 
#tr.en: are for eating, 
#tr.en: and 10 loaves of hot bread 
#tr.en: are the bread of the table.

#tr.en: are for the lamentation singers

#tr.en: The blind one 
#tr.en: who in ... 
#tr.en: stands, 
#tr.en: his bread for eating is one loaf, 
#tr.en: five loaves are his bread at midnight, 
#tr.en: one loaf is his bread at midday, 
#tr.en: and six loaves are his bread at evening. 
#tr.en: 60 loaves of bread, 
#tr.en: 1 mud vessel of beer, 
#tr.en: and three ban of barley 
#tr.en: are for the person who is to perform as the sagbur-priest. 
#tr.en: The ferry toll for the main gate 
#tr.en: of the paired-workmen 
#tr.en: he revoked. 
#tr.en: The craftsmen’s 
#tr.en: bread for the Raised Hand (ritual) 
#tr.en: he revoked. 
#tr.en: By the ...-administrator 
#tr.en: the orchard of the poor 
#tr.en: was not carried away. 
#tr.en: When to a royal subordinate 
#tr.en: a fine donkey 
#tr.en: has been born, 
#tr.en: and his foreman: I want to buy it! 
#tr.en: has said to him, 
#tr.en: whether he lets him buy it from him 
#tr.en: and: The silver that will satisfy me 
#tr.en: pay me! 
#tr.en: he has said to him, 
#tr.en: or whether he does not let him buy it from him, 
#tr.en: the foreman in anger 
#tr.en: must not strike him. 
#tr.en: When to the house of an aristocrat 
#tr.en: the house of a royal subordinate 
#tr.en: lies adjacent, 
#tr.en: and that aristocrat: 
#tr.en: I want to buy it from you! 
#tr.en: has said to him, 
#tr.en: whether 
#tr.en: he lets him buy it from him, 
#tr.en: and: The silver that will satisfy me 
#tr.en: pay me! 
#tr.en: My house is a cauldron, 
#tr.en: fill it up with barley for me! 
#tr.en: he has said to him, 
#tr.en: or whether he does not let him buy it from him, 
#tr.en: that aristocrat 
#tr.en: the royal subordinate 
#tr.en: in anger 
#tr.en: he must not strike. 
#tr.en: (All these things) he commanded. 
#tr.en: As for the citizens of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: the one living in debt, 
#tr.en: the one who had set up a (false) gur measure 
#tr.en: and had lowered (the amounts of) barley, 
#tr.en: the thief, 
#tr.en: and the one who had killed, 
#tr.en: their prison 
#tr.en: he cleared out, 
#tr.en: and their remission (of obligations) 
#tr.en: he established. 
#tr.en: That the orphan or widow 
#tr.en: to the powerful 
#tr.en: will not be subjugated, 
#tr.en: with Ningirsu 
#tr.en: URU-KA-gina 
#tr.en: made a binding agreement as to that command.

#tr.en: when the kingship

#tr.en: he received, 
#tr.en: their remission (of obligations) 
#tr.en: he established. 
#tr.en: When the (amount of) silver was imposed(?) 
#tr.en: and the sheep had been bought, 
#tr.en: the best sheep from among those sheep 
#tr.en: a person would take away.

#tr.en: measured the grain tax in Ambar, 
#tr.en: and those priests 
#tr.en: their grain-tax (storage) houses 
#tr.en: they would build in Ambar. 
#tr.en: When ..., 
#tr.en: stewards, 
#tr.en: foremen, 
#tr.en: lamentation singers, 
#tr.en: farmers, 
#tr.en: or brewers 
#tr.en: brought in a wool sheep, 
#tr.en: and it was plucked in the palace, 
#tr.en: whenever the sheep was pure(?) 
#tr.en: and its wool was taken away to the palace, 
#tr.en: five shekels of silver 
#tr.en: they would pay. 
#tr.en: The oxen of the gods 
#tr.en: the garlic plots 
#tr.en: of the ruler 
#tr.en: did plow, 
#tr.en: and the best fields 
#tr.en: When to the irrigation channels(?) 
#tr.en: that were located in the fields 
#tr.en: a blind worker 
#tr.en: was taken, 
#tr.en: the royal subordinate, 
#tr.en: (no matter) how much the work(?) being performed, 
#tr.en: drinking water 
#tr.en: he would not give him, 
#tr.en: and drinking water to the donkeys 
#tr.en: he would (also) not give. 
#tr.en: When a poor person 
#tr.en: a loan against his fish pond 
#tr.en: had made, 
#tr.en: a person would take away its fish, 
#tr.en: and that person could (only) say Oh Utu! (a cry for justice). 
#tr.en: When a man had divorced (his) wife, 
#tr.en: five shekels of silver 
#tr.en: the ruler 
#tr.en: took away, 
#tr.en: and one shekel of silver 
#tr.en: the chief minister 
#tr.en: took away. 
#tr.en: When a person put kohl on the head, 
#tr.en: five shekels of silver 
#tr.en: the ruler 
#tr.en: took away, 
#tr.en: one shekel of silver 
#tr.en: the chief minister 
#tr.en: took away, 
#tr.en: and one shekel of silver 
#tr.en: the sage 
#tr.en: took away. 
#tr.en: A person going along a path 
#tr.en: a garment(?) ... 
#tr.en: Silver ... 
#tr.en: the ruler, 
#tr.en: the minister, 
#tr.en: and the sage 
#tr.en: shall not take away. 
#tr.en: When a poor man 
#tr.en: an interest-bearing loan against his fish pond 
#tr.en: has made, 
#tr.en: no person shall take away its fish. 
#tr.en: For stolen property 
#tr.en: indemnification of it has been abandoned; 
#tr.en: lost property 
#tr.en: shall be hung at the main gate. 
#tr.en: If a woman to a male 
#tr.en: has spoken ... words(?) which exceeded (her rank?), 
#tr.en: onto the mouth (or teeth?) of that woman 
#tr.en: a baked brick shall be cast, 
#tr.en: and that brick 
#tr.en: will be hung at the main gate. 
#tr.en: As for women of former times, 
#tr.en: two of them a male 
#tr.en: could marry. 
#tr.en: But for women of today 
#tr.en: the indemnification of it has been abandoned. 
#tr.en: The dream interpreter, 
#tr.en: the seer, 
#tr.en: the caster of lots(?), 
#tr.en: the carpenter who plants pegs in the ground, 
#tr.en: of the words of the gods 
#tr.en: ... their copper arrow(s) 
#tr.en: Because of that barley, 
#tr.en: having sent envoys to him (Urlumma) 
#tr.en: and You must send here my barley! 
#tr.en: having said to him, 
#tr.en: Urlumma 
#tr.en: committed an agressive act(?) in response to it. 
#tr.en: The Antasura 
#tr.en: is mine! It is my border territory! 
#tr.en: he said. 
#tr.en: (The people of) Umma 
#tr.en: he levied, 
#tr.en: and he (also) chose (people from) foreign countries. 
#tr.en: In the Ugiga field, 
#tr.en: the field beloved 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu 
#tr.en: Umma’s 
#tr.en: levied (troops) 
#tr.en: he annihilated. 
#tr.en: Urlumma, 
#tr.en: the ruler 
#tr.en: of Umma, 
#tr.en: when he had been driven back, 
#tr.en: in the floor(?) of the Lummagirnunta canal 
#tr.en: he confronted him. 
#tr.en: His donkeys, sixty teams, 
#tr.en: were left behind, 
#tr.en: and their personnel’s 
#tr.en: bones 
#tr.en: were left out on the plain. 
#tr.en: he built for him. 
#tr.en: A wine brewery with many large sila vessels, 
#tr.en: fitting for its owner, 
#tr.en: he built for him.

#tr.en: and on the tenth day 
#tr.en: they were about to take pleasure at it, 
#tr.en: for my part, what did I have of it? 
#tr.en: I said said to him:

#tr.en: Should a foreign man 
#tr.en: destroy its place, 
#tr.en: or take it away 
#tr.en: and abscond (with it) from there, 
#tr.en: in his city, 
#tr.en: like a place ruined by snakes, 
#tr.en: may he not have a head raised in pride!

#tr.en: onto that ruler

#tr.en: be fastened!

#tr.en: at the bank of the Tigris river

#tr.en: and Zakur-elum,

#tr.en: the barley they shall measure out; 
#tr.en: month: “Silver hill,” 14th day, 
#tr.en: year: “By the order of Sin, Enlil, and Enki, a canal towards the Euphrates, the silvery cup of Nanna, Rim-Sin, the good shepherd, dug.” 
#tr.en: Immer-ilī, 
#tr.en: son of Ḫariya, 
#tr.en: servant of An-Martu. 
#tr.en: Zakur-elum, 
#tr.en: son of Iakunum, 
#tr.en: servant of An-Martu. 
#tr.en: [n minas] of silver, interest for 1 mina: [n gur] of barley each, 
#tr.en: from Gunaya, 
#tr.en: did Yadiḫi-ilī 
#tr.en: receive; 
#tr.en: before: Pazaya, 
#tr.en: before: Menḫidum, 
#tr.en: before: Arkadanum; 
#tr.en: month: “zazagar,” 
#tr.en: year “Itur-Šamaš died.” 
#tr.en: Yadiḫi-ilī 
#tr.en: son of Zankana-x.
#tr.en: It was time to decide destinies in heaven and on earth, 
#tr.en: Lagash had raised the head towards heaven in large ‘me’, 
#tr.en: Enlil looked righteously upon Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: Did the ‘nig2-ul’ not emerge in our city? 
#tr.en: The ‘heart’, did it not return to its banks? 
#tr.en: The ‘heart’ of Enlil, did it not return to its banks? 
#tr.en: The ‘heart’, did it not return to its banks? 
#tr.en: The flood, did it not twinkle? Frightening (all). 
#tr.en: The ‘heart’ of Enlil, it is the river Tigris, did it not bring sweet water? 
#tr.en: To the house its king spoke: 
#tr.en: “I will make the ‘me’ of Eninnu emerge in heaven and on earth. 
#tr.en: The governor is wise, he shall pay attention. 
#tr.en: He shall place his hand on big things. 
#tr.en: He shall straighten the horns of perfect oxen, perfect goats.” 
#tr.en: The brick of deciding destinies lifted the head towards him, 
#tr.en: to build the shiny house it raised its neck towards him. 
#tr.en: It was then, in a ‘dark goat’, that towards his king, 
#tr.en: on the lord Ningirsu, Gudea looked. 
#tr.en: “Build his house!,” he ordered him. 
#tr.en: On Eninnu, whose ‘me’ is very large, 
#tr.en: he (Ningirsu) directed his (Gudea’s) eye there. 
#tr.en: Gudea, his ‘heart’ is distant, 
#tr.en: counseled about the message: 
#tr.en: “Let me, let me tell it to her, let me, let me tell it to her, 
#tr.en: may she stand by me in this case. 
#tr.en: I am the shepherd, princeliness was given to me. 
#tr.en: Of what my ‘dark goat’ has revealed to me, 
#tr.en: its ‘heart’ I did not know. 
#tr.en: Let me bring my dream to her, to my mother. 
#tr.en: My dream-interpreter, knowing ‘ku3’ on her own, 
#tr.en: Nanše, my divine sister from Siraran, 
#tr.en: may she make its meaning visible for me.” 
#tr.en: Did he not set foot on his barge? 
#tr.en: Towards Nina, on Ininadua, he directed the barge, 
#tr.en: he is breaking the waves of Ideḫula. 
#tr.en: After reaching Bagara—house hanging over the river, 
#tr.en: he sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water, 
#tr.en: he went to the king of Bagara, and prayed to him: 
#tr.en: “Hero, charging lion, having no rival, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, boisterous in the Apsû, 
#tr.en: being noble in Nippur. 
#tr.en: Hero, you spoke to me, let me do it right for you, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, let me build your house for you, 
#tr.en: let me make the ‘me’ perfect for you. 
#tr.en: Your sister, child born to Eridu, 
#tr.en: hero in her own right, lady-dream-interpreter of the gods, 
#tr.en: Nanše, my divine sister from Siraran, 
#tr.en: may she make the path right for me.” 
#tr.en: His (Gudea’s) prayer was being heard. 
#tr.en: From Gudea, his offering and his prayer, his king, 
#tr.en: the lord Ningirsu, received from him. 
#tr.en: In the House of Bagara he celebrated the week-festival. 
#tr.en: The governor set up his bed in the house of Gatumdu. 
#tr.en: He sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water. 
#tr.en: He went to Shiny-Gatumdu, 
#tr.en: (and then) he is saying an offering(!) to her: 
#tr.en: “My lady, child born by shiny An, 
#tr.en: princely in her own right, god with the raised head, 
#tr.en: living in the land, 
#tr.en: knowing ‘nig2-du7’ in her city. 
#tr.en: You are the lady, the mother, founder of Lagash. 
#tr.en: (With) your looking at the people: it is a bountiful wind. 
#tr.en: (With) your looking at the righteous hero, the man: for him life is prolonged. 
#tr.en: I am a no-mother-haver, you are my mother. 
#tr.en: I am a no-father-haver, you are my father. 
#tr.en: You have placed my semen in the inside: you bore me in the cella. 
#tr.en: Gatumdu, your shiny name is sweet. 
#tr.en: I will lay me down here this night, 
#tr.en: you are my big dagger, following my side. 
#tr.en: You are a reed, planted in the big water, 
#tr.en: you have placed life in me. 
#tr.en: You are a broad parasol, under your shade 
#tr.en: let me cool myself there. 
#tr.en: With the index finger? of your right hand, 
#tr.en: ‘stroke’ me with it my lady Gatumdu. 
#tr.en: I will go to the city, may my sign be good. 
#tr.en: To Nina, mountain raising out of the sea, 
#tr.en: may your good Utukku go in front of me, 
#tr.en: may your good Lamma follow in my path. 
#tr.en: Let me, let me tell it to her. 
#tr.en: Let me, let me tell it to her. 
#tr.en: May she stand by me in this case. 
#tr.en: Let me bring my dream to my mother, 
#tr.en: my dream-interpreter knowing ‘ku3’ by herself, 
#tr.en: Nanše, my divine lady from Siraran, 
#tr.en: may she make its meaning visible for me.” 
#tr.en: His cry was heard. 
#tr.en: His lady, the offering and the prayer, 
#tr.en: Shiny-Gatumdu received from Gudea. 
#tr.en: Did he not place the foot on the barge? 
#tr.en: To her city, Nina, he moored at the port of Nina. 
#tr.en: In the courtyard of the deity of Siraran the governor raised the head to heaven, 
#tr.en: he sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water. 
#tr.en: He went to Nanše, he prayed to her: 
#tr.en: “Nanše, large lady, lady of precious, precious, ‘me’. 
#tr.en: Lady, like Enlil deciding destinies. 
#tr.en: My Nanše, your word is righteous, 
#tr.en: it goes to the top. 
#tr.en: You are the dream interpreter of the gods. 
#tr.en: You are the lady of all the lands. Mother, my words, in the day, in the dream. 
#tr.en: Inside the dream there was one man, his greatness was like heaven, 
#tr.en: his greatness was like the earth. 
#tr.en: He, according to his head he was a god, 
#tr.en: according to his arm he was the Anzu, 
#tr.en: according to his lower body he was the flood. 
#tr.en: Lions lay by his right and left. 
#tr.en: He spoke to me about the building of his house. 
#tr.en: His ‘heart’ I did not understand. 
#tr.en: A light went up on the horizon for me. 
#tr.en: There was one woman. Who was it, who was it not? 
#tr.en: going up to the top she made a haystack on the earth. 
#tr.en: She held a stylus of purified silver in the hand. 
#tr.en: She had the tablet of the stars on her lap. 
#tr.en: She counseled it. 
#tr.en: Secondly, it was a hero, 
#tr.en: he bent the arm, he held a lapis writing board in the hand, 
#tr.en: he drew the plan of the house. 
#tr.en: In front of me stood a shiny basket, 
#tr.en: a shiny mold was made ready, 
#tr.en: the brick of deciding destinies was placed in the mold for me. 
#tr.en: In a just poplar standing in front of me, 
#tr.en: a ‘tibu’-bird passed the time tweeting. 
#tr.en: A donkey stallion, on the right side of my king, scratched the earth for me.” 
#tr.en: His mother, Nanše, answered the governor: 
#tr.en: “My shepherd, let me, me interpret your dream for you. 
#tr.en: The man (who was) great like the heaven, (who was) great like the earth, 
#tr.en: (who) according to his head (he was a) god, according to his arm 
#tr.en: (he was) the Anzu, according to his lower body the flood, 
#tr.en: at (whose) right and left lions were lying, 
#tr.en: it is surely my brother Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: ‘Build his shrine, the Eninnu!’ He ordered you. 
#tr.en: The light that went up for you on the horizon, 
#tr.en: it is your god Ningešzida, who like the light went up for you on the horizon. 
#tr.en: The virgin, going up to the top, making a haystack on the earth, 
#tr.en: holding a stylus of purified silver in her hand, 
#tr.en: placing the tablet of the stars on the lap, 
#tr.en: counseled it. 
#tr.en: That is surely Nisaba, my sister. 
#tr.en: (About) the shiny star of the building of the house, 
#tr.en: she poured out her voice for you. 
#tr.en: The second (one), it was a hero, with bent arm, 
#tr.en: holding in the hand a lapis drawing board, 
#tr.en: it is Nindubba, placing the house on the plan of the house. 
#tr.en: The shiny basket standing in front of you, the prepared shiny mold, 
#tr.en: the brick of deciding destinies, placed in the mold, 
#tr.en: that is surely the righteous brick of Eninnu. 
#tr.en: In the righteous poplar standing in front of you, 
#tr.en: a ‘tibu’-bird passed time tweeting, 
#tr.en: in order not to let sweet sleep come to your eyes, (so) that the house is build. 
#tr.en: A donkey stallion scratching the ground on your kings right side, 
#tr.en: that is you, scratching the ground for Eninnu like a ‘choice’ (?) (donkey-)span (?). 
#tr.en: Let me give give you instructions, let my instructions be heeded. 
#tr.en: (When) you have reached Girsu, the chief house of Lagash: 
#tr.en: after you broke the seal of your treasure house, after your brought out wood, 
#tr.en: after your have prepared a chariot for your king, 
#tr.en: after you harnessed the donkey stallion, 
#tr.en: after you decorated this chariot with purified silver and lapis, 
#tr.en: (called) ‘quick as light the arrow go out from the quiver’, 
#tr.en: after you have cared for ‘Ankara’, the ‘arm of heroism’, 
#tr.en: after you have fashioned his beloved emblem, 
#tr.en: after you wrote your name on it, 
#tr.en: his beloved harp, ‘dragon of the land’, 
#tr.en: the famous roaring wood, with which he counsels, 
#tr.en: to the hero who loves gifts, 
#tr.en: to your king, lord Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: after you entered for him into Eninnu, ‘the white Anzu bird’, with it, 
#tr.en: he will receive your small word, as if it was a mighty word. 
#tr.en: The ‘heart’ of the lord, distant like the heavens, 
#tr.en: of Ningirsu, son of Enlil, he will calm for you.

#tr.en: The hero, his ‘me’ are the greatest, 
#tr.en: he shall let it grow for you.” 
#tr.en: The righteous shepherd Gudea 
#tr.en: learnt big, and now he will perform big. 
#tr.en: To the word Nanše spoke to him, 
#tr.en: he bowed his head. 
#tr.en: He broke the seal of his treasure house, 
#tr.en: he brought out wood. 
#tr.en: Gudea stood by the wood, 
#tr.en: he is caring for the wood. 
#tr.en: He made the top of the ‘mes’ wood good. 
#tr.en: He put the oak wood to the axe. 
#tr.en: He made it straight for him, for the lapis chariot. 
#tr.en: The donkey stallion, ‘lion called for running’, 
#tr.en: he harnesses for it. 
#tr.en: He fashioned his beloved emblem for him, 
#tr.en: he wrote his name on it.

#tr.en: the famous roaring wood, with which he councels, 
#tr.en: to the hero loving gifts, 
#tr.en: to his king, lord Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: in Eninnu, the white Anzu, 
#tr.en: he enters. 
#tr.en: Joyfully he entered to him in the house. 
#tr.en: Didn’t Gudea go out, brilliantly, from the shrine Eninnu? 
#tr.en: For the second (time), in(?) the house he passed the days, 
#tr.en: he passed the nights. 
#tr.en: He flattened the hills, he returned accusations. 
#tr.en: He removed the spittle from the dagger.

#tr.en: he went to him in ‘ubšu-ukkina’, he greeted him:

#tr.en: its ‘me’ is bigger than all the other enormous ‘me’

#tr.en: ‘the king, flood of Enlil, 
#tr.en: no-haver of opponent, 
#tr.en: Lord Ningirsu, on Gudea 
#tr.en: looked righteously,’ 
#tr.en: as name of that stone he named. 
#tr.en: His stone erected in front of the rising sun, 
#tr.en: ‘the King, roaring storm of Enlil, 
#tr.en: lord no-haver of rival, 
#tr.en: Lord Ningirsu, Gudea, 
#tr.en: in his shiny ‘heart’ called him,’ 
#tr.en: as name of that stone he named. 
#tr.en: His stone erected in front of Šugalam, 
#tr.en: ‘by the name of his king the mountains tremble, 
#tr.en: Lord Ningirsu, Gudea, 
#tr.en: his throne he made firm,’ 
#tr.en: as name of that stone he named. 
#tr.en: His stone erected in front of E'uruagaka: 
#tr.en: ‘lord Ningirsu, for Gudea, 
#tr.en: decided a sweet destiny,’ 
#tr.en: as name of that stone he named. 
#tr.en: His stone erected in Baba’s back-room, 
#tr.en: ‘Eninnu, knowing the face of An, 
#tr.en: Baba, life of Gudea,’ 
#tr.en: as name of that stone he named. 
#tr.en: He build the house of his king with righteousness. 
#tr.en: The righteous shepherd Gudea made it grow together with heaven and earth. 
#tr.en: Raising the crown like the new moon, 
#tr.en: its name until the middle of the mountain 
#tr.en: he made emerge. 
#tr.en: Gudea made Ningirsu’s house 
#tr.en: go out from the cloud like Utu, 
#tr.en: made it grow like a mountain of Lapis, 
#tr.en: like a white alabaster mountain, 
#tr.en: made it stand to be admired. 
#tr.en: Its ‘dubla’ stood (there) like an aurochs, 
#tr.en: its dragons lay (there) like lions on their paws. 
#tr.en: Its Gigun grows in a pure place like the Abzu, 
#tr.en: Its sign like the shiny ibex of Abzu, 
#tr.en: he made shine the horns, 
#tr.en: like the new moon standing in heaven, 
#tr.en: Gudea made the house of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: stand to be admired. 
#tr.en: The ‘dubla’ that stand in the house, 
#tr.en: that stand with Abzu Lahama, 
#tr.en: The house of standing wood is a wave (in) the mighty marsh into which snakes have dived. 
#tr.en: Its stretched out mouth, 
#tr.en: it is the terror of the x-heaven. 
#tr.en: The ‘covered house’ of the house is a light floating in the middle of the heavens. 
#tr.en: (Going out) from the gate, ‘entrance of the king’, 
#tr.en: it is an eagle gazing at an aurochs. 
#tr.en: The arrow leaning against the gate, 
#tr.en: it is the rainbow leaning against heaven. 
#tr.en: Its upper lintel, it is Eninnu coiled up, the roaring storm. 
#tr.en: Its frightening eyebrows, 
#tr.en: it is the admiring face of the gods. 
#tr.en: The house, his white flood returning, 
#tr.en: it is a lapis mountain firmly moored in heaven and earth. 
#tr.en: They prepare the meal in the great sanctuary, 
#tr.en: it is gold bowls filled with honney and wine, 
#tr.en: standing under the heaven. 
#tr.en: The built the bed-room, 
#tr.en: it is the shiny ‘mes’ tree of Abzu (competing) with innumerable mountains, 
#tr.en: carrying fruit. 
#tr.en: He built, and after he had finished it, 
#tr.en: it is the ‘heart’ of the gods, returned to its banks. 
#tr.en: The righteous shepherd Gudea has learned big (things), 
#tr.en: and he will perform big (things). 
#tr.en: At the war-door of the inner room, where the weapon hang, 
#tr.en: Sagar, the hero, the six headed ram, 
#tr.en: he seizes there. 
#tr.en: At the frightening place facing the city, 
#tr.en: the seven heroes he seizes there. 
#tr.en: At Šugalam, the gate of radiance, 
#tr.en: the dragon and the date palm he seizes there. 
#tr.en: At Igi'u'e, the place of deciding destinies, 
#tr.en: the emblem of Utu, the head of a bison, 
#tr.en: he places there. 
#tr.en: At Kasur, the cherished, 
#tr.en: a lion, the fear of the gods, 
#tr.en: he seizes there. 
#tr.en: At Tarsirsir, the place of instructions, 
#tr.en: (the metal) ‘friend of heaven’ and copper, 
#tr.en: he seizes there. 
#tr.en: At the inner room of Baba, place of council, 
#tr.en: Magilum and Gualim (bison) 
#tr.en: he seizes there. 
#tr.en: Because they are dead warriors, 
#tr.en: he placed their mouths at the libation place, 
#tr.en: (and) their names, in the midst of the gods, 
#tr.en: Gudea, governor of Lagash, 
#tr.en: made them emerge. 
#tr.en: The cedar doors standing in the house, 
#tr.en: it is Iškur roaring from heaven. 
#tr.en: Eninnu, its lock, a bison(?), 
#tr.en: its pivots, a lion; 
#tr.en: from its bolt, Muššatur (and) Mušhuš 
#tr.en: stretch out the tongue against an aurochs. 
#tr.en: The lintels leaning on the door, 
#tr.en: it is a young lioness, whose young ones rest on its paws. 
#tr.en: They fastened the shiny roof nail in the house, 
#tr.en: it is a dragon laying hand on a man. 
#tr.en: They stretched out the shiny (measuring) rope in the door, 
#tr.en: it is the shiny water snake of Abzu, dividing (things). 
#tr.en: Keš and Aratta give instructions at the tying (together) of the house: 
#tr.en: the tying together, it is a terrible lion, 
#tr.en: gazing at the land, 
#tr.en: the lonely wanderer cannot pass. 
#tr.en: The fear of Eninnu, on all the lands, 
#tr.en: like a garment, it covered. 
#tr.en: The house, founded by Anu with purified silver, 
#tr.en: decorated with good perfume, 
#tr.en: rising in heavenly brilliance, like the moon. 
#tr.en: The face of the house is a large mountain leaning on earth, 
#tr.en: its inside is a polyphonic song, 
#tr.en: its outside is a mighty house of abundance rising in heaven. 
#tr.en: Its outer throne room, 
#tr.en: the place of rendering the justice of Anunna, 
#tr.en: from its water throughs are words of prayer, 
#tr.en: with its food rations are the abundance of the gods. 
#tr.en: The signs placed with the house, 
#tr.en: it is Anzu spreading his wings in Kurmuš. 
#tr.en: The clay of Eninnu, mixed clay, 
#tr.en: is a flood draining(?) from the plain. 
#tr.en: Its king, Lord Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: chose it in his shiny ‘heart’, 
#tr.en: he poured it on top like good incense. 
#tr.en: Gudea, in the brilliance of heaven, 
#tr.en: decorated it. 
#tr.en: From the cow pen, 
#tr.en: oil deliveries, milk deliveries, 
#tr.en: From the mighty oven, 
#tr.en: large cakes, large croissants(!?). 
#tr.en: The Girpana, 
#tr.en: feeding oxen, feeding sheep. 
#tr.en: The provisions place, sustaining the uzga. 
#tr.en: The wine-cellar(?) 
#tr.en: (called) ‘mountain dripping with wine’. 
#tr.en: From the brewery, 
#tr.en: (called) ‘Tigris is being water in its might’. 
#tr.en: In the treasury, precious stones, silver, tin. 
#tr.en: The coach house, 
#tr.en: (called) ‘mountain standing on the ground’. 
#tr.en: The inner room of haprs, (called) ‘ox roaring princely’. 
#tr.en: The courtyard, shiny prayers, ‘sim’ and ‘ala’ (sounds). 
#tr.en: The stone basin sleeping in the house, 
#tr.en: it is a mountain sleeping in full flowering. 
#tr.en: The tin basin, siding with the storeroom, 
#tr.en: it is the light lifting the distant gaze to the mountain. 
#tr.en: The garden of the black plain placed with the house, 
#tr.en: it is the frightening place grown together with ‘mountain driping with wine’. 
#tr.en: The seven stones seized by the house, 
#tr.en: are things counselling with its king. 
#tr.en: The house of funerary offerings, 
#tr.en: is a pure thing, instructed by Abzu. 
#tr.en: The fragrant stones standing in the house, 
#tr.en: it is the house of the purification priests never lacking water. 
#tr.en: The high battlements 
#tr.en: where pigeons dwell, 
#tr.en: it is Eridu, built in abundance(?). 
#tr.en: Eninnu [...] the doves, 
#tr.en: it is a shade of large leaves, a sweet shadow. 
#tr.en: Buru-birds shrieking, 
#tr.en: it is the Ekur of Enlil in a festival. 
#tr.en: The big fear of the house 
#tr.en: rests on the land. 
#tr.en: Its praise 
#tr.en: reaches the mountains. 
#tr.en: The fear of Eninnu covers all the lands like a garment. 
#tr.en: The house (was) built in joy by its king. 
#tr.en: Ningešzida 
#tr.en: built it on a big place. 
#tr.en: Gudea, governor of Lagash, 
#tr.en: placed its foundation. 
#tr.en: Temple--going out in the land, 
#tr.en: standing outside in the dust like a big ox, 
#tr.en: like the moon pleasurably 
#tr.en: filling the assembly, 
#tr.en: like a green mountain 
#tr.en: clad in joy, 
#tr.en:--standing to be admired. 
#tr.en: For the restoration of Eninnu 
#tr.en: Ningirsu be praised! 
#tr.en: The building of the house of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: this is the middle of the praise. 
#tr.en: House, mooring post of the Land, 
#tr.en: grown up from earth to heaven, 
#tr.en: Eninnu, the good Brick for which Enlil has made a favorable firm promise, 
#tr.en: green mountain range, standing to be admired,  
#tr.en: standing out above all the lands. 
#tr.en: The House, being a great mountain, bordered on heaven, 
#tr.en: being the sun, it filled mid-heaven with light, 
#tr.en: being Eninnu, the White Thunderbird, 
#tr.en: it (attacked) the mountain with spread wings. 
#tr.en: The people have all been settled (again), and the Land has gone home, 
#tr.en: (but) the Anunna gods are all standing in admiration. 
#tr.en: The ruler, who is wise, is knowledgeable, 
#tr.en: kisses the ground over and over before the divinities; 
#tr.en: with rites and prayer, in submission, he touches the ground; 
#tr.en: the ruler, the (personal) god of his city, says a prayer. 
#tr.en: For the bread-consuming House he added more bread, 
#tr.en: for the supper in need of mutton he added more sheep. 
#tr.en: As if it were for the abundance of vast midheaven, 
#tr.en: in front (of the House) he set up jars in a row. 
#tr.en: He went to the Anunna gods, 
#tr.en: prayed to them: “O all you Anunna gods who are admiring (what) the Land of Lagaš (achieved), 
#tr.en: protectors of all the countries, whose command, a torrent of water, 
#tr.en: will make the one who (would try to) stem it founder,  
#tr.en: (but) who to the worthy man upon whom they looked 
#tr.en: have given a long life, 
#tr.en: I, the shepherd, built the House, and my master will enter his House— 
#tr.en: would you, O Anunna gods, say a blessing on my behalf?” 
#tr.en: The true shepherd Gudea 
#tr.en: is wise and able, too, to realize things. 
#tr.en: His friendly guardian walks in front of him, 
#tr.en: and his friendly protecting genius is following him, 
#tr.en: (and so) to his master for the House of yore, the old House, his (former) abode, 
#tr.en: to the lord Ningirsu Gudea 
#tr.en: made great gifts. 
#tr.en: He went into Eninnu, to the lord, 
#tr.en: prayed to him: 
#tr.en: “My master Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: lord who has turned back the fierce waters, 
#tr.en: lord whose command takes precedence, 
#tr.en: Enlil’s male child, warrior, you spoke to me,  
#tr.en: and I did faithfully obey you. 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, I built you your House, 
#tr.en: may you enter it in joy.” 
#tr.en: (And he added) “My Baba, I erected your women’s quarters for you, 
#tr.en: move in in comfort.” 
#tr.en: His call was heard,  
#tr.en: the warrior accepted from Gudea, the lord Ningirsu 
#tr.en: accepted from him, prayer and rite. 
#tr.en: (Meanwhile) the year had ended, the month had been completed, 
#tr.en: the new year had appeared in the sky, 
#tr.en: the month “had entered its house,” 
#tr.en: and of that month the third day had passed: 
#tr.en: (Then) Ningirsu had arrived from Eridu, 
#tr.en: (and) the most beautiful moonlight shone 
#tr.en: illuminating the Land; Eninnu with the (new-)born moon (god) 
#tr.en: vied.
#tr.en: Gudea made a paste with carnelian and lapis lazuli, 
#tr.en: he put it in the corners 
#tr.en: and sprinkled abundant oil on the floor. 
#tr.en: He bade the builders, the workmen, 
#tr.en: leave the House. 
#tr.en: Syrup, butter oil, wine, sour milk, 
#tr.en: gipar-fruit, fig-cakes 
#tr.en: topped with cheese, 
#tr.en: dates in clusters(?), small grapes, 
#tr.en: (all) things untouched by fire, 
#tr.en: (to prepare) food for the gods, 
#tr.en: he used syrup and butter. 
#tr.en: From the moment when the sun rose in the good sky, 
#tr.en: Gudea, from early morning 
#tr.en: till supper (time) passed to and fro. 
#tr.en: Asari saw to it that the House was all right, 
#tr.en: Nin-mada gave advice, 
#tr.en: king Enki provided oracular messages. 
#tr.en: Nin-duba, foremost lustration priest of Eridu, 
#tr.en: filled (the House) with incense, 
#tr.en: the lady of precious rites, Nanše, who knows the words of sacred songs, put them to music for the House. 
#tr.en: She “sheared” the black ewes (of the sky), 
#tr.en: and of the cow-of-heaven  
#tr.en: she milked the udder, 
#tr.en: while with (brooms of) tamarisk and ...,
#tr.en: they were cleaning Eninnu 
#tr.en: until they had polished it to perfection. 
#tr.en: The ruler made the (whole) city kneel down, 
#tr.en: he made the Land prostrate itself. 
#tr.en: He leveled what was high, refused (to listen to) chance utterances,  
#tr.en: “spittle” (of sorcery) had been removed from the roads.  
#tr.en: In the city (only) the mother of a sick person 
#tr.en: administered a potion— the wild animals, creatures of the steppe, 
#tr.en: all had crouched together.  
#tr.en: Lion, lioness(?) and the “dragon of the steppe” 
#tr.en: enjoyed sweet sleep. 
#tr.en: Rites (had made) the day (go by), prayers the night, 
#tr.en: the early morning (had) the moonlight (caused to fade)—
#tr.en: was the master (of the House) on his way? 
#tr.en: (Yea,) the warrior Ningirsu was entering (his) House. 
#tr.en: The master of the House had come to it 
#tr.en: like an eagle catching sight of an aurochs. 
#tr.en: When the warrior was entering his House, 
#tr.en: he was a storm roaring towards battle, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu went about his House, 
#tr.en: and it was (just as) in the Abzu sanctuary when a festival is going on. 
#tr.en: The owner indeed came out of his House (again), 
#tr.en: and he was (like) the sun god rising above the land of Lagaš. 
#tr.en: When Baba went to her women’s quarters 
#tr.en: she was (like) a respectful woman caring for her house; 
#tr.en: when she entered her bedroom 
#tr.en: she was (like) the Tigris at high waters, 
#tr.en: when she sat down in ... 
#tr.en: she was the lady, daughter of bright An, a green garden bearing fruit. 
#tr.en: The day was about to rise, firm promise had been fulfilled, 
#tr.en: Baba had entered her women’s quarters— 
#tr.en: that meant) abundance for the land of Lagaš. 
#tr.en: The day dawned, the sungod of Lagaš lifted his head over the Land. 
#tr.en: Fattened oxen and sheep were taken to the House, 
#tr.en: (Gudea) set up a jar in the open air, poured much wine into it. 
#tr.en: The Anunna gods of the land of Lagaš were installed around the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: (Gudea) performed the purification of the House in the most attentive way, 
#tr.en: and he took care of portents. 
#tr.en: Wine was poured from the big jar 
#tr.en: while Eninnu amassed ... 
#tr.en: Nin-duba caused the sanctuary to be full of clatter and noise, 
#tr.en: and with fresh bread, milk of hinds 
#tr.en: available day and night,  
#tr.en: the noble one, the beloved child of Enlil, the warrior Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: he rouses from sleep. 
#tr.en: He (Ningirsu) proudly looks around, very sure of himself, 
#tr.en: (and) his ..., functionaries, (and) ...
#tr.en: he lines up (to be assigned functions) for the sanctuary Eninnu. 
#tr.en: That he (Ig-alim) might guide the hand of the righteous one 
#tr.en: and force the evil-doer’s neck into a neck stock, 
#tr.en: that he might keep the House safe, keep it in harmony,  
#tr.en: that he might give instructions to his city (and) the sanctuaries of Girsu, 
#tr.en: that he might establish a throne of firm promise, 
#tr.en: hand over a sceptre for long days, 
#tr.en: that he might make the shepherd called by Ningirsu 
#tr.en: lift high the head as if it wore a blue crown,  
#tr.en: that the “skin-clad,” the “linen-clad,” and the “covered head”   
#tr.en: he might appoint to (their) offices in the courtyard of Eninnu—  
#tr.en: the Great Door, the Pole of Girnun, the chief bailiff of Girsu, 
#tr.en: his beloved son Ig-alim,  
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningusu. 
#tr.en: That he (Šul-šaga) might keep the House clean, let hands always be washed, 
#tr.en: have clean hands serve water to the lord,  
#tr.en: that he might pour beer into bowls, wine into jars, 
#tr.en: that in (Eninnu’s) brewery, the “house (with) the clean arms,” 
#tr.en: emmer beer like the waters (of) Papsir
#tr.en: might bubble,
#tr.en: that unblemished oxen and goats and grain-fed sheep, 
#tr.en: fresh bread, and milk of hinds 
#tr.en: be available day and night, that the noble one, 
#tr.en: Enlil’s beloved son, the warrior Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: might rise from sleep ... — 
#tr.en: the lord of the most careful hand-washing, the first-bom son of Eninnu, 
#tr.en: Šul-šaga, to Ningirsu 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces). 
#tr.en: That the seven-headed club might be held (firmly) in hand, 
#tr.en: that the (“King who makes the mountain tremble") might keep open the door-wings of the Ankar house, the Battle gate, 
#tr.en: that he might cause the dagger blades, the mace “dead man,” the “floodstorm weapon,” 
#tr.en: the “Bitter one,” (all of them) battle tools,  
#tr.en: exactly to hit their targets, 
#tr.en: all of Enlil’s enemies’ lands 
#tr.en: that he might inundate— 
#tr.en: the warrior “Mow-down-a-myriad” who in battle subdues all the lands, 
#tr.en: the mighty general of Eninnu,  
#tr.en: the falcon for the rebel land, 
#tr.en: “King who makes the mountain tremble,” his general, 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: After the heavenly mace “dead man” like a fierce storm 
#tr.en: has roared against the mountain, 
#tr.en: (being) the “Mow-down-a-myriad,” the floodstorm of battle, 
#tr.en: the cudgel of the rebel land, 
#tr.en: after the lord has frowned at the rebels, the mountain, 
#tr.en: and hurled at it his furious words, 
#tr.en: having carried away its wits, that he ...— 
#tr.en: the lord’s second general who is (called) 
#tr.en: “The-land-is-but-a-swallow-in-his-hand.” 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to Enlil’s son. 
#tr.en: That supplications of the land Lagaš 
#tr.en: might be released, 
#tr.en: that he (Lugal-sisa) might perform rites and prayers for it, propitious ones, 
#tr.en: that when the warrior is going to Eridu 
#tr.en: he might bid farewell,  
#tr.en: and that, (as a result) when he is returning from Eridu, 
#tr.en: the throne of the built-up city be firm; 
#tr.en: that for the life of the true shepherd  
#tr.en: Gudea 
#tr.en: hands be placed at the mouth (in prayer)—  
#tr.en: his adviser, 
#tr.en: Lugal-sisa, to the lord Ningirsu   
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces). 
#tr.en: Of what had been whispered 
#tr.en: and what had been said aloud, 
#tr.en: of whether the one speaking straightforwardly be seen as a partner 
#tr.en: or whether the one speaking evil might not be seen as such(?)—  
#tr.en: that the warrior sitting on a pure dais, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, might be informed in Eninnu 
#tr.en: Šakkan-the-...- deer, the messenger of the “good house,” ... 
#tr.en: to the lord Ningirsu he (Gudea) brings along with himself 
#tr.en: (and introduces). 
#tr.en: That he (Kindazi) might clean with water, scrub with soap, 
#tr.en: that oil from the white stone jars be ..., 
#tr.en: that he (Ningirsu) on his bedspread with blue flowers
#tr.en: might enjoy sweet sleep; 
#tr.en: his bedroom in his “good house” 
#tr.en: that he might enter from outside, 
#tr.en: but) not go out from it (again)— 
#tr.en: Kindazi, who is the one of the “good house” 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: That the brand-new chariot ... might be yoked up   
#tr.en: and that a donkey stallion, a lion-summoned-for-running, 
#tr.en: be included in that donkey(-team); 
#tr.en: that a slender donkey, one of Eridu, 
#tr.en: might gallop along with the stallions ...; 
#tr.en: that they might carry their master Ningirsu in joy— 
#tr.en: the one roaring like a lion, 
#tr.en: rising like a floodstorm, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu’s hurrying bailiff, 
#tr.en: Ensignun, his donkeyherd, 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: That there might be an abundance of fat and cream, 
#tr.en: that the white goats, milking goats, and the hind, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu’s mother, 
#tr.en: might never cease to provide fat and milk for the sanctuary Eninnu— 
#tr.en: the Lord Stag, the herdsman of the hinds, to the lord Ningirsu 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces). 
#tr.en: That the kettle drum(?) of beautiful sound be properly tuned, 
#tr.en: that Eninnu’s courtyard be full of merriment, 
#tr.en: that algar and mirītum, the instruments of the “good house,” 
#tr.en: to the listening warrior, 
#tr.en: to Ningirsu in Eninnu, offer their best— 
#tr.en: his beloved musician, the Dragon-of-the-Land, 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.  
#tr.en: That one might be at ease, body and soul, 
#tr.en: that tears be dried off the weeping eye, 
#tr.en: hat anguish be cut off the anguishing heart; 
#tr.en: that the lord’s heart that rises like the sea, 
#tr.en: washes away like the Euphrates, 
#tr.en: that hits like a floodstorm 
#tr.en: all Enlil’s enemies, 
#tr.en: that after submerging has returned to its banks, be ...—  
#tr.en: his harp, the King-with-the-fierce-face, 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu 
#tr.en: His beloved lukur maidens, (creating) plentitude for the myriads, 
#tr.en: Zazaru, 
#tr.en: Iškur-pa’e, 
#tr.en: Ur-agrunta-ea, 
#tr.en: Ḫegirnuna, 
#tr.en: Ḫešaga, 
#tr.en: Zurmu, 
#tr.en: Zarmu— 
#tr.en: Baba’s 7 (twin) daughters they are 
#tr.en: and Ningirsu’s unruly children—
#tr.en: with friendly prayers on behalf of Gudea 
#tr.en: they are standing by the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: That the vast fields might grow rich, 
#tr.en: that the ditches and canals of Lagaš 
#tr.en: be full to the brim,  
#tr.en: that in the plain befitting its owner, 
#tr.en: in Gu-edina, the Grain goddess, Bright-and-long, Pure stalk, 
#tr.en: might proudly look up from her furrow, 
#tr.en: that after the good fields (of Lagaš) have brought wheat, emmer and all kinds of pulses, 
#tr.en: enormous grain heaps, the (whole) yield of the land of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: might be heaped up— 
#tr.en: Enlil’s surveyor, the farmer of Gu-edina, 
#tr.en: Gešbar-e, to the lord Ningirsu 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces). 
#tr.en: About the marshes (of Lagaš), after they had brought forth carp and perch(?),  
#tr.en: and about the green cane-brakes, after they had produced new shoots of reed— 
#tr.en: that I, the messenger of Gu-edina, 
#tr.en: might inform Ningirsu in Eninnu, 
#tr.en: Lama-inspector-of-the-fisheries-of-Gu-edina
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: That the steppe (as far as it is) a “good” place might be properly advised,  
#tr.en: the Gu-edina, the “good” steppe,  
#tr.en: be subject to inspection, 
#tr.en: that the birds might ..., 
#tr.en: that their eggs might be in the nest, 
#tr.en: that they rear their young, 
#tr.en: that the weaned young of the beasts, as many as there are, 
#tr.en: the beloved steppe of Ningirsu  
#tr.en: might not diminish,
#tr.en: Dimngal-abzu, the herald of Gu-edina, 
#tr.en: to the lord Ningirsu along with himself  
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings (and introduces). 
#tr.en: That cities be built, settlements be founded, 
#tr.en: that the guard-houses of the wall of the Shining City might be built, 
#tr.en: that its resident constable, 
#tr.en: (being) the White cedar mace with the enormous head,  
#tr.en: might stay close to the House— 
#tr.en: the divine Master of the guard house of the Shining City 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: Enlil had ..., 
#tr.en: Ninḫursag had looked on it in a friendly way, 
#tr.en: Enki, king of Eridu, had driven in its foundation boxes. 
#tr.en: the true lord of a most pure heart, Suen, 
#tr.en: had in fact seen to it that (Eninnu’s) powers were greater than (the whole of) heaven and earth. 
#tr.en: Ningirsu had conceived (the House) in (his) heart as a sanctuary from which the seed sprouted,  
#tr.en: for the (first) Brick of the land of Lagaš Mother Nanše 
#tr.en: had cared, 
#tr.en: (but) the god of most reliable progeny 
#tr.en: (really) did build the House and make its name famous. 
#tr.en: The mighty steward of Nanše, 
#tr.en: the brave shepherd of Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: is wise and able, too, to realize things. 
#tr.en: For the House, the one who built it, 
#tr.en: Gudea, ruler 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: is (now) making presents. 
#tr.en: The chariot (named) “It subdued the mountain,” which carries terror and has made great awe “ride” on it, 
#tr.en: its donkey stallion, a merrily neighing wind,  
#tr.en: which is to be harnessed with the (other) donkeys, 
#tr.en: the seven-headed club, fierce battle mace, 
#tr.en: the weapon unbearable for North and South, a cudgel in pitched battle, 
#tr.en: (and) the “dead man,” the lion-headed weapon of ḫulālu stone,  
#tr.en: which never turns back before the highlands, 
#tr.en: the ... 9 standards, 
#tr.en: the warrior-arm, 
#tr.en: his bow twanging like a forest of mes trees, 
#tr.en: his angry arrows whizzing like flashes in battle, 
#tr.en: his quiver (depicting) lions and lionesses(?) against which fierce snakes 
#tr.en: stick out the tongue,  
#tr.en: (all of them) arms of battle that have been endued with the power of kingship— 
#tr.en: (with all this) the ruler, who had built the House,  
#tr.en: Gudea, ruler 
#tr.en: of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: is presenting (the House). 
#tr.en: Along with copper, tin, slabs of lapis lazuli, shining metal (and) spotless Meluḫḫa carnelian, 
#tr.en: huge copper pails, huge copper uri-vessels, 
#tr.en: shining copper ešda-vessels, shining copper bowls befitting An, 
#tr.en: ... ...ed at the ... place ...,  
#tr.en: so that a properly set table (= altar?) 
#tr.en: might be piled up to An. 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, his city 
#tr.en: Lagaš, ...
#tr.en: In its bedroom, the resting place of the House, 
#tr.en: he set up the bed. 
#tr.en: Everybody with Enlil’s son like the birds in their ... 
#tr.en: now rests. 
#tr.en: That (from now on) the river be full of flowing water, 
#tr.en: that there be carp and perch(?) in the marshes, 
#tr.en: that the inspector of fisheries and the dike inspector might assist, 
#tr.en: that barley might be filled in (and shipped) on the great waters, 
#tr.en: that tons, heaps and tons, the income of the land of Lagaš, 
#tr.en: might be piled up; 
#tr.en: that cattle-pens and sheepfolds be built, 
#tr.en: that lambs might abound around the healthy ewes, 
#tr.en: that the rams be let loose on the healthy ewes, 
#tr.en: that many calves might stand by the healthy cows, 
#tr.en: and that the pure-bred sire might low among them; 
#tr.en: that the oxen be properly yoked 
#tr.en: and the farmer and the ox-driver might stand at their place; 
#tr.en: that the pack-saddles be lifted on the donkeys 
#tr.en: and that the hirelings who feed them follow behind them, 
#tr.en:  that huge copper ... be strapped on the jackasses; 
#tr.en: that the mill might burst (with work) 
#tr.en: so that in the ..., the house of Ningirsu’s young slave women, 
#tr.en: ...; 
#tr.en: that ... be set right, 
#tr.en: that the courtyard of Eninnu be filled with joy,  
#tr.en: that together with the kettle drums(?) ala instruments and harps might sound in perfect concert 
#tr.en: and that (Ningirsu’s) beloved harp, the Dragon-of-the-Land,  
#tr.en: walk in front (of the procession)— 
#tr.en: (to that intent) did the ruler who had built the Eninnu, 
#tr.en: Gudea before the lord Ningirsu  
#tr.en: did come. 
#tr.en: The House lifted the head, proud of itself, 
#tr.en: unparalleled in awe and splendor. 
#tr.en: Like a boat it ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: Its owner, on the dais of Girnun, 
#tr.en: the warrior Ningirsu came out like daylight. 
#tr.en: The canopy(?) (of the dais) resting on a support 
#tr.en: is (like) the beautiful sky carrying splendour. 
#tr.en: The poles (of the canopy?) and their caps  
#tr.en: are Ningirsu (himself), laden with terror. 
#tr.en: The leather cord (of the canopy?) fitted in front of it 
#tr.en: is (like) a snake with a yellow mouth bathing in water. 
#tr.en: In his most fascinating blue chariot 
#tr.en: The owner (of the House), the warrior Ningirsu, stands like the sun god. 
#tr.en: The throne (of the House) standing in the guenna   
#tr.en: is the bright seat of An, dwelling in ... . 
#tr.en: The bed (of the House) standing in the bedroom 
#tr.en: is (adorned with) young cows that kneel down at their shed. 
#tr.en: On the snow-white cover (of the bed) having a pattern of blue flowers, 
#tr.en: mother Baba with the lord Ningirsu 
#tr.en: is lying at ease. 
#tr.en: Large bronze (plates) offer all sorts of food, 
#tr.en: in the “good” house at the side, (meals prepared from) first ...  
#tr.en: are cooking in shining bronze (vessels). 
#tr.en: The pure stone jars standing in the dining-hall 
#tr.en: are (like) huge, stout troughs with an inexhaustible supply of water, 
#tr.en: and the goblets standing next to them  
#tr.en: are both the Tigris and the Euphrates 
#tr.en: bringing abundance. 
#tr.en: (Thus) he had caused everything to function as it should in his city;  
#tr.en: Gudea had built the Eninnu, 
#tr.en: had met with all cultic necessities. 
#tr.en: He brought fat and cream into the dairy, 
#tr.en: he stored many things in the ... (of the House). 
#tr.en: He had debts remitted and he granted pardons. 
#tr.en: When his master had entered his House, 
#tr.en: for seven days 
#tr.en: the slave woman was allowed to be equal to her mistress, 
#tr.en: the slave was allowed to walk side by side with his master. 
#tr.en: In his city the one (who appeared) unclean (to someone) was permitted to sleep (only) outside. 
#tr.en: he had words cut off the evil-speaking tongue, 
#tr.en: and he had anything disharmonious turned away from the House. 
#tr.en: To the justice (ordained) by Nanše and Ningirsu  
#tr.en: he paid attention; 
#tr.en: he did not expose the orphan to the wealthy person 
#tr.en: nor did he expose the widow to the influential one. 
#tr.en: In(?) a house having no male child, 
#tr.en: a daughter of it would become its heir.
#tr.en: Days of justice had risen for him, 
#tr.en: and he set (his) foot on the neck of evil and complaint. 
#tr.en: For his city like the sun god 
#tr.en: had he himself not risen from the horizon? 
#tr.en: He ... 
#tr.en: In the face of bright heaven 
#tr.en: he showed who he was. 
#tr.en: Like a bull he enters, his head raised high. 
#tr.en: In the Eninnu sanctuary 
#tr.en: he had unblemished oxen and kids slaughtered. 
#tr.en: He put a jar in the open 
#tr.en: and poured much wine into it. 
#tr.en: The (harp) Dragon-of-the-Land he joined with the kettle drum(?), 
#tr.en: and the ala instruments sounded for him like a storm.  
#tr.en: Lo, the ruler on a ... 
#tr.en: stood, 
#tr.en: and his city gave him acclaim. 
#tr.en: Gudea ...
#tr.en: ... brought forth abundance for him. 
#tr.en: All places grew speckled barley for him. 
#tr.en: Lagaš under (its) ruler made abundance  
#tr.en: increase for him. 
#tr.en: (Now) that the warrior had moved into his new House, 
#tr.en: (Gudea) served a delicious banquet to the lord Ningirsu. 
#tr.en: He seated An at the place of honour for him,  
#tr.en: he made Enlil sit next to An 
#tr.en: and next to Enlil 
#tr.en: he seated Ninmaḫ. 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: The owner rejoiced over the House, 
#tr.en: and he made a firm promise for the “brick” of Eninnu: 
#tr.en: “O brick of Eninnu, 
#tr.en: let something favorable be promised, 
#tr.en: brick of Eninnu, let it be promised, 
#tr.en: let something favorable be promised, 
#tr.en: House, a mountain founded in heaven, 
#tr.en: built as (your) very self, 
#tr.en: He determines the destiny of the brickwork of the Eninnu, 
#tr.en: he determines the brickwork's destiny, 
#tr.en: he determines a good destiny for the brickwork of the Eninnu:
#tr.en: "The temple that lets fear(?) fall like embers, set upon the earth and embracing heaven,   
#tr.en: ... holy ...
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... Let the cattle pens be built on your behalf, 
#tr.en: let the sheepfolds be renewed on your account. 
#tr.en: May the people lie down in safe pastures under your reign, (enjoying) abundance, 
#tr.en: and let the eyes of all the countries be directed toward Sumer. 
#tr.en: May the House, your Thunderbird, soar in the skies for your (benefit). 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ...
#tr.en: grown as tall as Gilgamesh, 
#tr.en: its throne set there no one shall remove. 
#tr.en: Your (personal) god is Ningešzida, grandson of An, 
#tr.en: your mother goddess is Ninsuna, the mother who bore healthy offspring 
#tr.en: and who loves (her) offspring. 
#tr.en: You are (the young) whom the dear cow has born, 
#tr.en: the faithful youth arisen from Lagaš, 
#tr.en: you are Ningirsu’s. 
#tr.en: May your name be famous from “Below” to “Above”. 
#tr.en: O Gudea, what you ordered,  
#tr.en: nobody ... shall pass over, 
#tr.en: you ... are a man known to An,
#tr.en: you are a faithful ruler to (whose) house a firm promise has been made. 
#tr.en: Gudea, son of Ningešzida, 
#tr.en: may life be prolonged for you.” 
#tr.en: O House that reaches to heaven like a great mountain, 
#tr.en: whose awe and aura are shed over the Land, 
#tr.en: (now) that An, that Enlil have made a firm promise for Lagaš, 
#tr.en: that about Ningirsu’s reputation 
#tr.en: all countries have learned 
#tr.en: that Eninnu is joined both to heaven and earth— 
#tr.en: praise be unto Ningirsu! 
#tr.en: Of (the composition) “Ningirsu’s House having been built” 
#tr.en: (this) is the end of the praising hymn.

#tr.en: ruler

#tr.en: ruler

#tr.en: he constructed for her. 
#tr.en: Her great throne of queenship 
#tr.en: he constructed for her, 
#tr.en: and into her Great Temple he had it brought to her. 
#tr.en: From the mountains of Magan 
#tr.en: he had diorite brought down, 
#tr.en: and into (this) his stone figure 
#tr.en: he formed it. 
#tr.en: The lady who would determine the fates in heaven and earth, 
#tr.en: Nintu, 
#tr.en: the mother of the gods, 
#tr.en: of Gudea, 
#tr.en: the man who built the temple, 
#tr.en: his life she shall prolong, 
#tr.en: he named it for her, 
#tr.en: and into the temple he had it brought to her.

#tr.en: his master-

#tr.en: strong hero

#tr.en: ruler

#tr.en: child born 
#tr.en: by Gatumdug,

#tr.en: by Igalima, 
#tr.en: richly provided with encouragement 
#tr.en: by Šulšaga, 
#tr.en: rightful head of the assembly come forth in splendor 
#tr.en: of Ningešzida 
#tr.en: his (personal) god, 
#tr.en: when Ningirsu 
#tr.en: had directed his righteous gaze towards his city, 
#tr.en: and Gudea 
#tr.en: he had chosen as the rightful shepherd in the nation, 
#tr.en: and out of 36,000 people 
#tr.en: had taken him by the hand, 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) sanctified the city and refined it with fire. 
#tr.en: He set up the brick mold, 
#tr.en: and chose the (first) brick by kid-omen. 
#tr.en: The sexually impure persons who inspire fear, 
#tr.en: the [...] man, 
#tr.en: he with a shriveled(?) penis, 
#tr.en: and the woman who had been in labor(?), 
#tr.en: he sent out of the city. 
#tr.en: Women did not carry the earth baskets for it, 
#tr.en: (only) the chief warriors did the building for him. 
#tr.en: The temple of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: like (the city) Eridu 
#tr.en: in a clean place he built. 
#tr.en: There was no beating with whips 
#tr.en: nor beating with leather straps. 
#tr.en: No mother hit her child with anything. 
#tr.en: The military governors, 
#tr.en: overseers, 
#tr.en: foremen, 
#tr.en: those who performed worker levies, 
#tr.en: while stationed at the work 
#tr.en: (as light as) wool under the carding comb 
#tr.en: was the disciplining he put into their hands. 
#tr.en: No pickax was used in the cemetery of the city, 
#tr.en: no corpse was buried. 
#tr.en: The lamentation singer did not play the harp or bring forth laments, 
#tr.en: The wailing women did not perform wailing. 
#tr.en: Within the territory 
#tr.en: of Lagash, 
#tr.en: a person having a lawsuit 
#tr.en: to the place of oath-taking 
#tr.en: did not make another person go, 
#tr.en: and a creditor 
#tr.en: did not enter another person's house. 
#tr.en: For Ningirsu 
#tr.en: his master 
#tr.en: he (Gudea) made a fitting thing come forth resplendently, 
#tr.en: (namely) his temple Eninnu with a white thunderbird 
#tr.en: he built for him 
#tr.en: and restored for him. 
#tr.en: In the center of it his beloved high terrace 
#tr.en: with aromatic cedar 
#tr.en: he built for him. 
#tr.en: When the temple of Ningirsu 
#tr.en: he built, 
#tr.en: Ningirsu, 
#tr.en: his master who loved him, 
#tr.en: from the Upper Sea 
#tr.en: to the Lower Sea 
#tr.en: opened up the roads for him. 
#tr.en: From the Amanus, the mountain range of cedar, 
#tr.en: cedars 
#tr.en: whose length was sixty cubits, 
#tr.en: cedars 
#tr.en: whose length was fifty cubits, 
#tr.en: and boxwood 
#tr.en: whose length was twenty-five cubits, 
#tr.en: he made into planks 
#tr.en: and brought them down from their mountains. 
#tr.en: Levels the Multitudes, his storm of battle, 
#tr.en: he constructed for him, 
#tr.en: and Slaughters the Multitudes, his copper seven-faced peg, 
#tr.en: he constructed for him. 
#tr.en: His copper peg of a side-ax 
#tr.en: he constructed for him, 
#tr.en: and his copper peg of an allul-ax 
#tr.en: he constructed for him. 
#tr.en: Those cedars 
#tr.en: into big doors 
#tr.en: he fashioned, 
#tr.en: decorated them with sacred flowers, 
#tr.en: and into the Eninnu 
#tr.en: he had them brought for him. 
#tr.en: In his lofty temple where cold water would be poured, 
#tr.en: he (also) set them as roof-beams for him. 
#tr.en: From the city of Ursu 
#tr.en: and the mountain range of Ebla 
#tr.en: juniper,
