#tr.en: Stone, 10 mana;
#tr.en: Napsamenni,
#tr.en: foreman of the diviners, nešakku-official of Enlil,
#tr.en: servant of Marduk-šāpik-zēri,
#tr.en: king of Babylon.
#tr.en: 30 mana, established, 
#tr.en: that of Nabȗ-šumu-libūr. 
#tr.en: 30 mana, established: 
#tr.en: palace of Erība-Marduk, 
#tr.en: king of Babylon. 
#tr.en: n mana, established: 
#tr.en: palace of Erība-Marduk, 
#tr.en: king of Babylon. 
#tr.en: From the great heaven she set her mind on the great below. 
#tr.en: From the great heaven the goddess set her mind on the great below. 
#tr.en: From the great heaven Inana set her mind on the great below. 
#tr.en: My mistress abandoned heaven, abandoned earth, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: Inana abandoned heaven, abandoned earth, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the office of en, abandoned the office of lagar, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Eanna in Uruk, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-muš-kalam in Bad-tibira, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Giguna in zabala, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-šara in Adab, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Bara-dur-gara in Nibru, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Hursag-kalama in Kiš, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-Ulmaš in Agade, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Ebgal in Umma, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-Dilmuna in Ur, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Amaš-e-ku in Kisiga, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-ešdam-ku in Girsu, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-sig-meše-du in Isin, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Anzagar in Akšak, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the Nigin-gar-ku in Šuruppak, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She abandoned the E-cag-hula in Kazallu, and descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: She took the seven divine powers. 
#tr.en: She collected the divine powers and grasped them in her hand. 
#tr.en: With the good divine powers, she went on her way. 
#tr.en: She put a turban, headgear for the open country, on her head. 
#tr.en: She took a wig for her forehead. 
#tr.en: She hung small lapis-lazuli beads around her neck. 
#tr.en: She placed twin egg-shaped beads on her breast. 
#tr.en: She covered her body with a pala dress, the garment of ladyship. 
#tr.en: She placed mascara “Let a man come, let him come” on her eyes. 
#tr.en: She pulled the pectoral “Come, man, come” over her breast. 
#tr.en: She placed a golden ring on her hand. 
#tr.en: She held the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line in her hand. 
#tr.en: Inanna traveled towards the underworld. 
#tr.en: Her minister Ninšubur traveled behind her. 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna says to Ninšubur: 
#tr.en: “Come my faithful minister of Eanna, 
#tr.en: my minister who speaks fair words, 
#tr.en: my escort who speaks trustworthy words 
#tr.en: “On this day I will descend to the underworld. 
#tr.en: When I have arrived in the underworld, 
#tr.en: make a lament for me on the ruin mounds. 
#tr.en: Beat the drum for me in the sanctuary. 
#tr.en: Make the rounds of the houses of the gods for me. 
#tr.en: “Lacerate your eyes for me, lacerate your nose for me. 
#tr.en: In private, lacerate your buttocks for me. 
#tr.en: Like a pauper, clothe yourself in a single garment 
#tr.en: and all alone set your foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil. 
#tr.en: “When you have entered the E-kur, the house of Enlil, 
#tr.en: lament before Enlil: 
#tr.en: “Father Enlil, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
#tr.en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
#tr.en: “If Enlil does not help you in this matter, go to Ur. 
#tr.en: In the E-mukura at Ur, 
#tr.en: when you have entered the E-kišnugal toward Nanna, 
#tr.en: lament before Nanna: 
#tr.en: “Father Nanna, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
#tr.en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
#tr.en: “And if Nanna does not help you in this matter, go to Eridu. 
#tr.en: In Eridu, when you have entered the house of Enki, 
#tr.en: lament before Enki: 
#tr.en: “Father Enki, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
#tr.en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
#tr.en: “Father Enki, the lord of great wisdom, 
#tr.en: knows about the life-giving plant and the life-giving water. 
#tr.en: He is the one who will restore me to life.” 
#tr.en: When Inanna traveled on towards the underworld, 
#tr.en: her minister Ninšubur traveled on behind her. 
#tr.en: She says to her minister Ninšubur: 
#tr.en: “Go now, my Ninšubur, and pay attention. 
#tr.en: Don’t neglect the instructions I gave you.” 
#tr.en: When Inanna arrived at the palace Ganzer, 
#tr.en: she pushed aggressively on the door of the underworld. 
#tr.en: She shouted aggressively at the gate of the underworld: 
#tr.en: “Open up, doorman, open up. 
#tr.en: Open up, Neti, open up. I am all alone and I want to come in.” 
#tr.en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
#tr.en: answers holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “Who are you?” 
#tr.en: “I am Inanna going to the east.” 
#tr.en: “If you are Inanna going to the east, 
#tr.en: why have you traveled to the land of no return? 
#tr.en: How did you set your heart on the road whose traveller never returns?” 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna answers him: 
#tr.en: “Because lord Gud-gal-ana, 
#tr.en: the husband of my elder sister holy Ereškigal, has died; 
#tr.en: in order to have his funeral rites observed, 
#tr.en: she offers generous libations at his wake; that is the reason.” 
#tr.en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
#tr.en: answers holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “Stay here, Inanna. I will speak to my mistress. 
#tr.en: I will speak to my mistress Ereškigal and tell her what you have said.” 
#tr.en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
#tr.en: to his mistress Ereškigal 
#tr.en: entered the house and said: 
#tr.en: “My mistress, there is a lone girl outside. 
#tr.en: It is Inanna, your sister, and she has arrived at the palace Ganzer. 
#tr.en: She pushed aggressively on the door of the underworld. 
#tr.en: She shouted aggressively at the gate of the underworld. 
#tr.en: She has abandoned Eanna and has descended to the underworld. 
#tr.en: “She has taken the 7 divine powers. 
#tr.en: She has collected the divine powers and grasped them in her hand. 
#tr.en: She has come on her way with all the good divine powers. 
#tr.en: She has put a turban, headgear for the open country, on her head. 
#tr.en: She has taken a wig for her forehead. 
#tr.en: She has hung small lapis-lazuli beads around her neck. 
#tr.en: “She has placed twin egg-shaped beads on her breast. 
#tr.en: She has covered her body with the pala dress of ladyship. 
#tr.en: She has placed mascara “Let a man come” on her eyes. 
#tr.en: She has pulled the pectoral “Come, man, come” over her breast. 
#tr.en: She has placed a golden ring on her hand. 
#tr.en: She is holding the lapis-lazuli ‘reed-1-ninda’ measuring rod and measuring line in her hand.” 
#tr.en: When she heard this, Ereškigal slapped the side of her thigh. 
#tr.en: She bit her lip and took the words to heart. 
#tr.en: She says to Neti, her chief doorman: 
#tr.en: “Come Neti, my chief doorman of the underworld, 
#tr.en: don’t neglect the instructions I will give you. 
#tr.en: Let the seven gates of the underworld be bolted. 
#tr.en: Then let each door of the palace Ganzer be opened separately. 
#tr.en: As for her, after she has entered, 
#tr.en: and crouched down and had her clothes removed, they will be carried away.” 
#tr.en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
#tr.en: paid attention to the instructions of his mistress. 
#tr.en: He bolted the 7 gates of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Then he opened each of the doors of the palace Ganzer separately. 
#tr.en: He says to holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “Come on, Inanna, and enter.” 
#tr.en: And when Inanna entered, 
#tr.en: the turban, headgear for the open country, was removed from her head. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: When she entered the 2nd gate, 
#tr.en: the small lapis-lazuli beads were removed from her neck. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: When she entered the 3rd gate, 
#tr.en: the twin egg-shaped beads were removed from her breast. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: When she entered the 4th gate, 
#tr.en: the pectoral “Come, man, come” was removed from her breast. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: When she entered the 5th gate, 
#tr.en: the golden ring was removed from her hand. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: When she entered the 6th gate, 
#tr.en: the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line were removed from her hand. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: When she entered the 7th gate, 
#tr.en: the pala dress, the garment of ladyship, was removed from her body. 
#tr.en: “What is this?” 
#tr.en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
#tr.en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
#tr.en: After she had crouched down and had her clothes removed, they were carried away. 
#tr.en: Then she made her sister Ereškigal rise from her throne, 
#tr.en: and instead she sat on her throne. 
#tr.en: The Anuna, the seven judges, rendered their decision against her. 
#tr.en: They looked at her—it was the look of death! 
#tr.en: They spoke to her—it was the speech of anger! 
#tr.en: They shouted at her—it was the shout of heavy guilt! 
#tr.en: The afflicted woman was turned into a corpse! 
#tr.en: And the corpse was hung on a hook. 
#tr.en: After 3 days and 3 nights had passed, 
#tr.en: her minister Ninšubur 
#tr.en: carried out the instructions of her mistress. 
#tr.en: She made a lament for her in her ruined (houses). 
#tr.en: She beat the drum for her in the sanctuaries. 
#tr.en: She made the rounds of the houses of the gods for her. 
#tr.en: She lacerated her eyes for her, she lacerated her nose. 
#tr.en: In private she lacerated her buttocks for her. 
#tr.en: Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment, 
#tr.en: and all alone she set her foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil. 
#tr.en: When she had entered the E-kur, the house of Enlil, 
#tr.en: she laments before Enlil: 
#tr.en: “Father Enlil, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
#tr.en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
#tr.en: In his rage father Enlil answers Ninšubur: 
#tr.en: “My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
#tr.en: Inanna craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
#tr.en: The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?” 
#tr.en: Thus father Enlil did not help in this matter, so she went to Ur. 
#tr.en: In the E-mud-kura at Ur, 
#tr.en: when she had entered the E-kišnugal, the house of Nanna, 
#tr.en: she laments before Nanna: 
#tr.en: “Father Nanna, don’t let your daughter be killed in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
#tr.en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
#tr.en: In his rage father Nanna answers Ninšubur: 
#tr.en: “My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
#tr.en: Inanna craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
#tr.en: The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?” 
#tr.en: Thus father Nanna did not help her in this matter, so she went to Eridu. 
#tr.en: In Eridu, when she had entered the house of Enki, 
#tr.en: xshe laments before Enki:xx 
#tr.en: “Father Enki, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
#tr.en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
#tr.en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
#tr.en: Father Enki answered Ninšubur: 
#tr.en: “What has my daughter done? She has me worried. 
#tr.en: What has Inanna done? She has me worried. 
#tr.en: What has the mistress of all the lands done? She has me worried. 
#tr.en: What has the hierodule of An done? She has me worried.” 
#tr.en: He removed some dirt from the tip of his fingernail and created the kur-gar. 
#tr.en: He removed some dirt from the tip of his 2nd fingernail and created the gala-tur. 
#tr.en: To the kur-gar he gave the life-giving plant. 
#tr.en: To the gala-tura he gave the life-giving water. 
#tr.en: Then father Enki speaks out to the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
#tr.en: Go and direct your steps to the underworld. 
#tr.en: Flit past the door like flies. 
#tr.en: Slip through the door pivots like phantoms. 
#tr.en: The birth-mother, on account of her children, 
#tr.en: Ereškigal, is lying there. 
#tr.en: Her holy shoulders are not covered by a linen cloth. 
#tr.en: Her breasts are not full like a cagan vessel. 
#tr.en: Her nails are like a pickaxe (?) upon her. 
#tr.en: The hair on her head is bunched up as if it were leeks. 
#tr.en: “When she says “Oh my heart,” 
#tr.en: you are to say “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart.” 
#tr.en: When she says “Oh my liver,” 
#tr.en: you are to say “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your liver.” 
#tr.en: (She will then ask:) “Who are you? 
#tr.en: Speaking to you from my heart to your heart, from my liver to your liver— 
#tr.en: if you are gods, let me talk with you; 
#tr.en: if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you.” 
#tr.en: Make her swear this by heaven and earth. 
#tr.en: Go on out, 
#tr.en: They will offer you a riverful of water—don’t accept it. 
#tr.en: They will offer you a field with its grain—don’t accept it. 
#tr.en: But say to her: “Give us the corpse hanging on the hook.” 
#tr.en: (She will answer:) “That is the corpse of your queen.” 
#tr.en: Say to her: “Whether it is that of our king, whether it is that of our queen, give it to us.” 
#tr.en: She will give you the corpse hanging on the hook. 
#tr.en: 1 of you sprinkle on it the life-giving plant and 1 the life-giving water. 
#tr.en: Thus let Inanna rise up.” 
#tr.en: The gala-tura and the kur-gar paid attention to the instructions of Enki. 
#tr.en: They flitted through the door like flies. 
#tr.en: They slipped through the door pivots like phantoms. 
#tr.en: The birth-mother, because of her children, 
#tr.en: Ereškigal, was lying there. 
#tr.en: Her holy shoulders were not covered by a linen cloth. 
#tr.en: Her breasts were not full like a cagan vessel. 
#tr.en: Her nails were like a pickaxe (?) upon her. 
#tr.en: The hair on her head was bunched up as if it were leeks. 
#tr.en: When she said “Oh my heart,” 
#tr.en: they said to her “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart.” 
#tr.en: When she said “Oh my liver,” 
#tr.en: they said to her “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your liver.” 
#tr.en: (Then she asked:) “Who are you? 
#tr.en: I tell you from my heart to your heart, from my liver to your liver— 
#tr.en: if you are gods, I will talk with you; 
#tr.en: if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you.” 
#tr.en: They made her swear this by heaven and earth. 
#tr.en: they went on out, 
#tr.en: they were offered a river with its water—they did not accept it. 
#tr.en: They were offered a field with its grain—they did not accept it. 
#tr.en: They said to her: “Give us the corpse hanging on the hook.” 
#tr.en: Holy Ereškigal answers the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
#tr.en: “The corpse is that of your queen.” 
#tr.en: They said to her: “Whether it is that of our king or that of our queen, give it to us.” 
#tr.en: They were given the corpse hanging on the hook. 
#tr.en: 1 of them sprinkled on it the life-giving plant and 1 the life-giving water. 
#tr.en: And thus Inanna rose up. 
#tr.en: Ereškigal says to the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
#tr.en: “Bring your queen ..., your ... has been seized.” 
#tr.en: Inanna, because of Enki’s instructions, was about to ascend from the underworld. 
#tr.en: But as Inanna was about to ascend from the underworld, 
#tr.en: the Anuna seized her: 
#tr.en: “Who has ever ascended from the underworld, has ascended unscathed from the underworld? 
#tr.en: If Inanna is to ascend from the underworld, 
#tr.en: let her provide a substitute for herself.” 
#tr.en: So when Inanna left the underworld, 
#tr.en: the one in front of her, though not a minister, held a sceptre in his hand; 
#tr.en: the one behind her, though not an escort, carried a mace at his hip, 
#tr.en: while the small demons, like a reed enclosure, 
#tr.en: and the big demons, like the reeds of a fence, restrained her on all sides. 
#tr.en: Those who accompanied her, 
#tr.en: those who accompanied Inanna, 
#tr.en: know no food, know no drink, 
#tr.en: eat no flour offering 
#tr.en: and drink no libation. 
#tr.en: They accept no pleasant gifts. 
#tr.en: They take away the child hanging on a wet-nurse’s breasts. 
#tr.en: They crush no bitter garlic. 
#tr.en: They eat no fish, they eat no leeks. 
#tr.en: They, it was, who accompanied Inanna. 
#tr.en: After Inanna had ascended from the underworld, 
#tr.en: Ninšubur threw herself at her feet at the door of the Ganzer. 
#tr.en: She had sat in the dust and clothed herself in a filthy garment. 
#tr.en: The demons said to holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “Inanna, proceed to your city, we will take her back.” 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna answers the demons: 
#tr.en: “This is my minister of fair words, 
#tr.en: my escort of trustworthy words. 
#tr.en: She did not forget my instructions. 
#tr.en: She did not neglect the orders I gave her. 
#tr.en: She made a lament for me on the ruin mounds. 
#tr.en: She beat the drum for me in the sanctuaries. 
#tr.en: She made the rounds of the gods’ houses for me. 
#tr.en: She lacerated her eyes for me, lacerated her nose for me. 
#tr.en: In private, she lacerated her buttocks for me. 
#tr.en: Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment. 
#tr.en: “To the house of Enlil, 
#tr.en: and to Ur, to the house of Nanna, 
#tr.en: and to Eridu, to the house of Enki, 
#tr.en: all alone she directed her steps. 
#tr.en: She brought me back to life. 
#tr.en: How could I turn her over to you? 
#tr.en: Let us go on. Let us go on to the Šegkuršaga in Umma.” 
#tr.en: At the Šegkuršaga in Umma, 
#tr.en: Šara, in his own city, threw himself at her feet. 
#tr.en: He had sat in the dust and dressed himself in a filthy garment. 
#tr.en: The demons say to holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “Inanna, proceed to your city, we will take him back.” 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna answered the demons: 
#tr.en: “Šara is my singer, 
#tr.en: my manicurist and my hairdresser. 
#tr.en: How could I turn him over to you? 
#tr.en: Let us go on. Let us go on to the E-muškalama in Bad-tibira.” 
#tr.en: At the E-muškalama in Bad-tibira, 
#tr.en: Lulal, in his own city, threw himself at her feet. 
#tr.en: He had sat in the dust and clothed himself in a filthy garment. 
#tr.en: The demons said to holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “Inanna, proceed to your city, we will take him back.” 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna answers the demons: 
#tr.en: “Outstanding Lulal follows me at my right and my left. 
#tr.en: How could I turn him over to you? 
#tr.en: Let us go on. Let us go on to the great apple tree in the plain of Kulaba.” 
#tr.en: They followed her to the great apple tree in the plain of Kulaba. 
#tr.en: There was Dumuzi clothed in a magnificent garment and seated magnificently on a throne. 
#tr.en: The demons seized him there by his thighs. 
#tr.en: The 7 of them poured the milk from his churns. 
#tr.en: The seven of them shook their heads like ... 
#tr.en: They would not let the shepherd play the pipe and flute before her (?). 
#tr.en: She looked at him, it was the look of death. 
#tr.en: She spoke to him (?), it was the speech of anger. 
#tr.en: She shouted at him (?), it was the shout of heavy guilt: 
#tr.en: “How much longer? Take him away.” 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna gave Dumuzi the shepherd into their hands. 
#tr.en: Those who had accompanied her, 
#tr.en: who had come for Dumuzi, 
#tr.en: know no food, know no drink, 
#tr.en: eat no flour offering, 
#tr.en: drink no libation. 
#tr.en: They never enjoy the pleasures of the marital embrace, 
#tr.en: never have any sweet children to kiss. 
#tr.en: They snatch the son from a man’s knee. 
#tr.en: They make the bride leave the house of her father-in-law. 
#tr.en: Dumuzi let out a wail and turned very pale. 
#tr.en: The lad raised his hands to heaven, to Utu: 
#tr.en: “Utu, you are my brother-in-law. 
#tr.en: I am your relation by marriage. I brought butter oil to your mother’s house 
#tr.en: I brought cheese to Ningal’s house. 
#tr.en: Turn my hands into snake’s hands 
#tr.en: and turn my feet into snake’s feet, 
#tr.en: so I can escape my demons, let them not keep hold of me.” 
#tr.en: Utu accepted his tears. 
#tr.en: Utu turned Dumuzi’s hands into snake’s hands. 
#tr.en: He turned his feet into snake’s feet. 
#tr.en: Dumuzi escaped his demons. 
#tr.en: having seized ..., 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna ... her heart. 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna wept bitterly for her husband. 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna ... Dumuzi ... her heart ... 
#tr.en: ... her husband ... by force ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... like ... 
#tr.en: She tore at her hair like esparto grass, she ripped it out like esparto grass. 
#tr.en: “You wives who lie in your men’s embrace, where is my precious husband? 
#tr.en: You children who lie in your men’s embrace, where is my precious child? 
#tr.en: Where is my man? Where ...? 
#tr.en: Where is my man? Where ...?” 
#tr.en: A fly speaks to holy Inanna: 
#tr.en: “If I show you where your man is, what will be my reward?” 
#tr.en: Holy Inanna answers the fly: 
#tr.en: “If you show me where my man is, I will give you this gift: 
#tr.en: I will cover ... .” 
#tr.en: The fly helped (?) holy Inanna. 
#tr.en: The young lady Inanna decreed the destiny of the fly: 
#tr.en: “In the beer-house and the tavern (?), may there ... for you. 
#tr.en: You will live (?) like the sons of the wise.” 
#tr.en: Now Inanna decreed this fate and thus it came to be. 
#tr.en: ... was weeping. 
#tr.en: She came up to the sister (?) and ... by the hand: 
#tr.en: “Now, alas, my ... 
#tr.en: You for half the year and your sister for half the year: 
#tr.en: when you are demanded, on that day you will stay, 
#tr.en: when your sister is demanded, on that day you will be released.” 
#tr.en: Thus holy Inanna gave Dumuzi as a substitute ... 
#tr.en: Holy Ereškigal: 
#tr.en: sweet is your praise. 
#tr.en: Šara-kam, 
#tr.en: scribe: 
#tr.en: Šulgi-mudaḫ, your servant. 
#tr.en: 1 duck,

#tr.en: for food of my queen;

#tr.en: slaughtered, 
#tr.en: brought to the palace; 
#tr.en: of the month the 17th day passed;

#tr.en: king

#tr.en: Ibni-šarrī, 
#tr.en: scribe, 
#tr.en: is your servant.

#tr.en: (from the account of) Ur-nigar

#tr.en: has received; 
#tr.en: if his sealed document

#tr.en: he will break (it). 
#tr.en: Before Sîn-uselli; 
#tr.en: before Ubārrum, the colonel, son of Ilī-mālikī;

#tr.en: made available to Marduk-šumu-līšir 
#tr.en: and Nūr-Sîn; 
#tr.en: month: “Bricks,” 2nd day; 
#tr.en: 8th year: “Nabonidus, king of Babylon.”

#tr.en: in Puzrish-Dagan;

#tr.en: fodder for the grain-fed sheep;

#tr.en: Šulgi-ilī 
#tr.en: received; 
#tr.en: via Lu-girizal 
#tr.en: month: “Gazelle-feast,” 
#tr.en: year: “Ibbi-Suen is king.” 
#tr.en: After the flood had swept over 
#tr.en: and brought about the destruction of the countries; 
#tr.en: when mankind was made to endure, 
#tr.en: and the seed of mankind was preserved 
#tr.en: and the black-headed people all rose; 
#tr.en: when An and Enlil 
#tr.en: called the name of mankind 
#tr.en: and established rulership, 
#tr.en: but kingship and the crown of the city 
#tr.en: had not yet come out from heaven, 
#tr.en: and Ningirsu, the hoe and the spade 
#tr.en: the earth basket and the plough, which mean life for the Land, 
#tr.en: had not yet established for the multitude of well-guarded (?) people 
#tr.en: -- in those days, the carefree youth of man 
#tr.en: lasted for 100 years 
#tr.en: and, following his upbringing, he lasted for another 100 years. 
#tr.en: However, he did not do any work. 
#tr.en: He became smaller and smaller, ...; 
#tr.en: his sheep died (?) in the sheepfold. 
#tr.en: In those days, because the water of Lagaš was held back, 
#tr.en: there was famine in Ĝirsu. 
#tr.en: Canals were not dug, 
#tr.en: the levees and ditches were not cleaned. 
#tr.en: The large arable tracts were not ..., 
#tr.en: there was no water to irrigate abundantly all the cultivated fields: 
#tr.en: the people relied on rain; 
#tr.en: Ašnan did not make dappled barley grow, 
#tr.en: furrows were not yet opened, 
#tr.en: they bore no yield; 
#tr.en: the high plain was not tilled, 
#tr.en: it bore no yield. 
#tr.en: None of the countries with numerous people for the gods 
#tr.en: emmer beer, liquor, ..., 
#tr.en: sweet liquor or ... 
#tr.en: did they libate. 
#tr.en: Large fields with the plough 
#tr.en: they did not till for them 
#tr.en: ...

#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ...

#tr.en: Its field... 
#tr.en: In order to dig canals, 
#tr.en: to clean the levees and ditches, 
#tr.en: to ... the large arable tracts, 
#tr.en: to ... all the cultivated fields, 
#tr.en: The pickaxe, the spade, the earth basket and the plough, 
#tr.en: which mean life for the Land, 
#tr.en: he established for the people. 
#tr.en: Then, to making barley sprout, 
#tr.en: he did turn his attention. 
#tr.en: He made the people stand before the maiden, 
#tr.en: Day and night, at the appointed times, 
#tr.en: they raised their heads.

#tr.en: En-me-barage-si, the king,

#tr.en: Then the Tummal fell into ruins for a fourth time. 
#tr.en: From the years of Amar-Suena 
#tr.en: of Amar-Suena 
#tr.en: until King Ibbi-Suen 
#tr.en: chose En-am-gal-ana by extispicy as the high priest of inanna of Uruk, 
#tr.en: Ninlil came regularly to the Tummal. 
#tr.en: Written according to the words of Lu-inanna the chief leatherworker of Enlil. 
#tr.en: Išbi-Erra, who looks after the E-kur, 
#tr.en: built the storehouse of Enlil. 
#tr.en: To ...... the sanctuary like a cargo ship; 
#tr.en: to ...... its great furnaces; 
#tr.en: to see that its canals ...... waters of joy for eternity, 
#tr.en: to see that the hoes till the arable tracts and that ...... the fields; 
#tr.en: to turn the house of Kiš, which was like a haunted town, into a living settlement again, 
#tr.en: its king, shepherd Ur-Zababa, 
#tr.en: rose like Utu over the house of Kiš. 
#tr.en: However, to alter his term of reigning and to remove the prosperity of the palace 
#tr.en: An and Enlil authoritatively (?) decided (?) by their holy command. 
#tr.en: Then Sargon - his city was the city of ......, 
#tr.en: his father was La’ibum, his mother ...... 
#tr.en: Sargon ...... with happy heart. 
#tr.en: Since he was born ... 
#tr.en: One day, after the evening had arrived, 
#tr.en: and Sargon had brought the regular deliveries to the palace, 
#tr.en: He Ur-Zababa was sleeping (and dreaming) in the holy bed-chamber, his holy residence. 
#tr.en: He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone. 
#tr.en: After Sargon had received the regular deliveries for the palace, 
#tr.en: Ur-Zababa appointed him cupbearer, putting him in charge of the drinks cupboard. 
#tr.en: Holy inanna did not cease to stand by him. 
#tr.en: After five or 10 days had passed, 
#tr.en: King Ur-Zababa ...... and became frightened in his residence. 
#tr.en: Like a lion he urinated, sprinkling his legs, and the urine contained blood and pus. 
#tr.en: He was troubled, he was disturbed like a fish living in brackish water. 
#tr.en: It was then that the cupbearer of Ezina's wine-house, 
#tr.en: Sargon, lay down not to sleep, but lay down to dream. 
#tr.en: In the dream, holy inanna drowned Ur-Zababa in a river of blood. 
#tr.en: The sleeping Sargon groaned and gnawed the ground. 
#tr.en: When King Ur-Zababa heard about this groaning, 
#tr.en: he was brought into the king's holy presence, 
#tr.en: Sargon was brought into the presence of Ur-Zababa (who said:) 
#tr.en: "Cupbearer, was a dream revealed to you in the night?" 
#tr.en: Sargon answered his king: 
#tr.en: My king, this is my dream, which I will tell you about: 
#tr.en: There was a young woman who was as high as the heavens and as broad as the earth. 
#tr.en: She was firmly set as the base of a wall. 
#tr.en: For me, she drowned you in a great river, a river of blood." 
#tr.en: Ur-Zababa chewed his lips, he became seriously afraid. 
#tr.en: He spoke to ......, his chancellor: 
#tr.en: "My royal sister, holy inanna, 
#tr.en: is going to change (?) my finger into a ...... of blood; 
#tr.en: she will drown Sargon, the cupbearer, in the great river. 
#tr.en: Beliš-tikal, chief smith, man of my choosing, who can write tablets, 
#tr.en: I will give you orders, let my orders be carried out! 
#tr.en: Let my advice be followed! 
#tr.en: Now then, when the cupbearer has delivered my bronze hand-mirror (?) to you 
#tr.en: in the E-sikil, the fated house, throw them (the mirror and Sargon) into the mould like statues." 
#tr.en: Beliš-tikal heeded his king's words 
#tr.en: and prepared the moulds in the E-sikil, the fated house. 
#tr.en: The king spoke to Sargon: 
#tr.en: "Go and deliver my bronze hand-mirror (?) to the chief smith!" 
#tr.en: Sargon left the palace of Ur-Zababa. 
#tr.en: Holy inanna, however, did not cease to stand at his right hand side, 
#tr.en: and before he had come within five or 10 ninda of the E-sikil, the fated house, 
#tr.en: holy inanna turned around toward him and blocked his way, (saying:) 
#tr.en: "The E-sikil is a holy house! No one polluted with blood should enter it!" 
#tr.en: Thus he met the chief smith of the king only at the gate of the fated house. 
#tr.en: After he delivered the king's bronze hand-mirror (?) to the chief smith, 
#tr.en: Beliš-tikal, the chief smith, ...... and threw it into the mould like statues. 
#tr.en: After five or 10 days had passed, Sargon 
#tr.en: came into the presence of Ur-Zababa, his king; 
#tr.en: he came into the palace, firmly founded like a great mountain. 
#tr.en: King Ur-Zababa ...... and became frightened in his residence. 
#tr.en: He realised what was it about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone. 
#tr.en: Ur-Zababa became frightened in the bed-chamber, his holy residence. 
#tr.en: He realised what was it about, but did not put into words, did not discuss it with anyone. 
#tr.en: In those days, although writing words on tablets existed, putting tablets into envelopes did not yet exist. 
#tr.en: King Ur-Zababa despatched Sargon, the creature of the gods, 
#tr.en: with a message written on clay, which was about murdering Sargon 
#tr.en: to Lugal-zage-si in Uruk. 
#tr.en: With the wife of Lugal-zage-si ... 
#tr.en: She gave(?) her feminity as a shelter ... 
#tr.en: Lugal-zage-si did not ... the envoy. 
#tr.en: "Come! He directed his steps to brick-built E-ana!" 
#tr.en: Lugal-zage-si did not grasp it, he did not talk to the envoy. 
#tr.en: But as soon as he did talk to the envoy ... 
#tr.en: "Alas!" and sat in the dust. 
#tr.en: Lugal-zage-si replied to the envoy: 
#tr.en: "Envoy, Sargon does not yield." 
#tr.en: After he has submitted,Sargon ... Lugal-zage-si ... 
#tr.en: Sargon ... Lugal-zage-si ... 
#tr.en: Why .... Sargon ....? 
#tr.en: After Enlil’s frown 
#tr.en: had slain Kiš as if it were the Bull of Heaven, 
#tr.en: had slaughtered the house of the land of Uruk in the dust as if it were a mighty bull, 
#tr.en: Then, to Sargon, king of Agade, 
#tr.en: from the south as far as the highlands did Enlil 
#tr.en: give the rulership and kingship. 
#tr.en: at that time, holy inanna established the sanctuary of Agade 
#tr.en: as her celebrated woman’s domain; 
#tr.en: she set up her throne in Ulmaš. 
#tr.en: Like a young man building a house for the first time, 
#tr.en: like a girl establishing a woman’s domain, 
#tr.en: So that the warehouses would be provisioned; 
#tr.en: that dwellings would be founded in the city; 
#tr.en: that its people would eat splendid food; 
#tr.en: that its people would drink splendid beverages; 
#tr.en: that those bathed for holidays would rejoice in the courtyards; 
#tr.en: that the people would throng the places of celebration; 
#tr.en: that acquaintances would dine together; 
#tr.en: that foreigners would cruise about like unusual birds in the sky; 
#tr.en: that even Marhaši would be re-entered on the tribute rolls; 
#tr.en: that monkeys, mighty elephants, water buffalo, exotic animals 
#tr.en: would jostle each other in the public squares. 
#tr.en: as well as thoroughbred dogs, lions, {mountain ibexes}, and alum sheep with long wool 
#tr.en: holy inanna did not sleep as she ensured all of this. 
#tr.en: She then filled Agade’s stores for emmer wheat with gold, 
#tr.en: she filled its stores for white emmer wheat with silver; 
#tr.en: she delivered copper, tin, and blocks of lapis lazuli to its granaries 
#tr.en: and sealed its silos from outside. 
#tr.en: She endowed its old women with the gift of giving counsel, 
#tr.en: she endowed its old men with the gift of eloquence. 
#tr.en: She endowed its young women with the gift of entertaining, 
#tr.en: she endowed its young men with martial might, 
#tr.en: she endowed its little ones with joy 
#tr.en: The nursemaids who cared for the general’s children 
#tr.en: played the drumsticks. 
#tr.en: Inside the city tigi drums sounded; outside it, flutes and zamzam instruments. 
#tr.en: Its harbour where ships moored was full of joy. 
#tr.en: All foreign lands rested contentedly, 
#tr.en: and their people experienced happiness. 
#tr.en: Its king, the shepherd Naram-Suen, 
#tr.en: rose as the daylight on the holy throne of Agade. 
#tr.en: Its city wall, like a mountain, reached the heavens. 
#tr.en: Its city-gates were like the Tigris {going to} the sea 
#tr.en: when Inanna opened its portals 
#tr.en: and made Sumer bring its own possessions upstream by boats. 
#tr.en: The highland Martu, people ignorant of agriculture, 
#tr.en: brought spirited cattle and kids for her. 
#tr.en: The Meluḫans, the people of the black land, 
#tr.en: brought exotic wares up to her. 
#tr.en: Elam and Subir loaded themselves with goods for her as if they were packasses. 
#tr.en: All the governors, the temple administrators, 
#tr.en: and the accountants of the Gu-edina 
#tr.en: regularly supplied the monthly and New Year offerings. 
#tr.en: What a weariness all these caused at Agade’s city gates! 
#tr.en: Holy inanna could hardly receive all these offerings. 
#tr.en: As if she were a citizen there, she could not restrain (?) the desire (?) to prepare the ground for a temple. 
#tr.en: But the statement coming from the E-kur was disquieting. 
#tr.en: Because of Enlil (?) all Agade was reduced (?) to trembling, 
#tr.en: and terror befell inanna in Ulmaš. 
#tr.en: She left the city, returning to her home. 
#tr.en: Like someone abandoning the young women of her woman’s domain, 
#tr.en: Holy inanna abandoned the sanctuary of Agade 
#tr.en: Like a warrior hurrying to arms, 
#tr.en: she removed the gift of battle and fight from the city 
#tr.en: and handed them over to the enemy. 
#tr.en: Not even five or 10 days had passed 
#tr.en: and the jewels of rulership, the royal crown, 
#tr.en: the emblem and the royal throne bestowed on Agade, 
#tr.en: did Ninurta bring back into his E-šu-me-ša. 
#tr.en: Utu took away the eloquence of the city. 
#tr.en: Enki took away its wisdom. 
#tr.en: Its fearsomeness that reaches heaven, 
#tr.en: An took up into the midst of heaven. 
#tr.en: Its well-anchored holy mooring pole 
#tr.en: Enki tore out from the abzu. 
#tr.en: inanna took away its weapons. 
#tr.en: The life of Agade’s sanctuary was brought to an end as if it had been only the life of a tiny carp in the deep waters, 
#tr.en: and all the cities were watching it. 
#tr.en: Like a mighty elephant, it bent its neck to the ground 
#tr.en: while they all raised their horns like mighty bulls. 
#tr.en: Like a dying dragon, it dragged its head on the earth 
#tr.en: and they jointly deprived it of honour as in a battle. 
#tr.en: Enlil would not let the kingdom of Agade occupy a pleasant, lasting residence, 
#tr.en: that he would make its future altogether unfavourable, 
#tr.en: that he would make its temples shake and would scatter its treasures - 
#tr.en: - Naram-Suen saw that in a nocturnal vision. 
#tr.en: He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. 
#tr.en: ... temples shake ... 
#tr.en: ... perform (?) extispicy regarding (?) his temple ... 
#tr.en: Because of the E-kur, he put on mourning clothes, 
#tr.en: covered his chariot with a reed mat, 
#tr.en: tore the reed canopy off his ceremonial barge, 
#tr.en: and gave away his royal paraphernalia. 
#tr.en: Naram-Suen persisted for seven years! 
#tr.en: Who has ever seen a king burying his head in his hands for seven years? 
#tr.en: He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. 
#tr.en: Then he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, 
#tr.en: but the omen had nothing to say about the building of the temple. 
#tr.en: For a second time he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, 
#tr.en: but the omen again had nothing to say about the building of the temple. 
#tr.en: In order to change what had been inflicted (?) upon him, 
#tr.en: he tried to to alter Enlil’s pronouncement. 
#tr.en: Because his subjects were dispersed, 
#tr.en: he now began a mobilization of his troops. 
#tr.en: Like a wrestler who is about to enter the great courtyard, 
#tr.en: he ...... his hands towards (?) the E-kur. 
#tr.en: Like an athlete bent to start a contest, 
#tr.en: he treated the giguna as if it were worth only thirty shekels. 
#tr.en: Like a robber plundering the city, 
#tr.en: he set tall ladders against the temple. 
#tr.en: To demolish E-kur as if it were a huge ship, 
#tr.en: to break up its soil like the soil of mountains where precious metals are mined, 
#tr.en: to splinter it like the lapis lazuli mountain, 
#tr.en: to prostrate it like a city inundated by Iškur; 
#tr.en: alhough the temple was not the Mountains of Cedar-felling, 
#tr.en: he had large axes cast, 
#tr.en: he had double-edged agasilig axes sharpened to be used against it. 
#tr.en: He set spades against its roots 
#tr.en: and it sank as low as the foundation of the Land. 
#tr.en: He put axes against its top, 
#tr.en: and the temple, like a dead soldier, bowed its neck before him, 
#tr.en: and all the foreign lands bowed their necks before him. 
#tr.en: He ripped out its drain pipes, 
#tr.en: and all the rain went back to the heavens. 
#tr.en: He tore off its upper lintel and the Land was deprived of its ornament. 
#tr.en: From its Gate from which Grain is never Diverted, he diverted grain, 
#tr.en: and the Land was deprived of grain. 
#tr.en: He struck the Gate of Well-Being with the pickaxe, 
#tr.en: and well-being was subverted in all the foreign lands. 
#tr.en: As if they were for great tracts of land with wide carp-filled waters, 
#tr.en: he cast large spades to be used against the E-kur. 
#tr.en: The people could see the bedchamber, its room which knows no daylight. 
#tr.en: They could look into the holy treasure chest of the gods. 
#tr.en: its laḫama deities of the great pilasters standing at the temple, 
#tr.en: though they had committed no sacrilege, 
#tr.en: were thrown into the fire by Naram-Suen. 
#tr.en: The cedar, cypress, juniper and boxwood, 
#tr.en: the woods of its giguna, were ... by him. 
#tr.en: He put its gold in containers 
#tr.en: and put its silver in leather bags. 
#tr.en: He filled the docks with its copper, as if it were a huge transport of grain. 
#tr.en: The silversmiths were re-shaping its silver, 
#tr.en: jewellers were re-shaping its precious stones, 
#tr.en: smiths were beating its copper. 
#tr.en: Though they were not the goods of a plundered city, 
#tr.en: large ships were moored at the temple, 
#tr.en: large ships were moored at Enlil’s temple 
#tr.en: and its possessions were taken away from the city. 
#tr.en: With the possessions being taken away from the city, 
#tr.en: good sense left Agade. 
#tr.en: As the ships moved away from the docks, Agade’s intelligence was removed. 
#tr.en: The roaring storm that subjugates the entire land, 
#tr.en: the rising deluge that cannot be confronted, 
#tr.en: Enlil was considering what should be destroyed in return for the wrecking of his beloved E-kur. 
#tr.en: He lifted his gaze towards the Gubin mountains, 
#tr.en: and made all the inhabitants of the broad mountain ranges descend (?). 
#tr.en: Those who do not resemble other people, who are not reckoned as part of the Land, 
#tr.en: the Gutians, an unbridled people, 
#tr.en: with human intelligence but canine instincts and monkeys’ features - 
#tr.en: Enlil brought them out of the mountains. 
#tr.en: Like small birds they swooped on the ground in great flocks. 
#tr.en: Because of Enlil, they stretched their arms out across the plain like a net for animals. 
#tr.en: Nothing escaped their clutches, 
#tr.en: no one left their grasp. 
#tr.en: Messengers no longer travelled the highways, 
#tr.en: the courier’s boat no longer passed along the rivers. 
#tr.en: The Gutians drove the trusty (?) goats of Enlil out of their folds and compelled their herdsmen to follow them, they drove the cows out of their pens and compelled their cowherds to follow them. 
#tr.en: they drove the cows out of their pens and compelled their cowherds to follow them. 
#tr.en: Prisoners manned the watch. 
#tr.en: Brigands occupied the highways. 
#tr.en: The doors of the city gates of the Land lay dislodged in mud, 
#tr.en: and all the foreign lands uttered bitter cries from the walls of their cities. 
#tr.en: They established gardens for themselves within the cities, and not as usual on the wide plain outside. 
#tr.en: As if it had been before the time when cities were built and founded, 
#tr.en: the large arable tracts yielded no grain, 
#tr.en: the inundated tracts yielded no fish, 
#tr.en: the irrigated orchards yielded no syrup or wine, 
#tr.en: the thick clouds (?) did not rain, the mašgurum plant did not grow. 
#tr.en: In those days, oil for one shekel was only half a litre, 
#tr.en: grain for one shekel was only half a litre, 
#tr.en: wool for one shekel was only one mina, 
#tr.en: fish for one shekel filled only one ban measure 
#tr.en: these sold at such prices in the markets of the cities! 
#tr.en: Those who lay down on the roof, died on the roof; 
#tr.en: those who lay down in the house were not buried. 
#tr.en: People were flailing at themselves from hunger. 
#tr.en: By the Ki-ur, Enlil’s great place, 
#tr.en: dogs were packed together in the silent streets; 
#tr.en: if two men walked there they would be devoured by them, 
#tr.en: and if three men walked there they would be devoured by them. 
#tr.en: Noses were punched (?), heads were smashed (?), 
#tr.en: noses (?) were piled up, heads were sown like seeds. 
#tr.en: Honest people were confounded with traitors, 
#tr.en: heroes lay dead on top of heroes, 
#tr.en: the blood of traitors ran upon the blood of honest men. 
#tr.en: At that time, Enlil rebuilt his great sanctuaries 
#tr.en: into small reed (?) sanctuaries 
#tr.en: and from east to west he reduced their storehouses. 
#tr.en: The old women who survived those days, 
#tr.en: the old men who survived those days, 
#tr.en: and the chief lamentation singer who survived those years 
#tr.en: for seven days and seven nights 
#tr.en: set up seven balaĝ drums, 
#tr.en: ub, meze, and lilis drums made them resound to Enlil like Iškur. 
#tr.en: The old women did not restrain the cry “Alas for my city!” 
#tr.en: The old men did not restrain the cry “Alas for its people!” 
#tr.en: The lamentation singer did not restrain the cry “Alas for the E-kur!” 
#tr.en: Its young women did not restrain from tearing their hair. 
#tr.en: Its young men did not restrain from sharpening their knives. 
#tr.en: Their laments were as if Enlil’s ancestors 
#tr.en: were performing a lament in the awe-inspiring Holy Mound by the holy knees of Enlil. 
#tr.en: Because of this, Enlil entered his holy bedchamber and lay down fasting. 
#tr.en: At that time, Suen, Enki, inanna, Ninurta, Iškur, Utu, Nuska, and Nisaba, the great gods 
#tr.en: cooled Enlil’s heart with cool water and prayed to him: 
#tr.en: “Enlil, may the city that destroyed your city be treated as your city has been treated! 
#tr.en: May the one that defiled your giguna be treated as Nibru! 
#tr.en: In this city, may heads fill the wells! 
#tr.en: May no one find his acquaintances there, 
#tr.en: may brother not recognise brother! 
#tr.en: May its young woman be cruelly killed in her woman’s domain, 
#tr.en: may its old man cry in distress for his slain wife! 
#tr.en: May its pigeons moan on their window ledges, 
#tr.en: may its small birds be smitten in their nooks, 
#tr.en: may it live in constant anxiety like a timid pigeon!” 
#tr.en: Again, Suen, Enki, inanna, Ninurta, Iškur, Utu, Nuska and Nisaba, all the gods whosoever, 
#tr.en: turned their attention to the city, 
#tr.en: and cursed Agade severely: 
#tr.en: “City, you pounced on E-kur: it is as if you had pounced on Enlil! 
#tr.en: Agade, you pounced on E-kur: it is as if you had pounced on Enlil! 
#tr.en: May your holy walls, to their highest point, resound with mourning! 
#tr.en: May your giguna be reduced to a pile of dust! 
#tr.en: May your pilasters with the standing lahama deities 
#tr.en: fall to the ground like tall young men drunk on wine! 
#tr.en: May your clay be returned to its abzu, 
#tr.en: may it be clay cursed by Enki! 
#tr.en: May your grain be returned to its furrow, 
#tr.en: may it be grain cursed by Ezina! 
#tr.en: May your timber be returned to its forest, 
#tr.en: may it be timber cursed by Ninilduma! 
#tr.en: May the cattle slaughterer slaughter his wife, 
#tr.en: may your sheep butcher butcher his child! 
#tr.en: May water wash away your pauper as he is looking for ...! 
#tr.en: May your prostitute hang herself at the entrance to her brothel! 
#tr.en: May your pregnant (?) priestesses and cult prostitutes abort (?) their children! 
#tr.en: May your gold be bought for the price of silver, 
#tr.en: may your silver be bought for the price of pyrite (?), 
#tr.en: and may your copper be bought for the price of lead!” 
#tr.en: “Agade, may your strong man be deprived of his strength, 
#tr.en: so that he will be unable to lift his sack of provisions and ..., 
#tr.en: and will not have the joy of controlling your superior asses; may he lie idle all day! 
#tr.en: May this make the city die of hunger! 
#tr.en: May your citizens, who used to eat fine food, lie hungry, 
#tr.en: may your ... man 
#tr.en: eat the coating on his roof, 
#tr.en: The leather hinges on the main door of his father’s house, 
#tr.en: may he chew their leather hinges! 
#tr.en: May depression descend upon your palace, built for joy! 
#tr.en: May the evils of the desert, the silent place, howl continuously!” 
#tr.en: “Your uzga precinct, established for purification ceremonies, 
#tr.en: may foxes that frequent its ruin mounds and brush it with their tails 
#tr.en: Your gateways, established for the Land, 
#tr.en: May the ukuku, the bird of depression, make its nest in them! 
#tr.en: In your city that could not sleep because of the tigi drums, 
#tr.en: that could not rest from its joy, 
#tr.en: may the bulls of Nanna that fill the pens 
#tr.en: bellow like those who wander in the desert, the silent place! 
#tr.en: May the grass grow long on your canal-bank tow-paths, 
#tr.en: may the grass of mourning grow on your highways laid for waggons! 
#tr.en: Moreover, on your tow-paths built up with canal sediment, 
#tr.en: may ... wild rams (?) and alert snakes of the mountains allow no one to pass! 
#tr.en: In your plains where fine grass grows, may the reed of lamentation grow! 
#tr.en: Agade, may brackish water flow, where fresh water flowed for you! 
#tr.en: If someone decides, “I will dwell in this city!,” may he not enjoy the pleasures of a dwelling place! 
#tr.en: If someone decides, “I will rest in Agade!,” may he not enjoy the pleasures of a resting place!” 
#tr.en: And before Utu on that very day, so it was! 
#tr.en: On its canal bank tow-paths, the grass grew long. 
#tr.en: On its highways laid for waggons, the grass of mourning grew. 
#tr.en: Moreover, on its tow-paths built up with canal sediment, 
#tr.en: wild rams (?) and alert snakes of the mountains allowed no one to pass. 
#tr.en: On its plains, where fine grass grew, now the reeds of lamentation grew. 
#tr.en: Agade’s flowing fresh water flowed as brackish water. 
#tr.en: When someone decided, “I will dwell in that city!,” he could not enjoy the pleasures of a dwelling place. 
#tr.en: When someone decided, “I will rest in Agade!,” 
#tr.en: For the destruction of Agade, Inanna be praised! 
#tr.en: Enki took away its wisdom. 
#tr.en: Its fearsomeness that reaches heaven, 
#tr.en: An took it up into the midst of heaven. 
#tr.en: Its well-anchored holy mooring pole, 
#tr.en: Enki tore it out from the abzu 
#tr.en: That he would make its future altogether unfavourable; 
#tr.en: that he would make its temples shake and would scatter its treasures - 
#tr.en: - Naram-Suen saw that in a nocturnal vision. 
#tr.en: as if he were to change what had been inflicted (?) upon him. 
#tr.en: His subjects were dispersed, 
#tr.en: so he began a mobilization of his troops. 
#tr.en: Like a wrestler who is about to enter the great courtyard, 
#tr.en: he ... his hands towards (?) the E-kur. 
#tr.en: Like an athlete bent to start a contest, 
#tr.en: he treated the giguna as if it were worth only thirty shekels. 
#tr.en: Like a robber plundering the city, 
#tr.en: he set tall ladders against the temple. 
#tr.en: Though the temple was not a mountain of cedars, 
#tr.en: he had large axes cast to be used against it. 
#tr.en: He had double-edged agasilig axes sharpened to be used against it. 
#tr.en: As if they were for great tracts of land with huge carp-filled waters, 
#tr.en: he cast large spades. 
#tr.en: He put spades against its roots. 
#tr.en: and the Land was deprived of grain. 
#tr.en: He struck the Gate of Well-Being with the pickaxe 
#tr.en: and well-being was destroyed in all the foreign lands. 
#tr.en: Noses were punched, heads were smashed (?), 
#tr.en: noses (?) were piled up, heads were sown like seeds. 
#tr.en: Heroes lay (?) dead on top of heroes, 
#tr.en: the blood of traitors ran (?) upon honest men. 
#tr.en: Enlil rebuilt his great sanctuaries 
#tr.en: into small reed (?) sanctuaries 
#tr.en: and from the south to the uplands ... 
#tr.en: (Property of) the palace of Assurnasirpal, king of Assyria, 
#tr.en: son of Tukulti-Ninurta, king of everything, king of Assyria, 
#tr.en: son of Adad-narari, king of everything, king 
#tr.en: of Assyria: facing (brick) 
#tr.en: of the well of the temple of the divine Kidmuru. 
#tr.en: 15 male laborers for 5 workdays,
#tr.en: at the builder-house stationed, 
#tr.en: at the ...-house stationed, 
#tr.en: foreman: Ukkene, 
#tr.en: via Lu-girizal, 
#tr.en: under seal of Biduga; 
#tr.en: year: “Kimaš was destroyed.” 
#tr.en: 120 less 1 male laborer workdays,
#tr.en: in the field Ukunutigula reed ... pulled; 
#tr.en: under seal of Ur-amma; 
#tr.en: month: “Flight,” 
#tr.en: year: “Šašrum was destroyed.” 
#tr.en: Ur-Lisi, 
#tr.en: governor 
#tr.en: of Umma: 
#tr.en: Ur-amma, 
#tr.en: scribe, 
#tr.en: son of Nasilim, 
#tr.en: is your servant. 
#tr.en: For Baba, 
#tr.en: his lady, 
#tr.en: did ...-Rim-Sin, 
#tr.en: son of ..., foreman of traders, 
#tr.en: dedicate this. 
#tr.en: He has abandoned his cow-pen and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold. 
#tr.en: The wild bull has abandoned his cow-pen and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold. 
#tr.en: The lord of all the lands has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold. 
#tr.en: Enlil has abandoned the shrine Nibru and has let the breezes haunt his sheepfold. 
#tr.en: His wife Ninlil has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold. 
#tr.en: Ninlil has abandoned that house, the Ki-ur, and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold. 
#tr.en: The queen of Keš has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold. 
#tr.en: Ninmaḫ has abandoned that house Keš and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold. 
#tr.en: She of Isin has abandoned it and has let the breezes haunt her sheepfold.
