#tr.en: 3 male laborers for 2 days, 
#tr.en: to Nippur 
#tr.en: ...-straw carried; 
#tr.en: foreman: ...-gala; 
#tr.en: under seal of Lukalla; 
#tr.en: year: “Šu-Suen is king.”
#tr.en: Lukalla, 
#tr.en: scribe, 
#tr.en: son of Ur-E’e. 
#tr.en: 1 female kid, grain-fed, fine, second (quality), 
#tr.en: 2 sheep, 
#tr.en: 1 nanny, 
#tr.en: 4 lambs, 
#tr.en: from Šu-Mama 
#tr.en: did Šulgi-irimu 
#tr.en: receive; 
#tr.en: month: “Piglet-feast,” 
#tr.en: year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed.” 
#tr.en: (total:) 8. 
#tr.en: After the cattle pen had been built for the foremost divine powers - 
#tr.en: - how did it become a haunted place? When will it be restored? 
#tr.en: Where once the brick of fate had been laid - 
#tr.en: - who scattered its divine powers? The lamentation is reprised: 
#tr.en: how did the storeroom of Nibru, the shrine Dur-an-ki, 
#tr.en: become a haunted place? When will it be restored? 
#tr.en: After Ki-ur, the great place, had been built, 
#tr.en: after the brickwork of E-kur had been built 
#tr.en: after Ubšu-ukkena had been built, 
#tr.en: after the shrine Egal-maḫ had been built - 
#tr.en: - how did they become haunted? When will they be restored? 
#tr.en: How did the true city become empty? 
#tr.en: Its precious designs have been defiled! 
#tr.en: How were the city's festivals neglected? 
#tr.en: Its magnificent rites have been thrown into disorder! 
#tr.en: In the heart of Nibru, where the divine powers were allotted 
#tr.en: and the black-headed people prolificly multiplied, 
#tr.en: the city's heart no longer revealed any sign of intelligence - 
#tr.en: - there where the Anuna used to give advice! 
#tr.en: In Ubšu-ukkena, the place for making great judgments, 
#tr.en: they no longer impart decisions or justice! 
#tr.en: Where its gods had established their dwellings, 
#tr.en: where their daily rations were offered, their daises erected, 
#tr.en: where the sacred royal offering (?) and the evening meal in their great banquet hall 
#tr.en: were destined for the pouring out of choice beer and syrup - 
#tr.en: - Nibru, the city where, in its spreading shade, 
#tr.en: the black-headed people used to cool themselves - 
#tr.en: - in their dwellings Enlil fell upon them as if they were criminals. 
#tr.en: It was he who sent them scattering, like a scattered herd of cattle. 
#tr.en: The inner city, whose bitter tears were overwhelming, 
#tr.en: How long until its lady, the goddess Ninlil, would ask after it? 
#tr.en: That great temple whose bustle of activity was famous, 
#tr.en: as though it were empty wasteland, no one enters it. 
#tr.en: As for all the great rulers who increased the wealth of the city of Nibru - why did they disappear? 
#tr.en: Where the black-headed people ate rich grass like sheep, 
#tr.en: For how long would Enlil neglect that Land? ears, lamentation, depression and despair! 
#tr.en: How long would his spirit burn and his heart not be placated? 
#tr.en: Why were those who once played the šem and ala drums 
#tr.en: spending their time in bitter lamenting? 
#tr.en: Why were the lamenters sitting in its brick buildings? 
#tr.en: They were bewailing the hardship which beset them. 
#tr.en: The men whose wives had fallen, whose children had fallen, 
#tr.en: were singing “Oh our destroyed city!.” 
#tr.en: Their city gone, their homes abandoned - 
#tr.en: - as those who were singing for the brick buildings of the good city, 
#tr.en: as the lamenters of wailing, 
#tr.en: like the foster-children of an ecstatic no longer knowing their own intelligence, 
#tr.en: the people were smitten, their minds thrown into disorder. 
#tr.en: The true temple wails bitterly. 
#tr.en: 1st kirugu 
#tr.en: ...built the temple, Ninlil... 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: The true temple gave you only tears and lamentation - 
#tr.en: - it sings a bitter song of the proper cleansing-rites that are forgotten! 
#tr.en: The brickwork of E-kur gave you only tears and lamentation - 
#tr.en: - it sings a bitter song of the proper cleansing-rites that are forgotten! 
#tr.en: It weeps bitter tears over the splendid rites and most precious plans which are desecrated - 
#tr.en: - its most sacred food rations neglected and ... into funeral offerings, it cries “Alas!.” 
#tr.en: The temple despairs of its divine powers, utterly cleansed, pure, hallowed, which are now defiled! 
#tr.en: The true temple, which it is bitter to enter on one's own, 
#tr.en: passes the time renewing its tears. 
#tr.en: Because the sealings of the abundant materials stored in the temple have been broken open, they have placed the loads on the ground. 
#tr.en: Because the property in its well-tended storehouses has been sent back, it says “What will they weigh out for me now?"; 
#tr.en: because the enemies who do not know good from evil have cut off all good things, it sings a bitter dirge; 
#tr.en: because they have finished off its populace there like animals, it cries “Oh my Land!.” 
#tr.en: Because they have piled up the young women, young men and their little children like heaps of grain, it cries “Woe!” for them. 
#tr.en: Because they have splashed their blood on the ground like a rain-storm, there is no restraint to its crying. 
#tr.en: The temple, like a cow whose calf is cut off, groans bitterly to itself; 
#tr.en: it is grief-stricken, and the sweet-voiced lamenters, like nursemaids singing a lullaby, respond tearfully with its name. 
#tr.en: In anguish they bewail the fact that the city's lord has smashed heads there, 
#tr.en: that he has looked away from it and toward a foreign land instead. 
#tr.en: The true temple of all the countries, which had come before him - 
#tr.en: the black-headed people, who had taken a true path, 
#tr.en: what have they done regarding what have they forsaken, 
#tr.en: that their lord has become enraged with them and walks in anger? 
#tr.en: 2nd kirugu 
#tr.en: It voices bitter cries because he has removed the great divine powers from within it. 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal. 
#tr.en: The city's lord who became angry with it, 
#tr.en: How long will he not turn to it, not say “Alas!” for it? 
#tr.en: Why did he cut off the road to its brickwork? 
#tr.en: He made the noisy pigeons fly away from their windows. 
#tr.en: Why did he transform the appearance of the temple which knew voices, where they used to while away the days in sweet playing of tigi drums in the brick buildings? 
#tr.en: The temple, once a place to offer salutations in humility, 
#tr.en: is now as deathly silent as a temple which no one reveres! 
#tr.en: As though its purification priest's equipment were not utterly sacred, 
#tr.en: as though its cleansing-rites did not bring calm in all countries, 
#tr.en: he has abandoned it, turned his breast away from it, 
#tr.en: among dejection and lamentation he has made it a sacrilege. 
#tr.en: After its fate, how long till his face would be streaked with teardrops? 
#tr.en: He rejected it thus as though it were a blasphemy! 
#tr.en: Why has joy left its brickwork? 
#tr.en: Night and day he has filled its heart with tears! 
#tr.en: Even now, he has made it foreign and a sacrilege! 
#tr.en: Its lord, who has despoiled it like an evil wind, 
#tr.en: has destroyed that city and its temples! 
#tr.en: He has ripped out their foundations, struck them with the adze, 
#tr.en: killed wives and their children within it, 
#tr.en: he has turned that city into a deserted city - 
#tr.en: - when would he restore its ancient property? 
#tr.en: Its possessions have been carried off by the wind! 
#tr.en: Enlil turned the city which used to be there into a city no longer! 
#tr.en: He made its mind wander! 
#tr.en: He threw its intelligence into disorder and made it haunted! 
#tr.en: He took away its food and its water! 
#tr.en: He brought to an end its days of familiarity with milk and with beer! 
#tr.en: The temple which he has made a sacrilege utters bitter lamentations; 
#tr.en: he has made its eyes blurred with tears. 
#tr.en: The lamenters who perform the dirges 
#tr.en: respond to it sorrowfully. 
#tr.en: The city's lord who has removed its divine powers - 
#tr.en: no one touches his arm, no one intercedes! 
#tr.en: 3rd kirugu 
#tr.en: How did Enlil make all his greatest divine powers fly away! 
#tr.en: No one ever touches his arm! No one ever intercedes! 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: To my dirge singer of bitter fates 
#tr.en: I am going down and I shall weep tearfully to him. 
#tr.en: Even now the lamenters who are expert in song 
#tr.en: make ululating wails over me! 
#tr.en: Now my people who are overcome by hardship 
#tr.en: voice laments for me one by one! 
#tr.en: Even now the places of refuge of my people whose hearts are burning in dark distress 
#tr.en: have been made known to me! 
#tr.en: My people whose hearts have been broken on the bitter way 
#tr.en: perform the lullabies of my young ones for me in tears! 
#tr.en: The well-built houses, ladies' dwellings, 
#tr.en: were falsely founded, and they have been eroded by the winds! 
#tr.en: Of how the foe has finished off my Land 
#tr.en: They are making a lament! 
#tr.en: They are addressing the cries of my heart, overwhelmed with bitterness, in order to soothe it! 
#tr.en: They are beginning their laments about my lord! 
#tr.en: He will have mercy and compassion on me - 
#tr.en: Enlil, father of the black-headed people, 
#tr.en: he who will give the order to restore me! 
#tr.en: 4th kirugu 
#tr.en: My heart is dark, I am destroyed, I am in chaos, I have been devastated! 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: In the foremost brick buildings they sing that your fate is bitter! 
#tr.en: Even now, to Enlil who will accept your tears for you, 
#tr.en: weeping bitter tears of your own accord, 
#tr.en: speak supplications to your lord himself concerning what he did to you, concerning that fate! 
#tr.en: “My lord, how long? Look upon me with favour, my lord!" 
#tr.en: Say “Why ...?” 
#tr.en: Say “May your heart be soothed for me - overturn this sacrilege for your own good! The day is ...!" 
#tr.en: Say “Re-enter for me your dwelling in my darkened shrines!" 
#tr.en: Say “Like a bright, cleansed, sacred day, give ... for your own good!" 
#tr.en: Say “...!" 
#tr.en: Say “Your misfortunes ... will rebuild it!" 
#tr.en: Perhaps by this means I can make him have compassion and mercy for you. 
#tr.en: Depression has weakened your heart, but I am the one who has established good cheer for you. 
#tr.en: He will fix it forever as your lot that you shall lift your head high, 
#tr.en: he will make good again the hostilities he is directing against you. 
#tr.en: 5th kirugu 
#tr.en: In the city which does not know freedom he struck them down thus. 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: Even now your lord has smitten the enemy fury for you! 
#tr.en: He has had mercy on you and decreed your fate! 
#tr.en: He has said “Enough", so that he has removed lamentation from your brick buildings! 
#tr.en: In good mood and with a joyful heart he has entered in there again for you! 
#tr.en: Ninurta, the mighty commissioner, has looked after things! 
#tr.en: He stood there before the hero, 
#tr.en: his provider Išme-Dagan, and issued the command to him to completely rebuild the E-kur, the most precious shrine! 
#tr.en: He has restored its ancient property! 
#tr.en: to restore its ziggurat temple, to make it shine like the day, 
#tr.en: to make fitting the dais upon its platform! 
#tr.en: He has put back in their place the rites which the enemy disordered and desecrated, 
#tr.en: along with the scattered divine powers! 
#tr.en: The cleansing-rites which the enemy had put a stop to, 
#tr.en: so that they should sanctify and purify again, 
#tr.en: he has given him his sacred unchangeable decision. 
#tr.en: He has told Išme-Dagan, his beloved shepherd, 
#tr.en: that faultless bulls and faultless bucks should be slaughtered! 
#tr.en: When decrees the fate of the sacred royal offering place (?), he will offer salutations 
#tr.en: and stand there daily in supplication and prayer. 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: Your bitter tears... 
#tr.en: 6th kirugu 
#tr.en: How long before you will rest at ease? 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: How long will the brickwork strain its eyes upwards in tears and lamentations? 
#tr.en: Even now your lord, the Great Mountain Enlil, supreme in the universe, 
#tr.en: has removed lamentation from your brick buildings and made favourable your humour! 
#tr.en: Now, city, your lord who has had compassion and mercy for you, 
#tr.en: Father Enlil, lord of all countries, who has commanded that you be restored, 
#tr.en: and the great mother Ninlil, who entreated him in prayer there, 
#tr.en: and the brickwork itself which said to him “Steady the trembling of Nibru!" 
#tr.en: and said to him “Rebuild my women's quarters for me! Re-establish my temples for me!” - 
#tr.en: - he who mulled things over so that he came to a decision about them, 
#tr.en: Enlil, who found agreeable his command of true words, 
#tr.en: who beneficently entered the true temple which had suffered destruction - 
#tr.en: - he himself is removing what he turned upon you in distress. 
#tr.en: Just as he silenced you, when he made joy enter again 
#tr.en: he decreed as your fate the sound of choice beer and syrup being poured out to overflowing. 
#tr.en: “Enough! It is time to stifle the lament” he said to you himself. 
#tr.en: Because you have been living in a state of neglect, Enlil who has decreed your fate 
#tr.en: has said “My city, you have placated my sacred heart towards you.” He has returned to you! 
#tr.en: “Nibru, you have placated my sacred heart towards you.” He has returned to you! 
#tr.en: True city, he has decreed your great fate and made your reign long! 
#tr.en: Nibru, he has decreed your great fate and made your reign long! 
#tr.en: Enlil himself has commanded Išme-Dagan that the E-kur should shine like the day! 
#tr.en: Steady sunlight shines into the Ki-ur; he has brought daylight in there again for you! 
#tr.en: Ninlil has decreed your fate in the Ĝagiššua! 
#tr.en: Enlil and Ninlil together founded daises in the E-kur! 
#tr.en: They dined there and enjoyed choice beer! 
#tr.en: They deliberated how to make the black-headed people secure in their dwellings! 
#tr.en: They have brought back to you the people who had been completely devastated! 
#tr.en: They have gathered back together the children whom they turned away from their mothers! 
#tr.en: The populace goes with you in their strongholds! 
#tr.en: Shrine Nibru, the Great Mountain Enlil has returned to you! 
#tr.en: 7th kirugu 
#tr.en: How you suffer! How depression exhausts you! 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: Even now, they command Išme-Dagan that Sumer and Akkad should be restored at your feet, 
#tr.en: that their scattered people should be returned to their nests! 
#tr.en: They have brought the news that the magnificent rites of Eridug would not be forgotten, 
#tr.en: its heart sending forth wisdom, so that good sense should be allotted! 
#tr.en: Adab, the city whose lady fashions living things, who promotes birthing, 
#tr.en: The Anuna, the lords who decree fates, order that it should be rebuilt, 
#tr.en: Ur founded in a pasture, its divine powers distinct from the rest, 
#tr.en: An and Enlil have advised that it should be restored, 
#tr.en: The prince of the city Larsam, the herald of the universe, the judge of the numerous people, 
#tr.en: They command him to secure its foundations, to follow the proper path! 
#tr.en: Uruk-Kulaba, the sacred city, the handiwork of the gods, 
#tr.en: They have taken a decision concerning it and restored it. 
#tr.en: from the region of zabala, the city where the mistress of heaven concentrated her forces, 
#tr.en: they have brought news of the removal of all foes and enemies. 
#tr.en: On Lagaš, the mooring-pole of heaven, and the shrine Ĝirsu, established long ago. 
#tr.en: An and Enlil have looked with their beneficent gaze 
#tr.en: From that temple in Umma, Šeg-kuršaga, which had been ill treated, 
#tr.en: they have removed the treacherous Tidnum. 
#tr.en: Kiš, at the edge of Sumer and Akkad, its dominion superlative, 
#tr.en: It is the great gods who have commanded that its foundations should be secured, 
#tr.en: Marda, the city in whose river water flows, in whose fields is fine grain - 
#tr.en: - the Anuna who took those things away from it returned them to it again! 
#tr.en: Isin, the provisioner of the Anuna, rising high since times of old - 
#tr.en: - An, Enlil, Enki and Ninmaḫ have made its reign long! 
#tr.en: By their command they have handed it over and expressed their approval! 
#tr.en: They have entrusted it to Ninurta, the champion, the strong hero! 
#tr.en: Ninisina, the exalted child of An, the incantation priest of the Land 
#tr.en: they have told to rest calmly in her sacred dwelling, Egal-maḫ! 
#tr.en: Damu, the chief barber of Nunamnir, healer of the living, 
#tr.en: they have told to make the foreign countries bow at the feet of his father and mother! 
#tr.en: 8th kirugu 
#tr.en: An, Enlil, Enki and Ninmaḫ have given their orders! 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal 
#tr.en: Now see! Enlil has fixed a good day in the land! 
#tr.en: He has even now ordered the day for Nibru to raise its neck to heaven! 
#tr.en: He himself has provided a good day for the E-kur to shine! 
#tr.en: He himself has raised up the day for the Ki-ur's magnificent manifestation! 
#tr.en: He himself has restored the day for Sumer and Akkad to expand! 
#tr.en: He himself has set aside the day for houses to be built and storerooms to be enclosed! 
#tr.en: He himself has brought out the day for seeds to sprout and living things to be born! 
#tr.en: He has brought out the day for building cattle pens and founding sheepfolds! 
#tr.en: he ewes which bore lambs have filled the pens! 
#tr.en: Ewes have given birth in the folds, their lambs have filled the pens! 
#tr.en: The goats which bore kids have filled the folds! 
#tr.en: The ewes which flocked with their lambs have swelled the sheepfold! 
#tr.en: The goats which flocked with their kids have caused the pens to be widened! 
#tr.en: He himself has set the day for turning destruction to the good! 
#tr.en: He has ... the day ... evil! 
#tr.en: He has brought in Išme-Dagan as assistance for the day for establishing justice in the land! 
#tr.en: 9th kirugu 
#tr.en: Although Sumer and Akkad had been desecrated by the foe, 
#tr.en: afterwards hearts were appeased, spirits soothed! 
#tr.en: All the great gods thus had compassion! 
#tr.en: They looked upon those sunk in exhaustion and brought them up out of it! 
#tr.en: They restored your city which had been razed to ruins! 
#tr.en: Its shining property which had been scattered, which had been devastated, 
#tr.en: Enlil, king of all countries, restored it! 
#tr.en: There where the populace rested in the cool after building their nests, 
#tr.en: in Nibru, the mountain of the greatest divine powers, from where they had taken an unfamiliar path - 
#tr.en: at Enlil's word the Anuna, those very lords who determine the fates, ordered that the temples which they had forsaken 
#tr.en: and the jewels, put there long ago, which had been carried off by the wind 
#tr.en: should all be restored! 
#tr.en: He has established there dining in joy within! 
#tr.en: To Išme-Dagan, his joyous, reverent sacral officiant, 
#tr.en: to sanctify its food, to purify its water Enlil has given the command to him. 
#tr.en: He has commanded him to purify its defiled divine powers! 
#tr.en: He has put in order its disordered and scattered rites, 
#tr.en: he has put back in their place the most sacred things, neglected and defiled. 
#tr.en: He decrees as a fate the offering of daily rations and the grinding up of fine meal and flour. 
#tr.en: He has decided to make bread plentiful on the table, to make loaves numerous! 
#tr.en: 10th kirugu 
#tr.en: A time when no one is to speak hostile words to another, when a son is to respect his father, 
#tr.en: a time to establish humility in the Land, for the inferior to be as important as the mighty, 
#tr.en: a time when the younger brother, fearing his big brother, is to show humility, 
#tr.en: a time when the elder child is to treat the younger child reasonably and to pay heed to his words, 
#tr.en: a time to take neither weak nor strong away into captivity, but to serve with great acts of good, 
#tr.en: time to travel the disordered roadways, to extirpate evil growths, 
#tr.en: {a time when anyone is to go where they will, to hurl no insults at one's fellow,} 
#tr.en: {a time no one is to speak hostile words to another, to perform no sacrilege,} 
#tr.en: a time to remove bitterness from the Land, to establish light therein, 
#tr.en: a time when darkness is to be lifted in the Land, so that living things should rejoice. 
#tr.en: Father Enlil, the lord whose command cannot be altered, prince of all countries, 
#tr.en: has fixed it among the black-headed people, and commanded for their benefit. 
#tr.en: 11th kirugu 
#tr.en: Now, see! After that time, Enlil, the prince who is full of pity, 
#tr.en: has been beneficent to his hero who had laid the ... brick! 
#tr.en: He put in order again for him the divine powers which had been desecrated by the enemy! 
#tr.en: He sanctified again the defiled rites for him! 
#tr.en: He purified its ziggurat temple and made it resplendent for him! 
#tr.en: Within he made abundance plentiful, he filled it with choice beer and syrup! 
#tr.en: He established there at that time the pleasing of hearts, the appeasing of spirits, the ameliorating of moods! 
#tr.en: Išme-Dagan himself stood in prayer to Enlil and offered salutations! 
#tr.en: When he had begun the lament and spoken the supplication, 
#tr.en: the prince of all countries treated his body with oil of abundance as if it were the sweetest syrup! 
#tr.en: And his prayer was heard - Enlil looked upon him with favour, 
#tr.en: Išme-Dagan whose words bring Enlil pleasure! 
#tr.en: Enlil's constant attendant, with whose thoughts he agrees! 
#tr.en: Because the humble one prostrated himself in his devotions and served there, 
#tr.en: because he will entreat him in supplication and will do obeisance, 
#tr.en: because he will complete and honour the royal offering and will return 
#tr.en: because he will keep watch over everything and will not be negligent, 
#tr.en: Enlil has promised to Išme-Dagan his dominion of extended years! 
#tr.en: He promised him that he will be a man of pre-eminent kingship! 
#tr.en: He promised him that he will be a king whose reign is good! 
#tr.en: He promised him that he shall have the people inhabit safe dwellings! 
#tr.en: Enlil found agreement in what he had said to the numerous people! 
#tr.en: On the day for decreeing fates, every part of Sumer and Akkad, 
#tr.en: mong the black-headed people flocking like sheep, among their well-tended people, 
#tr.en: will praise forever the majesty of the Great Mountain Nunamnir, enkar weapon of the universe! 
#tr.en: It is his awe-inspiring way! 
#tr.en: 12th kirugu 
#tr.en: The ... which had developed -- its wiping clean (?) was to be accomplished (?) 
#tr.en: The ... of heaven and earth put their divine powers ... to sleep (?). 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... mortal man multiplied to become as numerous as the gods. 
#tr.en: When together ... had achieved a momentous decision, 
#tr.en: , the ... of the gods ... 
#tr.en: Enki and Ninki determined the consensus - 
#tr.en: Enul and Ninul assigned the fate, ... 
#tr.en: When together An and Enlil had created it, that one resembled ... 
#tr.en: When Ninlil had given it features, that one was fit for ... 
#tr.en: When together Aruru, Suen and Enki had fashioned its limbs, 
#tr.en: that one turned pitch black, as at night, halfway through the watch, ... 
#tr.en: All the great gods paled at its immensity and ... was brought about. 
#tr.en: Like a great wild bull which bellows mightily, that one filled the world with its roar. 
#tr.en: As its gigantic horns reached up to heaven, who trembled in his very core? 
#tr.en: As it was piled up over the mountains like a battle-net, who turned away? 
#tr.en: Who caused wailing and lamenting in those streets and ...? 
#tr.en: Uruk, like a loyal citizen in terror, set up an alarm 
#tr.en: (and exclaimed) “Rise up!” Why did its hand seize Uruk? Why did the benevolent eye look away? 
#tr.en: Who brought about such worry and lamenting and ...? 
#tr.en: That one drew nearer. That one settled upon the ground. Why would he withdraw? 
#tr.en: Who distorted Uruk's good sense and deranged its good counsel? 
#tr.en: Who smashed its good udug deity? Who struck its good lamma deity too? 
#tr.en: Who desecrated the fearsome radiance which crowned it? 
#tr.en: Who brought about mob panic in Uruk? Who ... sickness too? 
#tr.en: Along with the city, the foreign lands ..., who ... in the temple of Uruk? 
#tr.en: That one ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: Who made ...? 
#tr.en: Why was ... expanded? Who made the black-headed people become so numerous? 
#tr.en: Who overthrew ...? 
#tr.en: ... was destroyed - who restored ...? 
#tr.en: Who confronted ...? 
#tr.en: That one crushed ... 
#tr.en: That one ... 
#tr.en: ... like ... 
#tr.en: ... and Utu, who in human form renders judgment at the law court of heaven, set and did not rise again. 
#tr.en: ... bore a heavy burden of sin. 
#tr.en: ... the altered verdicts of Lord Nunamnir. 
#tr.en: who can smite ...? 
#tr.en: ... and they approach (?) 
#tr.en: ... he brings ... forth. 
#tr.en: ... of Enlil ... 
#tr.en: He ... and puts an end to ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... each and every one ... 
#tr.en: ... its ways were ... 
#tr.en: ...its destruction and demolition, ... 
#tr.en: The ... of the gods ... attention. 
#tr.en: ..., who neglected ..., 
#tr.en: ... the city watched as the evil ghost approached. 
#tr.en: ... breathed painfully, he wept bitterly. 
#tr.en: ... there was no nodding of the head. 
#tr.en: He consoled himself with tears and laments - the city trembled. 
#tr.en: A defiled hand smote him and flattened his skull - the city collapsed. 
#tr.en: The fearsome radiance overwhelmed like ... 
#tr.en: The proud city of all the lands became like one who spreads havoc. 
#tr.en: The faithful cowherds themselves overturned every single cattlepen. 
#tr.en: The chief shepherds themselves burned (?) every sheepfold. 
#tr.en: They built them up like grain heaps, they spread them out like grain piles, 
#tr.en: they were convulsed. ... they drenched the fields with water, they turned the city into a swamp. 
#tr.en: They did all that. Like reeds in a wasteland, life could not be revived. 
#tr.en: They brought ruination. Evil things menaced (?) the city. 
#tr.en: A hush settled over the awed hearts of its people like a cloak. 
#tr.en: Its good udug deities went away, its lamma deities ran off. 
#tr.en: Its lamma deity (said) “Hide in the open country” and they took foreign paths. 
#tr.en: The city's patron god turned against it and its shepherd abandoned it. 
#tr.en: Its guardian spirit, though not an enemy, was exiled (?) to a foreign place. 
#tr.en: Thus all its most important gods evacuated Uruk, they kept away from it. 
#tr.en: They hid out in the hills and wandered (?) about in the haunted plains. 
#tr.en: In the city built upon peace, food and drink were overturned like a saman vessel. 
#tr.en: In the pasture lands a tumultuous noise arose, the asses and sheep were driven away. 
#tr.en: Elderly people and babies, taking their rest, ... in front ... 
#tr.en: They saw ... and slaughtered (?) ...

#tr.en: The ... of heaven ... and the people ... to the limits of heaven. 
#tr.en: Its gišgigal. 
#tr.en: He ..., stretched forth his hand and induced terror in the land. 
#tr.en: Enlil struck out with great ferocity. He announced: 
#tr.en: “A deluge dashing the hoe on the ground shall be invoked. 
#tr.en: At its front war shall be a ... axe, at its rear it shall be a ... 
#tr.en: Its overgrown hair shall be a harrow, its back shall be flames. 
#tr.en: Its countenance shall be a malevolent storm that enshrouds heaven and earth. 
#tr.en: The glint of its eyes shall be lightning that flashes far like the Anzud bird. 
#tr.en: Its mouth shall rage -- a blazing fire that extends as far as the nether world. 
#tr.en: Its tongue shall be an inferno, raining embers, that sunders the Land. 
#tr.en: Its arms shall be the majestic Anzud bird that nothing can escape when it spreads wide its talons.” 
#tr.en: “Its ribs shall be crowbars that let light pass inside like the sun's rays. 
#tr.en: Knotted at both its hips shall be city-destroying slingstones. 
#tr.en: Its great haunches shall be dripping knives, covered with gore, that make blood flow. 
#tr.en: Its muscles shall be saws that slash, its feet those of an eagle. 
#tr.en: It shall make the Tigris and Euphrates quaver, it shall make the mountains rumble. 
#tr.en: At its reverberation the hills shall be uprooted, the people shall be pitched about like sheaves, 
#tr.en: Sumer and Akkad shall shiver, they shall be flooded like a harvest crop. 
#tr.en: The foolish shall rejoice, they shall exclaim (?): 
#tr.en: “Let it come -- we shall be seeing war and battle in the city, 
#tr.en: how the sacred precinct (?) is destroyed, how the walls are battered down, how the city's peace is disrupted, 
#tr.en: how among the loyal families honest men are transformed into traitors.”" 
#tr.en: “But the sensible shall beat their breasts and droop (?) their heads. 
#tr.en: At midnight they shall be afraid and tearful, and suffer insomnia. 
#tr.en: In bed, under the covers, they shall be unable to sleep soundly, they shall wander about the city. 
#tr.en: They shall be immobilised, their courage shall run out: 
#tr.en: “May our allies serving in times of war raise their forces for peace. 
#tr.en: May the word of Enlil be sent back, may it turn tail. 
#tr.en: May the venom of Nunamnir's anger become exhausted. 
#tr.en: May those vicious men who have seized the E-kur be punished. 
#tr.en: May those who have set their sight upon Nibru be swept away.”" 
#tr.en: 3rd kirugu.

#tr.en: House, your great divine power is the shackle of the gods put on the Land. 
#tr.en: Your gate is named by your god, the beautiful god; only when it is is open does Utu illuminate from the horizon. 
#tr.en: Your platform, the place where the fates are determined by the gods, 
#tr.en: in order to make just decisions, is where the Anuna, the gods of heaven and earth, take counsel. 
#tr.en: Your ... makes (?) the faithful woman joyous, the father proud. 
#tr.en: In your interior the evildoer dare not lay hold of the holy statutes.

#tr.en: Igi-ḫatet did Manzat call; she heard him and 
#tr.en: the kingship of Susa and Anshan on him bestowed, and the kukunnû 
#tr.en: of baked brick, the old one, he (=Igi-ḫatet) renewed and to Manzat 
#tr.en: gave. May Manzat a long life to him give! 
#tr.en: May she (=Manzat) a joyful kingship to him provide! 
#tr.en: I am Untaš-napiriša, son of Ḫumbannumena, king of Anshan 
#tr.en: and Susa. Wishing that my life and reign (will) constantly prosper 
#tr.en: and that the extinction of lineage (at the time of) judgment (?) to me may not be granted, it is for this reason that 
#tr.en: a temple with baked brick, a kukunnû with glazed bricks I have built. 
#tr.en: To Inšušinak of siyan-kuk I gave it. A ziggurat 
#tr.en: I raised. May my work to Inšušinak be dedicated. 
#tr.en: (Property of) the palace of Assurnasirpal, vice-regent of Assur, chosen of the gods Enlil and Ninurta, beloved of the gods Anu and Dagan, destructive weapon of the great gods, strong king, king of the universe, king of Assyria, 
#tr.en: son of Tukultī-Ninurta, great king, strong king, king of the universe, king of Assyria, son of Adad-nārāri, king of the universe (and) king of Assyria; valiant man who with the support of Assur, his lord, acts 
#tr.en: and among the princes of the four quarters has no rival, marvellous shepherd, fearless in battle, mighty flood-tide 
#tr.en: that has no opponent, the king who subdues those insubordinate to him, he who all peoples rules, strong male who treads upon 
#tr.en: the necks of his foes, trampler of all enemies, he who breaks up the forces of the rebellious, king who with the support of the great gods, 
#tr.en: his lords, acts, and all lands has conquered, dominion over all the highlands gained 
#tr.en: and their tribute received, capturer of hostages, he who is victorious over all countries: When Assur, the lord 
#tr.en: who called me by name (and) made supreme my sovereignty, his merciless weapon in my lordly arms 
#tr.en: placed, the extensive troops of the Lullumu in battle with the sword I felled. 
#tr.en: With the help of the gods Šamaš and Adda, the gods my supporters, against the troops of the lands Nairi, Ḫabḫu, the Šubarû,  
#tr.en: and the land Nerbu, like the god Adda, the devastator, I thundered. The king who (the territory stretching) from the opposite bank of the Tigris to Mount Lebanon 
#tr.en: and the Great Sea, the entire land Laqû, (and) the land Suḫu including the city Rapiqu subdued;  
#tr.en: from the source of the River Subnat to the land Urartu he conquered. (The territory stretching) from the passes of Mount Kirruru to the land Gilzanu, 
#tr.en: from the opposite bank of the Lower Zab to the city Til-Bāri that is upstream from the land Zaban, from the city Til-ša-Zabdani  
#tr.en: and the city Til-ša-Abtani, the cities Ḫirimu, Ḫarutu, (that are) fortresses of Karduniaš within the boundaries of my land I brought. 
#tr.en:  (The people) from the passes of Mount Babitu to Mount Ḫašmar as people of my land I accounted. In the lands over which I gained dominion my governors I always appointed. 
#tr.en: They did servitude. Assurnasirpal, attentive prince, worshipper of the great gods, ferocious dragon, conqueror of cities and the entire highlands, 
#tr.en: king of lords, encircler of the obstinate, crowned with splendor, fearless in battle, merciless hero, 
#tr.en: he who stirs up strife, praiseworthy king, shepherd, protection of the (four) quarters, the king whose command grinds mountains 
#tr.en: and seas, the one who by his lordly conflict ferocious (and) merciless kings from east 
#tr.en: to west has brought under one authority: mighty mountains I have traversed; I have seen remote (and) rugged regions throughout all the (four) quarters; 
#tr.en: I have caused to rain down flaming arrows upon the princes of all cities (so that) they ever revere my command 
#tr.en: (and) pray to my lordship; I, Assurnasirpal, sage, expert, intelligent one, open to counsel (and) wisdom that Ea, king of the Apsu, destined for me;
#tr.en: the great gods of heaven and underworld in their steadfast hearts chose me, and my sovereignty, dominion, (and) power came forth by their holy command; the lands 
#tr.en: and mighty highlands to rule, subdue, and direct they sternly commanded me. By the command of Assur, the great lord, my lord,
#tr.en: and the god Ninurta who loves my priesthood, I marched to Mount Lebanon. I went up to the Great Sea. In the Great Sea 
#tr.en: my weapons I cleansed (and) sacrifices to my gods made. At that time tribute from the kings of the sea-coast,
#tr.en: from the lands of the people of Tyre, Sidon, Amurru, Byblos, Maballatu, Kaizu, 
#tr.en: Maizu, and the city Arvad that is (on an island) in the sea—silver, gold, tin, bronze, bronze casseroles,  
#tr.en: linen garments with multi-coloured trim, ivory of nāḫirus (that are) sea creatures, I received. At that time large female monkeys (and) 
#tr.en: small female monkeys with their tribute I received from them, (the monkeys) to my land Assur I brought. In Calah 
#tr.en: herds of them in great numbers I bred (and) to all the people of my land  displayed. With my outstretched hand 
#tr.en: and my fierce heart 15 strong lions from the mountains and forests I captured. 50 lcubs 
#tr.en: of lions I took away. Into Calah and the palaces of my land into cages I herded them. Their cubs 
#tr.en: in great numbers I bred. Live tigers I captured. Herds of wild bulls
#tr.en: elephants, lions, ostriches, male monkeys, female monkeys, wild asses, deer, aialu-deer, female bears,  
#tr.en: panthers, senkurru, beasts of mountain (and) plain, all of them in my city Calah I formed. To all the people  
#tr.en: of my land I displayed (them). O later prince among the kings my sons whom Assur calls, or later people, 
#tr.en: or vice-chancellor, or noble, or eunuch—you must not despise (these animals). Before Assur may these creature(s) live! 
#tr.en: Ninurta and Nergal, who love my priesthood, gave to me the wild beasts (and) commanded me to hunt. 
#tr.en: 30 elephants from an ambush pit I killed. 257 strong wild bulls from my ... chariots   
#tr.en: with my lordly assault with swords I slew. 370 strong lions like caged birds with the spear I killed. 
#tr.en: On the 8th day of the month Iyyar from Calah I moved. After crossing the Tigris the city Carchemish of the land Ḫatti.
#tr.en: I approached. I received from it much of its palace property, the weight of that could not be determined. All the kings of the lands 
#tr.en: came (and) submitted to me. Hostages from them I took (and) they were kept in my presence on the march to Mount Lebanon. 
#tr.en: Moving on from the city Carchemish the way between Mounts Munziganu (and) Ḫamurga  I took. Leaving Mount Aḫanu on my left 
#tr.en:  I approached the city Ḫ:azazu that (was ruled by) Lubarna, the Patinu. Silver, gold, (and) linen garments I received. Passing on the River Apre,
#tr.en:  I crossed, pitched camp, (and) spent the night. Moving on from the River Apre the city Kunulua, the royal city of Lubarna, the Patinu, I approached.
#tr.en: In the face of my raging weapons (and) fierce battle he took fright and submitted to me to save his life. 20 talents of silver, 1 talent of gold, 100 talents of tin, 
#tr.en: 100 talents of iron, 1,000 oxen, 10,000 sheep, 1,000 linen garments with multi-coloured trim, decorated couches of boxwood with inlay, 
#tr.en: beds of boxwood, ivory beds decorated with inlay, many ornaments from his palace the weight of that could not be determined I received as his tribute. 
#tr.en: The ancient city Calah that Shalmaneser, king of Assyria, a prince who preceded me, had built—this city had become dilapidated; it lay dormant. 
#tr.en: This city I rebuilt. People that I had conquered from the lands over that I had gained dominion, from the land Suḫu,
#tr.en: (from) the entire land of Laqu, (from) the city Sirqu that is at the crossing of the Euphrates, (from) the entire land of Zamua,  
#tr.en: (from) Bit-Adini and the land .tJatti, and from Lubarna, the Patinu I took. I settled (them) therein.  The old ruin hill 
#tr.en: I cleared away (and) down to water level dug. (The foundation pit) down to a depth of 120 layers of brick I sank. A palace of cedar,
#tr.en: a palace of cypress, a palace of dapranu-juniper, a palace of boxwood, a palace of meskannu wood, a palace of terebinth, and tamarisk  
#tr.en: as my royal residence (and) for my lordly leisure for eternity I founded therein. (Replicas of) beasts of mountains
#tr.en: and seas in white limestone and paratu-alabaster I made, (and) at its doors stationed. I decorated it in a splendid fashion;
#tr.en: with knobbed nails of bronze I surrounded it. Doors of cedar, cypress, dapranu-juniper, (and) meskannu-wood in its doorways I hung.
#tr.en: Silver, gold, tin, bronze, booty from the lands over that I gained dominion 
#tr.en: in great quantities I took and put therein. 
#tr.en: 2 barig barley rations, 
#tr.en: (for) Ur-Mami, 
#tr.en: from the silo of Apisal, 
#tr.en: from Gududu 
#tr.en: seal of Lugal-inimgina; 
#tr.en: month “Pa’u’e,” 
#tr.en: year: “Simanum was destroyed.” 
#tr.en: Lugal-inimgina 
#tr.en: son of Lugal-nesage. 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, proud king, enthroned prince, 
#tr.en: most fit offshoot of kingship, 
#tr.en: who stands like Utu, brilliant light of the land, 
#tr.en: lofty in nobility, riding the great ordinances, 
#tr.en: who settles the people in the four quarters, 
#tr.en: favored by Enlil, beloved by Inanna, 
#tr.en: true youth with shining eyes, worthy of the throne 
#tr.en: (whose) head is adorned with the tiara, the true crown, 
#tr.en: (who is) perfectly equipped with the sceptre over the blackheads, 
#tr.en: prince Lipit-Ištar, son of Enlil, wise shepherd, 
#tr.en: who leads the people, letting the people people relax in sweet shade? 
#tr.en: Lord, great bison, beloved by An, 
#tr.en: your trust is (put in) the mother of Ninlil. 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, you are granted princely power; 
#tr.en: (your) name, a sound as sweet as honey, is perfect for speaking; 
#tr.en: longed-for husband of Inanna, 
#tr.en: whom Enki gave broad wisdom as a gift. 
#tr.en: Nisaba, the woman radiant with joy, 
#tr.en: the true woman scribe, the lady of all knowledge, 
#tr.en: guided your fingers on the clay, 
#tr.en: embellished the writing on the tablets, 
#tr.en: made the hand resplendent with a golden stylus. 
#tr.en: the 1-ninda rod, the gleaming surveyor’s line, 
#tr.en: the cubit ruler which gives wisdom, Nisaba lavishly bestowed upon you. 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, you are Enlil's son; 
#tr.en: truth and justice you make manifest; 
#tr.en: lord, your goodness covers even the horizon. 
#tr.en: King Lipit-Ištar, counsellor of great judgment, 
#tr.en: (whose) word never falters, wise one (whose) decision provides justice for the people; 
#tr.en: great mind, knowing all things deeply, 
#tr.en: in order to lay down the law for all foreign countries, 
#tr.en: you perceive falsehood and truth even from the words hidden in the heart. 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, you rage against the enemies, 
#tr.en: from evil and oppression you know how to save people, 
#tr.en: from sin and destruction you know how to free them. 
#tr.en: The mighty do not perpetrate robbery, 
#tr.en: and the strong do not make the weaker ones into hirelings— 
#tr.en: thus you established justice in Sumer and Akkad, 
#tr.en: and made pleasant (the life of) everybody in the land. 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, king of Isin, king of Sumer and Akkad, 
#tr.en: to Nippur you are the scribe; 
#tr.en: to the Ekur, Enlil’s house; Lipit-Ištar, you are its provider; 
#tr.en: for Enlil and Ninlil you are the love of their hearts; 
#tr.en: the hero Ninurta is your powerful guard, 
#tr.en: and vizier Nusku enforces your decisions. 
#tr.en: You are the Išib-priest for Keš, whom Nintu truly chose. 
#tr.en: Installed in Ur, you are the youth who has the attention of Suen. 
#tr.en: You are the one whom Enki gave the true tiara in Eridu. 
#tr.en: For holy Inanna in the region of Uruk, you, Lipit-Ištar, are her heart’s delight. 
#tr.en: Ninisina in Isin made you sit on your lofty dais. 
#tr.en: With a hearty song of joy, in a prosperous regnal year, 
#tr.en: the prince, the valiant prince surpassing in greatness and nobility, 
#tr.en: your father Išme-Dagan, king of the land, 
#tr.en: stabilized the foundation of your throne, 
#tr.en: and upon the order spoken by An and Enlil 
#tr.en: he silenced the loud strife of the foreign countries. 
#tr.en: You, Lipit-Ištar, Enlil’s son, 
#tr.en: have put your righteousness on everybody’s lips; 
#tr.en: your praise shall never disappear from the clay in the Edubba; 
#tr.en: may every scribe therefore sing of this bliss and glorify (you) greatly, 
#tr.en: so that your laudation in the Edubba shall not cease. 
#tr.en: O leading shepherd, youthful son of Enlil, 
#tr.en: Lipit-Ištar, be praised! 
#tr.en: Let me cast on you an incantation that drives away all illness, 
#tr.en: which Ellil-banda presented; the one who determines fates. 
#tr.en: Let Ea cast on you an incantation of healing, 
#tr.en: Nudimmud and Namma together with An. 
#tr.en: Let Ningirima cast an incantation on you, lady of incantations. 
#tr.en: She cast an incantation, did Ningirima, lady of incantations: 
#tr.en: the sick man arises, through her incantation he no longer suffers. 
#tr.en: May Ninkarrak bandage you with her gentle hands 
#tr.en: (and) may Damu make your suffering pass by, above you. 
#tr.en: The p. daughter, the snatcher Lamaštu, the bite of a dog, tooth of mankind, 
#tr.en: may Annunītum subdue through her incantation. 
#tr.en: Adda, Šakkan, Nisaba, Šamaš, Id, Ḫursānu, 
#tr.en: those holy gods, may they cleanse you, 
#tr.en: together with Enlil, may they cleanse you. 
#tr.en: (If) the twin brother and sister, children of Sin, Šamaš and Ištar 
#tr.en: (or) a talkative man, an angry woman, a sleepless man, a bewitched woman, or a stuffy-nosed man, 
#tr.en: or (anyone) who displeased the god, against you may be angry 
#tr.en: the king of the Apsû, the pure exorcist, Ea, 
#tr.en: an incantation that you cannot block, let him cast on you. 
#tr.en: May your suffering cross with haste to the Netherworld. 
#tr.en: I cast on you an incantation driving away all illness. 
#tr.en: The constipation, the fire, 
#tr.en: vertigo, the scorpion sting, 
#tr.en: the bad fall, 
#tr.en: the s. sickness, the red one, 
#tr.en: the red boil, the leprosy, 
#tr.en: the sweet appearance, the putrid sore, 
#tr.en: the itch, the bloody excrement, 
#tr.en: the chills, the head disease, 
#tr.en: and the šaššaṭu disease. 
#tr.en: from the ziggurat of heaven, they descended on us. 
#tr.en: It made feverish the sheeps and lambs. 
#tr.en: It made jittery the child on the shoulder of the nurse. 
#tr.en: Whom should I send and order 
#tr.en: to the daughters of An, the 7and 7 
#tr.en: whose containers are gold (and) pots 
#tr.en: are pure lapis lazuli. 
#tr.en: Let them take their containers of gold 
#tr.en: (and) pots of pure lapis lazuli. 
#tr.en: Let them draw water of the pure seas 
#tr.en: (and) sprinkled so that it may extinguish 
#tr.en: the constipation, the fire, 
#tr.en: vertigo, the scorpion sting 
#tr.en: the bad fall, 
#tr.en: the d. disease, the red one, 
#tr.en: the red boil, the leprosy, 
#tr.en: the sweet appearance, 
#tr.en: the putrid sore, the itch 
#tr.en: the bloody excrement, the chills, 
#tr.en: the head disease, and the šaššaṭa disease.

#tr.en: against the king a storm of small hailstones arose, 
#tr.en: against Enki a storm of large hailstones arose, 
#tr.en: The small ones were light hammers, 
#tr.en: the large ones were like stones from catapults (?). 
#tr.en: The keel of Enki’s little boat 
#tr.en: as if it were being butted by turtles was trembling, 
#tr.en: against the king the waves at the bow of the boat 
#tr.en: like wolves were eating together, 
#tr.en: against Enki the waves at the stern of the boat 
#tr.en: like a lion were attacking. 
#tr.en: At that time, there was a single tree, a single ḫalub tree, a single tree, 
#tr.en: growing on the bank of the pure Euphrates, 
#tr.en: being watered by the Euphrates. 
#tr.en: The force of the south wind uprooted it and stripped its branches, 
#tr.en: and the Euphrates picked it up and carried it away. 
#tr.en: A woman, respectful of An’s words, was walking along; 
#tr.en: respectful of Enlil’s words, was walking along, 
#tr.en: and took the tree and into Unug, 
#tr.en: into Inanna’s luxuriant garden brought it. 
#tr.en: The woman planted the tree not with her hands, but with her feet. 
#tr.en: The woman planted the tree not with her hands, but with her feet planted it. 
#tr.en: “When will this be a luxuriant chair on which I can take a seat?” she said; 
#tr.en: “When this will be a luxuriant bed on which I can lie down?” she said; 
#tr.en: 5 years, 10 years went by, 
#tr.en: the tree grew massive; its bark, however, did not split. 
#tr.en: At its roots, a snake immune to incantations made itself a nest. 
#tr.en: In its branches, the Anzud bird settled its young. 
#tr.en: In its trunk, the phantom maid built herself a dwelling, 
#tr.en: the maid who laughs with a joyful heart. 
#tr.en: But silver Inanna cried! 
#tr.en: When dawn was breaking, when the horizon became bright, 
#tr.en: when the little birds, at the break of dawn, began to clamor, 
#tr.en: when Utu had left his bedchamber, 
#tr.en: his sister silver Inanna 
#tr.en: to the young warrior Utu: said 
#tr.en: “My brother, in those days when destiny was determined, 
#tr.en: when abundance overflowed in the Land, 
#tr.en: when An had taken the heavens for himself, 
#tr.en: when Enlil had taken the earth for himself, 
#tr.en: when the nether world had been given to Ereškigala as a gift;

#tr.en: “At that time, there was a single tree, a single ḫalub tree, a single tree (?),

#tr.en: “The woman planted the tree not with her hands, but with her feet. 
#tr.en: Inanna watered it using not her hands, but her feet. 
#tr.en: “When will this be a luxuriant chair on which I can take a seat?” she said; 
#tr.en: “When will this be a luxuriant bed on which I can lie down?” she said; 
#tr.en: 5 years, 10 years had gone by, 
#tr.en: the tree had grown massive; its bark, however, did not split. 
#tr.en: At its roots, a snake immune to incantations made itself a nest. 
#tr.en: In its branches, the Anzu bird settled its young. 
#tr.en: In its trunk, the phantom maid built herself a dwelling, 
#tr.en: the maid who laughs with a joyful heart. 
#tr.en: I, silver Inanna, cried!” 
#tr.en: In the matter which his sister had told him about, 
#tr.en: her brother, the warrior Gilgamesh, stood by her. 
#tr.en: to his waist his ... belt of 50 minas weight he strapped— 
#tr.en: 50 minas were to him as 30 shekels. 
#tr.en: His bronze axe used for expeditions, 
#tr.en: which weighs 7 talents and 7 minas, in his hand he took; 
#tr.en: He killed the snake immune to incantations living at its roots. 
#tr.en: The Anzu bird living in its branches took up its young and went into the mountains. 
#tr.en: The phantom maid living in its trunk left (?) her dwelling 
#tr.en: and sought refuge in the wilderness. 
#tr.en: As for the tree, he uprooted it and stripped its branches, 
#tr.en: and the sons of his city, who went with him, 
#tr.en: cut up its branches and bundled them 
#tr.en: He gave it to his sister silver Inanna for her chair. 
#tr.en: He gave it to her for her bed. 
#tr.en: As for himself, from its roots, he manufactured his ball (?) 
#tr.en: and, from its branches, he manufactured his mallet (?). 
#tr.en: He played with the ball (?) in the broad square, never wanting to stop playing it, 
#tr.en: and he praised himself in the broad square, never wanting to stop praising himself. 
#tr.en: The young men of his city were playing with the ball (?). 
#tr.en: For (?) him who made the team of the widows’ children ..., 
#tr.en: they lamented: “O my neck! O my hips!” 
#tr.en: For those that had a mother, bread for her son she brought; 
#tr.en: for those that had a sister, she poured water for her brother. 
#tr.en: As the evening came, 
#tr.en: he marked the spot where the ball (?) had been placed, 
#tr.en: and he picked up his ball (?) from in front of him and took it home. 
#tr.en: But early in the morning as he ... the place marked, 
#tr.en: the widows’ accusation 
#tr.en: and the young girls’ complaint 
#tr.en: caused his ball (?) and his mallet (?) to fall down to the bottom of the nether world. 
#tr.en: He could not reach them by ... 
#tr.en: He tried with his hand but could not reach them, 
#tr.en: tried with his foot but could not reach them. 
#tr.en: At the gate of Ganzer, in front of the nether world, he sat down. 
#tr.en: Gilgamesh wept, crying bitterly: 
#tr.en: “O my ball (?)! O my mallet (?)! 
#tr.en: My ball (?), I am still not satiated with its charms, 
#tr.en: the game with it has not yet palled for me! 
#tr.en: If only my ball (?) waited still in the carpenter’s house for me! 
#tr.en: I would treat the carpenter’s wife like my own mother— 
#tr.en: I would treat the carpenter’s child like my little sister! 
#tr.en: My ball (?) has fallen down to the nether world—who will retrieve it for me? 
#tr.en: My mallet (?) has fallen down to Ganzer—who will retrieve it for me? 
#tr.en: His servant Enkidu answered: 
#tr.en: “My king, you weep; why does your heart worry? 
#tr.en: Today I shall retrieve your ball (?) from the nether world, 
#tr.en: I shall retrieve your mallet (?) from Ganzer.” 
#tr.en: Gilgamesh answered Enkidu: 
#tr.en: “If today you are going to go down to the nether world, 
#tr.en: let me advise you! My instructions should be followed. 
#tr.en: Let me talk to you! Pay attention to my words!" 
#tr.en: “You should not put on your clean garments: 
#tr.en: they would recognise immediately that you are alien. 
#tr.en: You should not anoint yourself with fine oil from a bowl: 
#tr.en: they would surround you at its scent. 
#tr.en: You should not hurl throw-sticks in the nether world: 
#tr.en: those struck down by the throw-sticks would surround you. 
#tr.en: You should not not hold a cornel-wood stick in your hand: 
#tr.en: the spirits would feel insulted by you. 
#tr.en: You should not put sandals on your feet. 
#tr.en: You should not shout in the nether world. 
#tr.en: You should not kiss your beloved wife. 
#tr.en: You should not hit your wife even if you are annoyed with her. 
#tr.en: You should not kiss your beloved child. 
#tr.en: You should not hit your son even if you are annoyed with him. 
#tr.en: The outcry aroused would detain you in the nether world.” 
#tr.en: “She who lies there, she who lies there, 
#tr.en: Ninazu’s mother who lies there— 
#tr.en: her pure shoulders are not covered with a garment, 
#tr.en: and no linen is spread over her pure breast. 
#tr.en: She has fingers like a pickaxe, 
#tr.en: she plucks her hair out like leeks.” 
#tr.en: Enkidu, however, did not heed not his master’s words. 
#tr.en: He put on his clean garments 
#tr.en: and they recognised that he was alien. 
#tr.en: He anointed himself with fine oil from a bowl 
#tr.en: and they surrounded him at its scent. 
#tr.en: He hurled throw-sticks in the nether world 
#tr.en: and those struck down by the throw-sticks surrounded him. 
#tr.en: He held a cornel-wood stick in his hand 
#tr.en: and the spirits felt insulted by him. 
#tr.en: He put sandals on his feet. 
#tr.en: He caused irritation in the nether world. 
#tr.en: He kissed his beloved wife 
#tr.en: and hit his wife when he was annoyed with her. 
#tr.en: He kissed his beloved child 
#tr.en: and hit his son when he was annoyed with him. 
#tr.en: He aroused an outcry and was detained in the nether world. 
#tr.en: The warrior Gilgamesh, son of Ninsumun, 
#tr.en: directed his steps on his own to E-kur, the temple of Enlil. 
#tr.en: He cried before Enlil: 
#tr.en: “Father Enlil, my ball (?) fell down into the nether world, my mallet (?) fell down into Ganzer. 
#tr.en: Enkidu went down to retrieve them but the nether world has seized him. 
#tr.en: Namtar did not seize him, the Asag did not seize him; but the nether world has seized him. 
#tr.en: The udug demon of Nergal, who spares nobody, did not seize him, but the nether world has seized him. 
#tr.en: He did not fall in battle on the field of manhood, but the nether world has seized him.” 
#tr.en: Father Enlil did not stand by him in the matter, so he went to Eridu. 
#tr.en: In Eridu he directed his steps on his own to the temple of Enki. 
#tr.en: He cried before Enki: 
#tr.en: “Father Enki, my ball (?) fell down into the nether world, my mallet (?) fell down into Ganzer. 
#tr.en: Enkidu went down to retrieve them but the nether world has seized him. 
#tr.en: Namtar did not seize him, the Asag did not seize him; but the nether world has seized him. 
#tr.en: The udug demon of Nergal, who spares nobody, did not seize him, but the nether world has seized him. 
#tr.en: He did not fall in battle on the field of manhood, but the nether world has seized him.” 
#tr.en: Father Enki stood by him in this matter. 
#tr.en: He said to the young warrior Utu, the son born by Ningal: 
#tr.en: “Open a window in the nether world immediately, 
#tr.en: and then bring up his servant from the nether world!” 
#tr.en: He opened a window in the nether world 
#tr.en: and brought up his servant with his breeze (?) from the nether world. 
#tr.en: They hugged and kissed. 
#tr.en: They wearied each other with questions: 
#tr.en: “Did you see the order of the nether world? 
#tr.en: If only you would tell me, my friend, if only you would tell me!” 
#tr.en: “If I tell you the order of the nether world, 
#tr.en: si yourself down and weep! I shall sit down and weep! 
#tr.en: ..., which your heart rejoiced to touch, 
#tr.en: is ..., 
#tr.en: worms infest it like an old garment (?); 
#tr.en: like ... of (?) a crevice, it is full of dust.” 
#tr.en: “Alas!” he said and sat down in the dust. 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 1 son?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “He weeps bitterly at the wooden peg which was driven into his wall.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 2 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “He sits on 2 bricks, eating bread.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 3 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “He drinks water from a saddle waterskin.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 4 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “His heart rejoices like a man who has four asses to yoke.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 5 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “Like a good scribe he is indefatigable, he enters the palace easily.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 6 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “He is a cheerful as a ploughman.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had 7 sons?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “As a companion of the gods, he sits on a throne and listens to judgments.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see the palace eunuch?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “Like a useless alala stick he is propped in a corner.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see the woman who never gave birth?” “I saw her.” “How does she fare?” 
#tr.en: “Like a ... pot, she is thrown away violently, she gives no man joy.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see the young man who never undressed his wife?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “You finish a rope, and he weeps over the rope.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see the young woman who never undressed her husband?” “I saw her.” “How does she fare?” 
#tr.en: “You finish a reed mat, and she weeps over the reed mat.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who had no heir?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “Like him who ... bricks (?), he eats bread.” 
#tr.en: “...?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: “Did you see ...?” 
#tr.en: “His food is set apart, his water is set apart, he eats the food offered (?) to him, he drinks the water offered (?) to him.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who was eaten by a lion?” 
#tr.en: “He cries bitterly “O my hands! O my legs!” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who fell down from the roof?” 
#tr.en: “They cannot ... his bones.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see the leprous man?” 
#tr.en: “He twitches like an ox as the worms eat at him.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who fell in battle?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “His father and mother are not there to hold his head, and his wife weeps.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see the spirit of him who has no funerary offerings?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “He eats the scraps and the crumbs ... tossed out in the street.” 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: “Did you see him hit by a ship’s board? How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “Alas, my mother!” the man cries to her, 
#tr.en: as he pulls out the ship’s board ..., 
#tr.en: he ... cross beam ... crumbs.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see my little stillborn children who never knew existence?” “I saw them.” “How do they fare?” 
#tr.en: “They play at a table of gold and silver, laden with honey and ghee.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who died ...?” “I saw him.” “How does he fare?” 
#tr.en: “He lies on a bed of the gods.” 
#tr.en: “Did you see him who was set on fire?” “I did not see him. 
#tr.en: His spirit is not about. His smoke went up to the sky.” 
#tr.en: Enter, good spirit! 
#tr.en: Leave, evil spirit! 
#tr.en: 10 bundles of reed, 
#tr.en: under seal of Lugal-ezem. 
#tr.en: 1 cadaver, ram, grain-fed, 
#tr.en: from Ba’aga, the fattener, 
#tr.en: did Adda-rabi, the agrig, 
#tr.en: receive; 
#tr.en: month “Festival of Lisi,” day 25 elapsed, 
#tr.en: year: “The priest of Inanna of Uruk by (extispicy-)goat was chosen.” 
#tr.en: Anger, they say, anger 
#tr.en: goes like a wild bull; 
#tr.en: it constantly leaps forth like a dog; 
#tr.en: like a lion 
#tr.en: fierce in going, 
#tr.en: like a wolf 
#tr.en: in moving numerous, they say. 
#tr.en: It ripped out the good looks 
#tr.en: of his face; 
#tr.en: it broke the fullness 
#tr.en: of his stomach. 
#tr.en: I examined him and 
#tr.en: like a bridge 
#tr.en: I passed over him 
#tr.en: (and) underneath his jaw(?). 
#tr.en: The Tigris 
#tr.en: river, 
#tr.en: abundance of the land ... 
#tr.en: Approach him! 
#tr.en: Scratch him! 
#tr.en: If not... 
#tr.en: let me pronounce a prayer. 
#tr.en: The magical machination 
#tr.en: of expelling anger(?). 
#tr.en: I have destroyed you like a flood, 
#tr.en: bound you like a fog. 
#tr.en: I cast you to your ass. 
#tr.en: I took a bowstring and have bound your lips; 
#tr.en: like a wolf I have leapt on you; 
#tr.en: like a lion my spittle I cast over you. 
#tr.en: Let me command, and may my order be higher than your order be high; 
#tr.en: Let me speak, and may my utterance be louder than your utterance; 
#tr.en: just as a wild animal is louder than a š.; 
#tr.en: accordingly, may my order be louder than your order; 
#tr.en: just as the sky is louder than the earth; 
#tr.en: accordingly, may my order be louder than your order. 
#tr.en: You tied your nose to your anus 
#tr.en: so that I cannot slap your cheek? 
#tr.en: Anger goes like a wild bull, 
#tr.en: it constantly leaps forth 
#tr.en: like a dog; 
#tr.en: like a lion 
#tr.en: it is ferocious in running; 
#tr.en: like a wolf, 
#tr.en: it is full of rage. 
#tr.en: You sit there like a doorsill, 
#tr.en: I walk across you; 
#tr.en: like an unfinished door, 
#tr.en: I will pass through you again and again; 
#tr.en: like a doorframe, 
#tr.en: I will hang over you; 
#tr.en: over you 
#tr.en: like a š.-rope, 
#tr.en: I will repel your footsteps. 
#tr.en: I will send away the fire 
#tr.en: of your stomach. 
#tr.en: Crossways, it is strange, 
#tr.en: thrown back, like the g-(fruit), 
#tr.en: like fruit of an orchard did he over him go out. 
#tr.en: Let bring to her charcoal 
#tr.en: the Tigris; 
#tr.en: my s. of copper, my powder of licorice 
#tr.en: may he bring. My s. that pierces your eyes. 
#tr.en: (Sumerian:) incantation against fire of the stomach. 
#tr.en: (Weight) stone: 20 mana.

#tr.en: account 
#tr.en: (of) Ur-Nanše, son (of) Luduga, 
#tr.en: in Gu’abba, 
#tr.en: from month “GANmaš” 
#tr.en: to month “Barley carried,” 
#tr.en: it is 12 months; 
#tr.en: Ur-Lamma, 
#tr.en: governor; 
#tr.en: year: “Sulgi, strong man, king of Ur, king of the four regions, the heads of Urbilum, Simurrum, Lullubu and Karḫar in a single campaign did smash.”

#tr.en: Lord Enlil, lord of the lands, 
#tr.en: Looked maliciously at Sumer, devastated it with a flood-storm. 
#tr.en: He destroyed Kiur, the great place. 
#tr.en: “My beloved, for how long was it built? For how long is it destroyed? … adornment of the Abzu.” 
#tr.en: Its gešgigal. 
#tr.en: “Lord Enki, who has seen a destruction (like that) of your city Eridu? 
#tr.en: Who has seen a misfortune like that of the Abzu shrine, your house? 
#tr.en: No one goes up to your cultic place. 
#tr.en: At the afternoon meal, in his great dining hall, they do not call his name.” 
#tr.en: Enki, king of the abzu, 
#tr.en: felt distresssed, felt anxious. At the words of his spouse, 
#tr.en: he himself began to wail, and lay down fasting. 
#tr.en: “My king, you must not be distressed, you must not be anxious!”
