#tr.en: Total: 
#tr.en: 22 (persons under) Ka’a. 
#tr.en: I (am) Darius, the great king, king of kings, king in Persia, king of nations, Hystaspes, his son, Arsames, his the grandson, an Achaemenid. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: I, my father (was) Hystaspes, and Hystaspes, his father (was) Arsames, and Arsames, his father (was) Ariaramnes, and Ariaramnes, his father (was) Teispes, and Teispes, his father (was) Achaemenes. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: For that reason we call (our) family Achaemenids. From long ago (we) have been noble and from long ago our family has been kings. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: 8 kings in my family formerly held kingship. I held the 9th kingship. One after the other, we were kings. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I performed the kingship. Ahuramazda gave me the kingship. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: These (are) the nations who called (themselves) mine (and by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I placed the kingship over them: The Persians and the Elamites and the Babylonians and the Assyrians and the Arabians and the Egyptians and the Sea-People and the Sardians and the Ionians and the Medes and the Armenians and the Cappadocians and the Parthians and the Drangians and the Areians and the Chorasmians and Bactria and the Sogdians and Parauparisana(?) and the Scythians and Sattagydia and Arachosia and Maka, a grand(?) total (of) 23 nations. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: These nations who call (themselves) mine, (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, performed service unto me, brought me tribute, (and) whatever I commanded, night and day, they accomplished. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Throughout these nations, the man who(?) was(?) …, him (I) upheld; whoever injured, him greatly (I) investigated. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my law was upheld throughout these nations; whatever I commanded, that they accomplished. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Ahuramazda gave me this kingship and Ahuramazda sent me aid, until I strengthened this kingship, and (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I held kingship. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I did (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, after (I) received the kingship. Cambyses by name, Cyrus, his son, of our family, formerly(?) held kingship. That Cambyses, his brother was Smerdis by name, and (Cambyses from) mother (and) father was together with him and that Cambyses killed Smerdis. When Cambyses killed Smerdis the people didn’t know that Smerdis was dead. Then Cambyses went to Egypt. Then the people caused destruction; furthermore, the lies grew throughout the nations, both in Persia and in Media, and throughout other nations. And then, a man, a Magus Gaumata by name, he, from Naširma, a mountain, Harakkatarriš by name, from there 14 days of month Mikannaš had passed, thus (he) rose up. He lied to the people: I am Smerdis, Cyrus the son, Cambyses the brother. Then all the people rebelled against Cambyses and went (over) to him, both the Persians and the Medes and the other nations and(?) he held kingship. 9 days of month Karmabataš had passed, thus (the kingship) was seized(?) from Cambyses. And then Cambyses died of natural causes. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This kingship that Gaumata the Magus took away from Cambyses, this kingship for a long time belonged to our family. Accordingly, Gaumata the Magus took it away from Cambyses, both the Persians and the Medes and the other nations, he took them away from him and made (them) his possessions. He held kingship. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: There was no man, no-one(?), not a Persian or a Mede or (anyone) from our family, who received the kingship from Gaumata the Magus. The people greatly feared him. (He) slaughtered the people, (those) who formerly knew Smerdis. For that reason (he) slaughtered the people: lest (they) know me that I am not Smerdis, Cyrus, his son and no-one (with) anything related to Gaumata Magus came forth, until I came. After that I prayed to Ahuramazda. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, 10 days of month Bakeyatiš had passed, thus with a few men I killed Gaumata Magus and his accompanying men, his foremost followers, in a fortress, Shikkaumatiš by name, (in) Nušaya by name, a district in Media, there I killed him and I took away his kingship. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I held kingship. Ahuramazda gave me the kingship. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: The kingship that had been taken away from our family, that I brought back and I set in its place as it was formerly. Accordingly, and(?) I made the temple(s) of the gods that Gaumata the Magus had destroyed, and I restored to the people, to them, pasture lands(?) and herds and workers and the houses, as seized(?) (by people) that Gaumata the Magus had taken away from them, and I place the people in their places, both the Persians and the Medes and the other nations, and(?) accordingly as it was formerly. I, what had been taken away, that brought back. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, this I made. I exerted effort until (I) restored our house as it was formerly and I exerted effort, (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, that Gaumata the Magus hadn’t taken away our house. 
#tr.en: This is what was accomplished by me as formerly (I) held kingship. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: When I killed Gaumata the Magus, then Hašina by name, an Elamite, Ukbatarranma, his son, rose up in the Elamites’ (land and he) said: I held kingship of the Elamites. Then the Elamites rebelled against me and went (over) to that Hašina. Then he held kingship of the Elamites and both, one man Nidintu-Bēl by name, a Babylonian, Ḫanara, his son, he rose up in Babylon and (to) the people, thus, to them lied (and) said: I (am) Nebuchadnezzar, son of Nabonidus. Then all the Babylonian people went (over) to that Nidintu-Bēl. Then the Babylonians rebelled. He held kingship of the Babylonians. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then I sent a messenger to Elam that Hašina was seized and in shackles (he) was brought back to me. Then I killed him. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then I went to Babylon, to that Nidintu-Bēl, who said: I (am) Nebuchadnezzar. The troops of that Nidintu-Bēl, at the river Tigris by name, there, were deployed(?). (They) sized the bank(?) of the Tigris and that river was navigable. Then I supplied the troops with leather-skins; (another) remaining part, (I) placed them on camels, (for another) remaining part, on horses was placed. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, (we) went across the Tigris there, (I) killed the troops of that Nidintu-Bēl. 26 days of month Hashiyatiyasš had passed, thus (we) made battle. (I) killed many of his(?) troops there. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: then I went to Babylon. Before I arrived in Babylon, a town, Zazzan by name, situated on the Euphrates, there that Nidintu-Bēl, who said: Nebuchadnezzar attacked me together with troops in battle. Then (we) made battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) intercession of Ahuramazda, (I) killed the troops of that Nidintu-Bēl there. 2 days of month Hanamakaš had passed, thus we made battle. I slaughtered the troops of Nidintu-Bēl, and (others) who were fleeing to the river were carried away by this river. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then that Nidintu-Bēl together with several horsemen fled and went to Babylon. Then I went forth to Babylon and (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, (I) seized Babylon and that Nidintu-Bēl. Then I killed that Nidintu-Bēl in Babylon. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: While I was in Babylon these nations rebelled against me: The Persians and the Elamites and the Medes and the Assyrians and the Egyptians and the Parthians and the Margians and Sattagydia and the Scythians. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: One man, Martiya by name, Zinzakriš, his son, a town, Kukkannakan by name, in Persia, dwelt. He rose up in Elam and the people thus to them (he) said: I (am) Ummannuš, king of the Elamites, and at that time I was near Elam. Afterwards, the Elamites feared me; (they) seized that Martiya who called himself their chief, and killed him. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: One man, Phraortes by name, rose up in Media,  thus to the people said: I am Šattarrida of the family of Cyaxares. Then the Mede troops who were in the palace rebelled against me (and) went (over) to him. (He) held kingship in Media. The Persian and the Median troops with me were few. Then I sent forth the troops to Media. Hydarnes by name, a Persian, my servant, I made their chief, thus I said to them: Go forth! The Median troops who do not call themselves mine, kill them! Then Hydarnes together with the troops went off to the Media. When he went to Media, in the town, Maruš by name, in Media, there (he) did battle. (He) who was chief among the Medes wasn't present at that time. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 27 days of the month Hanamakaš had passed, thus (they) did battle. Then my troops did not accomplished anything. (In a) district, Kampantaš by name, in Media, there he awaited for me until I came to Media. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Daturšiš by name, an Armenian, my servant, I sent to the Armenia, thus I said to him: Go forth! The troops who (are) rebels (and) do not call themselves mine, kill them! Then Daturšiš went off. When (he) went to Armenia, the rebels assembled (and) came against Daturšiš: let us do battle! Then Daturšiš battled them in a village, Suzza by name, in Armenia. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 8 days of the month Turmar had passed, thus (they) did battle. And again (for) the 2nd (time) the rebels assembled (and) came against Daturšiš: let us do battle! Then at a fortress, Tigra by name, in Armenia, (they) did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 18 days of the month Turmar had passed, thus (they) did battle. And again (for) the 3rd (time) the rebels assembeled (and) came against Daturšiš: let us do battle! In a fortress, Wiyama by name, in Armenia (they) did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 9 days of the month Sakurriziš had passed, thus (they) did battle, and then Daturšiš did not accomplished anything. (He) awaited me until I came to Media. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Maumiša by name, a Persian, my servant, I sent forth to Armenia, thus (I) said him: Go forth! The troops who are rebels (and) don’t call themselves mine, kill them! Then Maumiša went (off). When (he) went (off) to Armenia, the rebels assembled (and) came against Maumiša: let us do battle! In Izzila by name in Assyria (they) did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 15 days of the month Hanamakaš had passed, thus (they) did battle. And again (for) the 2nd (time) the rebels assembled (and) came against Maumiša: let us do battle! In a district, Hautiyaruš by name, (they) did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. The month Turmar, at its end thus (they) did battle. Then Maumiša waited in Armenia until I came to Media. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then I came forth from Babylon and went to Media. When I went to Media, the town, Kuntarruš by name, in Media, that Phraortes, who said: I held kingship of the Medes, came to do battle. Then (we) did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I slaughtered the troops of Phraortes. 25 days of the month Hadukannaš had passed, thus (we) did battle. Then that Phraortes together with several horsemen fled and went to Rakkan. Then I sent the troops after him. From there (he) was seized and brought (back) to me. I cut off his nose and tongue and ears and I put out one eye, (and) at my gate (he) was bound and seized. All people saw him and then at Ecbatana I impaled him and the men who were his foremost followers. At a fortress in Ecbatana I cut off their heads. I displayed(?) all of them together. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: One man, Zišantakma by name, a Sagartian, rebelled against me and the to the people thus said: I held kingship. (I) am of the family of Cyaxares. Then I sent forth the Persian and the Median troops. Takmašbada by name, a Mede, my servant, I made him their chief, thus (I) said to them: Go forth! Rebellious troops (who) do not call themselves mine, kill them! Then Takmašbada together with troops went (off and) did battle with Zišantakma. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops and (they) seized Zišantakma (and) brought him to me. I cut off his nose and ears and put out one eye, and at my gate (he) was bound and seized. All people saw him. Then at Harbera by name, I impaled him. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I accomplished in Media. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: The Parthians and the Hyrcanians rebelled against me and called themselves those of Phraortes. Hystaspes, my father, was in Parthia. The troops abandoned him and rebelled and then Hystaspes together with troops at his side went (off and) in the town, Mišbauzatiš by name, in Parthia, (he) did battle (with) rebels. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, Hystaspes slaughtered the rebellious troops. 22 days of the month Miyakannaš had passed, thus (he) did battle. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then I sent the Persian troops from Rakkan to Hystaspes. When that troops went to Hystaspes, then Hystaspes together with troops went (off) to a town, Pattigrabban by name, in Parthia, (where he) made battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, Hystaspes slaughtered the rebellious troops. 1 day ot the month Karmabataš had passed, thus (he) made battle. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then the nation became mine. This is what I accomplished in Parthia. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: a nation, Margiana by name, rebelled against me, and one man, Pirrada by name, a Magian, made their kingship and then to Daturšiš by name, a Persian, my servant (who) had a satrapy in Bactria, I sent a messenger and (I) told (him) to go forth (and) kill the rebellious troops (who) do not call themselves mine. Then Daturšiš went (off) together with troops (and) did battle with the these Margians. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 23 days of the month Hašiyatiyaš had passed, thus (he) made battle. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then the nation became mine. This is what I accomplished in Bactria. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: One man, Mišdada by name, (in) the town, Turrauma by name, (in) Yautiyaš by name, in Persia, dwelled. He again(?) a second time(?) rose up in Persia and to the people said: I (am) Smerdis, the son of Cyrus. Then the Persian troops who were in the palace, formerly assembled from Anzan, they rebelled against me and went over to him. He held kingship in Persia. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then I sent forth the few Persian troops, who were in the palace (and) didn’t rebel against me, and the Mede troops who (were) mine. Irdumartiya, a Persian, my servant, I made their chief and the other Persian troops followed me in Media, and Irdumartiya went (off) to Persia. When he went to the Persia a town, Rakkan by name, … in Persia, that Mišdada who says I am Smerdis came together with troops against Irdumartiya to do battle and then did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the troops of Mišdada. 12 days of the month Turmar had passed, thus (he) did battle. And that Mišdada fled and together with several horsemen went to Naširma. From there again he came (with?) troops against Irdumartiya to do battle. In a mountain, Parrakka by name, (he) did battle. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the troops of Mišdada. 5 days of the month Karmapadaš had passed, thus (he) did battle and (Irdumartiya) seized that Mišdada and seized the men who were his foremost followers. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then (I) impaled that Mišdada together with the men who were his foremost followers in Mateziš by name(?). 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I did in Persia. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: That Mišdada who said: I am Smerdis, sent forth the troops to Arachosia (and) made a man their chief. Mimana by name, a Persian, my servant, (he) made the satrapy of Arachosia. Thus he said to them: Go forth! Kill Mimana and that troops who call themselves of Darius! Then that troops went forth to Arachosia to Mimana. (They) whom Mišdada sent forth at the fortress, Kappišakanuš by name, did battle with him. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 13 days of the month Hanamakaš had passed, thus (they) did battle. And again (for) the 2nd (time) the rebels assembled and did battle with Mimana in a district, Irdumaka by name, in Arachosia. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, my troops slaughtered the rebellious troops. 7 days of the month Miyakannaš had passed, thus (they) made battle. And then the man whom Mišdada made the chief of troops fled together with several horseman and went (off). He came to a fortress, Iršada by name, in Arachosia, a dwelling of Mimana. Then Mimana together with troops was set after him, and went. They seized and killed that man who called himself the chief of troops and the men who were his foremost followers. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Then (this) nation became mine. This is what I accomplished in Arachosia. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: While I was in Persia and Media, again (for) the 2nd (time) the Babylonians rebelled. A man, Harakka by name, an Armenian, the son of Haltida, in the town, Dubbala by name, in Babylon, rose up. Thus (he) lied and to the people said: I am Nebuchadnezzar the son of Nabonidus, and then the Babylonian people rebelled against me and went (over) to that Harakka, and he seized Babylon and he held kingship of Babylonia. And then I sent forth the troops to Babylon. Mindaparna by name, a Persian, my servant, I made their chief, thus I said them: Go forth! The Babylonian troops who don’t call themselves mine, kill them! And then Mindaparna went to Babylon together with troops. Ahuramazda sent me aid. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, Mindaparna slaughtered the Babylonians (and) led their troops shackled. 22 days of the month Markazanaš had passed, thus that Harraka who said I am Nebuchadnezzar was seized and the men who were his foremost followers together with him seized and bound. Then I ordered that Harraka and the men who were his foremost followers together with him imapled in Babylon. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I accomplished in Babylon. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I accomplished (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda; one year after that I held kingship. (I) did 19 battles. (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I killed them and seized 9 kings: A Gaumata by name, a magus, lied (and) said: I am Smerdis the son of Cyrus. He caused the Persians to rebel and Hašina by name, an Elamite, caused these Elamites to rebel and said: I held kingship of the Elamites and Nidintu-Bēl by name, a Babylonian, lied (and) said: I am Nebuchadnezzar, the son of Nabonidus. He caused the Babylonians to rebel and Martiya by name, a Persian, lied (and) said: I am Ummannuš, the king of the Elamites. He caused the Elamites to rebel and Phraortes by, name, a Mede, lied (and) said: I am Šattarida of the family of Cyaxares. He caused the Medes to rebel and Zišantakma by name, a Sagartian, lied (and) said: I held kingship. (I am) of the family of Cyaxares. He cause the Sagartians to rebel and Pirrada by name, a Margian, lied (and) said: I held kingship of Margians. He cause the Margians to rebel and Mišdada by name, a Persian, lied (and) said: I am Smerdis the son of Cyrus. He caused the Persians to rebel and Harakka by name, an Armenian, lied (and) said: I am Nebuchadnezzar, the son of Nabonidus. He caused these Babylonians to rebel. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: These are the 9 kings whom I seized in these battles. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: The nations who rebelled, the lie caused them to rebel, they lied to the people and then Ahuramazda put them into my hands, as I desired(?) I did (unto) them. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Whosover shall be king hereafter, guard yourself greatly from the lie! The man (who) lies, (greatly) investigate him! If thus you think: my nations are secure. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I accomplished in a year (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, and whosoever shall hearafter read the inscription that I made, believe in what is written therein, lest you think (it is) a lie! 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: (I as a) devotee(?) of Ahuramazda, as to the fact that this is truth, not a lie, (what) I accomplished in one year. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, much else has been done by me that (has) not been written in this inscription; for that reason may whoever reads this inscription hereafter think much that has been done by me, dand not believe (and) think, a lie. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Those who were formerly kings, as long as they lived, accomplished nothing like it (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, in one year. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Now, believe in what I accomplished! Thus speak to the people! Don’t conceal! If (you) don’t conceal this record (and) speak to the people, may Ahuramazda befriend you and your family and may you live for a long time. And if you ever conceal this record, do not speak to the people, may Ahuramazda kill you and may (you) not pour out your seed. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: This is what I accomplished (by) the intercession of Ahuramazda, (I) accomplished in one year. Ahuramazda, the god of Aryans, sent me aid and the other gods; 
#tr.en: and Darius the king says: For that reason Ahuramazda, the god of Aryans, sent me aid and the other gods, because I wasn’t hostile and wasn’t a liar and wasn’t a transgressor, neither I nor my family. I proceed (according to) the right and neither the strong (person) nor weak (person) I did transgress against. The man who coorporated with my house, him I greatly upheld and who injured, him I greatly investigated. (I) didn’t transgress against anyone. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Whosover shall be king hereafter, the man (who) lies, don’t befriend him, neither (the man) who transgressed. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Whosover shall hereafter see the inscription that I wrote down, don’t destroy these sculptures (and) the sculptured likeness(?). Protect them as long as you have strength! And if (you) see this inscription (and) these sculptures and don’t destroy them, as long as you have strength, protect (them), may Ahuramazda befriend you and your family and may you live for a long time, and whatever you do, may Ahuramazda make that successful, but if (you) destroy this inscription and (these) sculptures (and) don’t protect (them), may Ahuramazda kill you and may (you) not pour out your seed! And whatever you do, may Ahuramazda destroy it. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: Mindaparna by name, Mišparra, his son, a Persian and Huttana by name Dukkurra, his son a Persian and Kambarma by name Mardunuya, his son, a Persian, and Mitarna by name, Bakapikna, his son, a Persian, and Bakapukša by name, Dadumanya, his son, a Persian, and Irdumannuš, Mawukka, his son, a Persian. These men were helpful (for) me when I killed Gaumata the Magus, who said: I am Smerdis the son of Cyrus, and in that time these men brought me help. Whosover shall be king hereafter, protect the family of these men! 
#tr.en: I (am) Darius, the king, Hystaspes, his son, an Achaemenid, king of kings, I (am) …, king in Persia. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: I, my father (was) Hystaspes, and Hystaspes, his father (was) Arsames, and Arsames, his father (was) Ariaramnes, and Ariaramnes, his father (was) Teispes, and Teispes, his father (was) Achaemenes. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: For that reason we, (our) family, Achaemenids are called. From long ago (we) have been noble and from long ago our family have been kings. 
#tr.en: And Darius the king says: 8 kings in my family formerly held kingship, I was the 9th king. One after another(?), we were kings. 
#tr.en: This is Gaumata the Magus, (who) lied (and) said: I (am) Smerdis, the son of Cyrus. I held kingship. 
#tr.en: This is Hasšina (who) lied (and) said: I held kingship of the Elamites. 
#tr.en: This is Nidintu-Bēl (who) lied (and) said: I (am) Nebuchadnezzar son of Nabonidus. (I) held kingship of the Babylonians. 
#tr.en: This is Phraortes (who) lied (and) said: I am Šattarridda of the family of Cyaxares. I held kingship of the Medes. 
#tr.en: This is Martiya (who) lied (and) said: I (am) Ummanuš. (I) held kingship of the Elamites. 
#tr.en: This is Zišantakma (who) lied (and) said: I (am) of the family of Cyaxares. I held kingship of the Sagartians. 
#tr.en: This is Mišdada (who) lied (and) said: I (am) Smerdis, the son of Cyrus. I held kingship. 
#tr.en: This is Harakka (who) lied (and) said: I (am) Nebuchadnezzar, son of Nabonidus. (I) held kingship of the Babylonians. 
#tr.en: This is Pirrada (who) lied (and) said: I held kingship of the Margians. 
#tr.en: This is Iškunka, who is Scythian. 
#tr.en: Darius the king says: (By) the intercession of Ahuramazda, I created a text elsewhere in Aryan that did not formerly exist, neither on clay (tablets) nor on parchment, (and) both the name and lineage(?) (I) created, so that it was written down and read before me. Then I sent this text throughout all nations. The people copied (it). 
#tr.en: For Gilgamesh 
#tr.en: his king, 
#tr.en: for the might(?) 
#tr.en: of Gungunum, 
#tr.en: the Amorite chief 
#tr.en: and king of Ur, 
#tr.en: did ...ingatum, 
#tr.en: your servant, 
#tr.en: son of Ilī-maraḫ, 
#tr.en: his house 
#tr.en: build. 
#tr.en: 40 male laborers, 1/2 labor, 
#tr.en: for 6 years, 
#tr.en: they being fishermen; 
#tr.en: from year following: “For the 3rd time Simurrum was destroyed,”
#tr.en: to the year following: “The wall was erected;” 
#tr.en: 4 mana silver, 
#tr.en: silver of the fisheries-tithe; 
#tr.en: under seal of Umani. 
#tr.en: 2 oxen, grain-fed,
#tr.en: 19th day;
#tr.en: from Abbasaga
#tr.en: Aḫu-wer
#tr.en: accepted;
#tr.en: month “kisiki-of-Ninazu,”
#tr.en: year: “Ḫuḫnuri was destroyed;”
#tr.en: (total:) 2 oxen.
#tr.en: 10 less 1 lambs, 
#tr.en: 1 billy, 
#tr.en: 30th day, 
#tr.en: from Abbasaga 
#tr.en: did Intae’a  
#tr.en: accept; 
#tr.en: month “Big-festival,”
#tr.en: year: “Šašru was destroyed;” 
#tr.en: (total:) 10. 
#tr.en: Ka-kugani, 
#tr.en: priest of Enlil: 
#tr.en: Inanna-ka, 
#tr.en: his wife. 
#tr.en: Imgur-Sin, 
#tr.en: the administrator, 
#tr.en: son of Sin-idinnam, 
#tr.en: servant of Sin-magir. 
#tr.en: Akšakia, 
#tr.en: servant of Sūmû-la-Il 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: servant of Hammurapi.
#tr.en: I would praise the lord of wisdom, the circumspect god, 
#tr.en: who rages at night, reconciling by day; 
#tr.en: Marduk, lord of wisdom, circumspect god, 
#tr.en: who rages at night, reconciling by day; 
#tr.en: who like a storm, a whilrwind, causes desolation his rage, 
#tr.en: and (then) as a breeze of the morning, his breath sweet; 
#tr.en: in his anger unapproachable, a flood his fury; 
#tr.en: attentive his mind, his liver is merciful; 
#tr.en: the n. of whose hand cannot bear the heavens, 
#tr.en: whose tender hand holds back the dead; 
#tr.en: Marduk, the n. of whose hand cannot bear the heavens, 
#tr.en: whose tender hand holds back the dead; 
#tr.en: through whose rage are opened the graves, 
#tr.en: then from disaster he raised the fallen; 
#tr.en: he frowns, do exit the guardian and protective spirit, 
#tr.en: he looks on, and to the one whom he pushed away, his god turns; 
#tr.en: where momentarily his overbearing punishment is heavy, 
#tr.en: yet he showed pity, and turns into his own mother, 
#tr.en: He becomes pointed, and his inner wild bull butts, 
#tr.en: then like a cow to calf, he constantly turns round to his back; 
#tr.en: stinging are his beatings, piercing the body, 
#tr.en: cooling his bandages, reviving the deceased; 
#tr.en: he speaks, and sin spreads, 
#tr.en: yet on the day of his prosperity, excused are obligation and guilt; 
#tr.en: he is it who utukku and tremors lets have, 
#tr.en: yet his spell drives away frost and chills; 
#tr.en: who multiplies the flooding of Adad, the blows of Erra, 
#tr.en: yet who placates the angry god and goddess; 
#tr.en: the lord the entire stomach of the gods inspects, 
#tr.en: and no one among the gods his path knows, 
#tr.en: Marduk the entire stomach of the gods inspects, 
#tr.en: but no god comes to understand his mind; 
#tr.en: as heavy his hand, so his stomach merciful, 
#tr.en: as cruel his weapons, so his liver revives; 
#tr.en: absent his stomach, who his blows would pacify? 
#tr.en: Without his weightiness, who would causes to hang his hands? 
#tr.en: I would glorify his wrath, as one who like fish ate mud, 
#tr.en: he penalized as quickly as he revives the dead; 
#tr.en: how near is their salvation, 
#tr.en: that his good remembrance would their sins lift; 
#tr.en: on the day the lord punished me, 
#tr.en: the hero Marduk became angry with me, 
#tr.en: rejects me my god, up his mountain went, 
#tr.en: ceased my goddess, went to the foriegn region, 
#tr.en: split away the good šēdu-spirit of my side, 
#tr.en: fearful was my lamassu-spirit, a second one sought out, 
#tr.en: taken away was my strength, my manliness darkened; 
#tr.en: my essence flew off, onto the roof jumped, 
#tr.en: established for me were the signs of terror, 
#tr.en: expelled from my house, outside I wandered; 
#tr.en: confused were my omens, swollen all day, 
#tr.en: with diviner and dream interpreter, my path is not distinct; 
#tr.en: in the entry of the street, ominous my oracular expressions, 
#tr.en: I lay down in the second watch, and my dream was frightening: 
#tr.en: the king, flesh of the gods, sun of his people, 
#tr.en: his stomach was knotted up, and he was making its loosening very difficult, 
#tr.en: the administrators slander let constantly fly against me, 
#tr.en: gathered themselves, and made stick maliciousness. 
#tr.en: If the first one: ‟His life I'll make him pour out,” 
#tr.en: is saying the second, “I’ll raise (him) up from his post;” 
#tr.en: who like the third, “his appointment I will seize." 
#tr.en: “I will enter in his house,” the fourth swears 
#tr.en: the fifth: “the mouth of the lung was turned over,” 
#tr.en: the sixth and seventh follow in his šēdu-spirit. 
#tr.en: They joined up against me, the band of seven, their gang; 
#tr.en: like a storm without mercy, evil demons matching, 
#tr.en: and one was their flesh, and each by (word of) mouth making known, 
#tr.en: raging against me, burning like a fire, 
#tr.en: malicious talk and obstruction they cause to join forces against me, 
#tr.en: my noble mouth as with a bridle they bound, 
#tr.en: my lips that were in constant motion became as to a deaf man; 
#tr.en: my loud roar escaped into silence; 
#tr.en: my high head bowed to the ground; 
#tr.en: my fulsome stomach the horror weakened; 
#tr.en: my broad chest, into (that of) a small man changed; 
#tr.en: my far-reaching arms were bound together; 
#tr.en: I who as a lord was walking, to crawl I learned; 
#tr.en: I was such a one as was prideful, but I turned into a slave; 
#tr.en: (born) to an extended family, I became a loner; 
#tr.en: the street I am traversing, and stretched out are fingers; 
#tr.en: I enter to the palace, and in fast movement are the eyes; 
#tr.en: my city, like an enemy, is looking at me with an evil eye. 
#tr.en: It was as a furious enemy, my land; 
#tr.en: into a stranger my brother turned; 
#tr.en: into an evil one and a gallê-demon has turned my friend; 
#tr.en: an enraged companion denounces me; 
#tr.en: my colleague always dirties the weapon; 
#tr.en: my sweet friend cuts off my life; 
#tr.en: openly in an assembly cursed me my male slave; 
#tr.en: my female slave before gatherings slander against me spoke; 
#tr.en: an acquaintance saw me, and he leaned in to the the corner; 
#tr.en: as one not of its flesh established me my family; 
#tr.en: for who spoke of my goodness, opened up for him a tomb; 
#tr.en: who swore to my slander was moved to the head; 
#tr.en: who pronounced my defamation, a god was his aid; 
#tr.en: to the one who said “Mercy!,” quickly to him came death; 
#tr.en: who was not hesitant, swore health his šēdu (spirit); 
#tr.en: I had no-one at my side, mercy I did not experience; 
#tr.en: to the bands and thugs they distributed all that I own; 
#tr.en: the mouth of my river they measured out with silt; 
#tr.en: from my farmlands they sent out the work song; 
#tr.en: like the city of an enemy, they let grow silent my city; 
#tr.en: my offices they let take another; 
#tr.en: and to my cultic duties a stranger they stationed. 
#tr.en: A day of weariness, a night of wailing; 
#tr.en: a month of anxious silence, misery the year; 
#tr.en: like a dove I mourn all my days, 
#tr.en: singers my lamentation make loud; 
#tr.en: in constant weaping were caused to see my eyes; 
#tr.en: fifty times over, in tears burned my cheeks; 
#tr.en: blackened my face the darkness of my stomach; 
#tr.en: my skin turned yellow did terror and panic, 
#tr.en: the ‘sources’ of my stomach in constant panic trembled, 
#tr.en: it burned like a thousand suns, 
#tr.en: like a flame blazing turned my supplication; 
#tr.en: like strife and brawl was my prayer, 
#tr.en: I sweetened my lips, like a lance stiff, 
#tr.en: like salt I swore, a bolt is my interpreter; 
#tr.en: I hope, at daybreak comes a good thing to me; 
#tr.en: the moon becomes visible, shines my sun. 
#tr.en: I survived to the next year; the appointed time passed. 
#tr.en: As I turn round, it is terrible, it is so terrible; 
#tr.en: My ill luck has increased, and I do not find the right. 
#tr.en: I called to my god, but he did not show his face, 
#tr.en: I prayed to my goddess, but she did not raise her head. 
#tr.en: The diviner with his inspection has not got to the root of the matter, 
#tr.en: nor with a libation has the dream interpreter elucidated my case. 
#tr.en: I sought the favor of the zaqzīqu-spirit, but he did not enlighten me; 
#tr.en: And the incantation priest with his ritual did not appease the divine wrath against me. 
#tr.en: What strange conditions everywhere! 
#tr.en: When I look behind, there is persecution, trouble. 
#tr.en: Like one who has not made libations to his god, 
#tr.en: Nor invoked his goddess at table, 
#tr.en: Does not engage in prostration, nor takes cognizance of bowing down; 
#tr.en: From whose mouth supplication and prayer is lacking, 
#tr.en: Who has done nothing on holy days, and despised sabbaths, 
#tr.en: Who in his negligence has despised the gods’ rites, 
#tr.en: Has not taught his people reverence and worship, 
#tr.en: But has eaten his food without invoking his god, 
#tr.en: And abandoned his goddess by not bringing a flour offering, 
#tr.en: Like one who has grown torpid and forgotten his lord, 
#tr.en: Has frivolously sworn a solemn oath by his god, (like such an one) do I appear. 
#tr.en: For myself, I gave attention to supplication and prayer: 
#tr.en: To me prayer was discretion, sacrifice my rule. 
#tr.en: The day for reverencing the god was a joy to my heart; 
#tr.en: The day of the goddess’s procession was profit and gain to me. 
#tr.en: The king’s prayer-that was my joy, 
#tr.en: And the accompanying music became a delight for me. 
#tr.en: I instructed my land to keep the god’s rites, 
#tr.en: And provoked my people to value the goddess’s name. 
#tr.en: I made praise for the king like a god’s, 
#tr.en: And taught the populace reverence for the palace. 
#tr.en: I wish I knew that these things were pleasing to one’s god! 
#tr.en: What is proper to oneself is an offence to one’s god, 
#tr.en: What in one’s own heart seems despicable is proper to one’s god, 
#tr.en: Who knows the will of the gods in heaven? 
#tr.en: Who understands the plans of the underworld gods? 
#tr.en: Where have mortals learnt the way of a god? 
#tr.en: He who was alive yesterday is dead today. 
#tr.en: For a minute he was dejected, suddenly he is exuberant, 
#tr.en: One moment people are singing in exaltation, 
#tr.en: Another they groan like professional mourners. 
#tr.en: Their condition changes like opening and shutting (the legs). 
#tr.en: When starving they become like corpses, 
#tr.en: When replete they vie with their gods. 
#tr.en: In prosperity they speak of scaling heaven, 
#tr.en: Under adversity they complain of going down to hell. 
#tr.en: I am appalled at these things; I do not understand their significance. 
#tr.en: As for me, the exhausted one, a tempest is driving me! 
#tr.en: Debilitating Disease is let loose upon me: 
#tr.en: An Evil Wind has blown from the horizon, 
#tr.en: Headache has sprung up from the surface of the underworld, 
#tr.en: An Evil Cough has left its Apsu, 
#tr.en: The irresistible Ghost left Ekur, 
#tr.en: The Lamastu-demon came down from the Mountain, 
#tr.en: Cramp set out from ... the flood, 
#tr.en: Impotence cleaves the ground along with the grass. 
#tr.en: ... their host, fogether they came on me. 
#tr.en: ... head, they enveloped my skull; 
#tr.en: My face is gloomy, my eyes are in flood. 
#tr.en: They have wrenched my neck muscles and taken the strength from my neck. 
#tr.en: They struck my chest, drubbing my breast. 
#tr.en: They affected my flesh and caused convulsions, 
#tr.en: In my epigastrium they kindled a fire. 
#tr.en: They upset my bowels ... . 
#tr.en: Causing the discharge of phlegm, they brought on a fever in my lungs. 
#tr.en: They caused fever in my limbs and made my fat quake. 
#tr.en: My lofty stature they destroyed like a wall, 
#tr.en: My robust figure they laid down like a bulrush, 
#tr.en: I am thrown down like a bog plant and cast on my face. 
#tr.en: The alu-demon has clothed himself in my body as with a garment; 
#tr.en: Sleep covers me like a net. 
#tr.en: My eyes stare, but do not see, 
#tr.en: My ears are open, but do not hear. 
#tr.en: Feebleness has seized my whole body, 
#tr.en: Concussion has fallen upon my flesh. 
#tr.en: Paralysis has grasped my arms, 
#tr.en: Impotence has fallen on my knees, 
#tr.en: My feet forget their motion. 
#tr.en: A stroke has got me; I choke like someone prostrate. 
#tr.en: ... death, it has covered my face. 
#tr.en: The dream priest mentions me, but I do not respond. 
#tr.en: ... weep, but I have no control of my faculties. 
#tr.en: A snare is . laid on my mouth, 
#tr.en: And a bolt bars my lips. 
#tr.en: My ’gate’ is barred, my ’drinking place’ blocked, 
#tr.en: My hunger is prolonged, my throat stopped up. 
#tr.en: When grain is served, I eat it like stinkweed, 
#tr.en: Beer, the life of mankind, is distasteful to me. 
#tr.en: My malady is indeed protracted. 
#tr.en: Through lack of food my countenance is changed, 
#tr.en: My flesh is flaccid, and my blood has ebbed away. 
#tr.en: My bones have corne apart, and are covered (only) with my skin. 
#tr.en: My tissues are inflamed, and have caught the ...-disease. 
#tr.en: I take to a bed of bondage; going out is a pain; 
#tr.en: My house has become my prison. 
#tr.en: My arms are stricken-which shackles my flesh; 
#tr.en: My feet are limp-which fetters my person. 
#tr.en: My afflictions are grievous, my wound is severe. 
#tr.en: A scourge has thrown me down, the stroke is intense. 
#tr.en: The crop pierces me and the spur is severe. 
#tr.en: All day long the tormentor torments me, 
#tr.en: Nor at night does he let me relax for a minute. 
#tr.en: Through twisting my sinews are parted, 
#tr.en: My limbs are splayed and knocked apart. 
#tr.en: I spend the night in my dung like an ox, 
#tr.en: And wallow in my excrement like a sheep. 
#tr.en: My complaints have exposed the incantation priest, 
#tr.en: And my omens have confounded the diviner. 
#tr.en: The exorcist has not diagnosed the nature of my complaint, 
#tr.en: Nor has the diviner put a time limit on my illness. 
#tr.en: My god has not come to the rescue in taking me by the hand, 
#tr.en: Nor has my goddess shown pity on me by going at my side. 
#tr.en: My grave was waiting, and my funerary paraphernalia ready, 
#tr.en: Before I had died lamentation for me was finished. 
#tr.en: All my country said, “How he is crushed!” 
#tr.en: The face of him who gloats lit up when he heard, 
#tr.en: The tidings reached her who gloats, and her heart rejoiced. 
#tr.en: But I know the day for my whole family, 
#tr.en: When, among my friends, their Sun will have mercy. 
#tr.en: Heavy his hand, I was not able to bear it, 
#tr.en: frightening was his fearsomeness ... 
#tr.en: his punishment fiece was a flood, and ... 
#tr.en: arduous was his way, ... 
#tr.en: the severe disease was heavy. My self not ... 
#tr.en: of my wakefullness I was forgetful; they make me wander ... 
#tr.en: day and night alike I was wailing; 
#tr.en: dream, daydream equally are insufferable for me, 
#tr.en: one young man, superior in form, 
#tr.en: in physique prideful, in clothing renewed, 
#tr.en: because in dreaming his sides of form were deprived, 
#tr.en: in fearsome radiance he was covered, clothed in fear, 
#tr.en: he entered and stood over me. 
#tr.en: I saw him, paralyzed my flesh, 
#tr.en: and he said, “Your lord sent me.” 
#tr.en: ... he stood, sickening ... 
#tr.en: “Gather, and I will speak of their thoughts, 
#tr.en: they whom the king who sent, the people 
#tr.en: grew silent; no one answered me, 
#tr.en: those who heard me I was observing, and 
#tr.en: A second time, a dream I see, 
#tr.en: in the dream that I saw at night, 
#tr.en: one cleansing priest carrying a water basin 
#tr.en: a tamarisk purifying grasped in his hand: 
#tr.en: “Laluralimma, sorceress of Nippur, 
#tr.en: to purify you sent me.” 
#tr.en: water that he carried over me he poured, 
#tr.en: the spell of life he cast rubbed on my body. 
#tr.en: A third time, a dream I see, 
#tr.en: in the dream that I saw at night, 
#tr.en: one maid, beautiful her countenance, 
#tr.en: like people dressed, (but) a god equal, 
#tr.en: a queen of the people ... 
#tr.en: she entered, and sat at my side, 
#tr.en: saying, “Enough! Greatly he was distressed. 
#tr.en: Do not fear!” She said to me and made firm my stomach. 
#tr.en: and in whatever dream he saw, ... 
#tr.en: and she said, “Enough! Greatly he was distressed.” 
#tr.en: anyone who in the second watch of the night witnessed a vision. 
#tr.en: In the dream Ur-Nintinuga I see, 
#tr.en: a bearded young man, bearing his crown, 
#tr.en: an incanttion priest carrying a writing board: 
#tr.en: “Marduk sent me, 
#tr.en: In his pure hands, he brought a bandage, 
#tr.en: for my personal assistant into his hand he entrusted, 
#tr.en: in the dream he sent the message, 
#tr.en: his favorable sign to my people he revealed, 
#tr.en: from sickness the snake coiled had stolen away, 
#tr.en: my illness suddenly was passed, broken my cuffs, 
#tr.en: since my lord’s stomach has calmed, 
#tr.en: of merciful Marduk his liver released, 
#tr.en: he took my petition, the requests ... 
#tr.en: his good attention he uncovered ..., 
#tr.en: saying, “Enough! Greatly is he troubled.” 
#tr.en: his ... to proclaim ... 
#tr.en: ... to labor and ... 
#tr.en: ... the sin ... 
#tr.en: ... divine punishment ... 
#tr.en: ... my guilt ... 
#tr.en: my transgressions he let carry off the wind, 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... like ... 
#tr.en: He has brought near his spell instead of cough, 
#tr.en: he has driven away Evil Wind to the horizon; 
#tr.en: to the edge of the netherworld, he took away the dī’u(-disease), 
#tr.en: he has sent down to its Deep the evil cough; 
#tr.en: the irresistible utukku he sent back to Ekur, 
#tr.en: he overwhelmed Lamaštu, to the mountain he let her climb up; 
#tr.en: the crowns of the seas the chill he made take away, 
#tr.en: the base of debility he tore out like grass; 
#tr.en: my bad sleep, poured out restfulness, 
#tr.en: like smoke that filled the heavens he sent off; 
#tr.en: woe and grief, pushing and shaking, 
#tr.en: he made rise like a fog and made descend to the netherworld; 
#tr.en: persistent headache, like a grinding-stone heavy, 
#tr.en: he lifted like dew of the night, from me he removed; 
#tr.en: my afflicted eyes that were covered with the pall of the death, 
#tr.en: he made rise a multitude of double-hours; he made bright my vision; 
#tr.en: from my ears that were clogged and blocked like those of a deaf person, 
#tr.en: he took away their obstruction, he opened my hearing; 
#tr.en: my nose that in pursuit of fever was stopped its breathing, 
#tr.en: he soothed its affliction and I breathed immediately; 
#tr.en: from my lips, that were raging and taking harsh words, 
#tr.en: he wiped away their terror and loosened their knot; 
#tr.en: my mouth, that was covered and for speaking stiff, 
#tr.en: he polished like a qû-(jar), its filth he wiped away; 
#tr.en: my teeth, caught and as one bound, 
#tr.en: he opened their restraints and their roots let speak; 
#tr.en: the tongue, bound and to wag unable, 
#tr.en: its fatty coating he cleared and sharp was my speech; 
#tr.en: for the windpipe, shut up and stopped as with a lump, 
#tr.en: he relieved the chest that like a reed pipe he let sing; 
#tr.en: the larynx, blocked up and unable to get air, 
#tr.en: its scales he sent straight off and its blockage opened; 
#tr.en: ... of mine are high, its rain ... 
#tr.en: ... piled-up high, he pours on ... 
#tr.en: ... veiled like being buried, ... 
#tr.en: his ..., a song .... 
#tr.en: The large intestine, in hunger raised, like a basket joined together, 
#tr.en: ... water, its meadow, ... 
#tr.en: it shall receive meal, it shall bring the drink. 
#tr.en: ... I flourished ... 
#tr.en: xxx 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: My neck, whose roots become loose and bent down, 
#tr.en: he made strong the mountain and like a fir-tree fixed it upright; 
#tr.en: to that of a wrestler my physical power he made equal; 
#tr.en: like a boil taking out, he trimmed my finger-nails; 
#tr.en: he drove out their fatigue, their filth made good; 
#tr.en: Like a tower ..., 
#tr.en: inside ... 
#tr.en: My knees, bound and like a partridge cramped, 
#tr.en: he has made the legs straight like ... 
#tr.en: my feet that lay wasted ..., 
#tr.en: my strength taken away ...; 
#tr.en: the form of my body widened ...; 
#tr.en: my limbs ...; 
#tr.en: body, my limbs, ...; 
#tr.en: clad like ... 
#tr.en: the discharge of ... 
#tr.en: he wiped off frost, its filth cleared; 
#tr.en: manliness flickering is flashing, 
#tr.en: on the bank of River, where judgment of people is determined, 
#tr.en: ... of ... 
#tr.en: ... gods ... 
#tr.en: ... goddesses penalties ... 
#tr.en: ... they placed them, utterance ... 
#tr.en: ... both ... 
#tr.en: ... I have been tormented ... 
#tr.en: ... with him, healing is established, ... 
#tr.en: ... he healed me, his punishment ...; 
#tr.en: on the forehead I was struck, from slavery I was released. 
#tr.en: ... like a lion(?) ... 
#tr.en: ... snake ... 
#tr.en: ... bent over ... 
#tr.en: ... in Esagil a šigû I recited; 
#tr.en: ... of mine, the šigû ... 
#tr.en: Kunuš-kadru street in freedom I was traversing, 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: Zarpanītu I trust(?) ... 
#tr.en: my god I trust(?) ... 
#tr.en: my goddess I trust(?) ... 
#tr.en: who does not fear his god ... 
#tr.en: who does not fear his goddess ... 
#tr.en: who to Esagil is negligent my example shall see, 
#tr.en: who to Babylon ... 
#tr.en: painful deeds ... 
#tr.en: morning ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: My lord relieved me, 
#tr.en: my lord bandaged me; 
#tr.en: my lord released me; 
#tr.en: my lord healed me; 
#tr.en: from the pit he took me away; 
#tr.en: up from the grave dug me; 
#tr.en: from the annihilation raised me; 
#tr.en: from the Ḫubur-river pulled me; 
#tr.en: in the adversity my hand held; 
#tr.en: from the right side struck me, 
#tr.en: from the left side, held high my head; 
#tr.en: struck the hands of my beater, 
#tr.en: made fall his weapon did Marduk; 
#tr.en: in the mouth of the lion devouring me 
#tr.en: put a muzzle did Marduk; 
#tr.en: Marduk, that of my capturer, 
#tr.en: took away his sling, his sling-stone turned away; 
#tr.en: from the hand of my burier the spade he took away; 
#tr.en: from the hands of my male wailer made fall the harp?; 
#tr.en: the mouth of the female wailer from wailing stopped; 
#tr.en: the mouth of my ill-wisher with woe filled; 
#tr.en: the mouth of my lady ill-wisher ... 
#tr.en: he cast a mourning-ritual ...; 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: to the city square ... he will take me; 
#tr.en: to the presence of ... let me enter; 
#tr.en: my ill-wisher who ... destroyed? did Marduk, 
#tr.en: my lady ill-wisher who ..., held back did Ṣarpanītu. 
#tr.en: Who might it be? The lord released me! 
#tr.en: let life quickly come to an end! 
#tr.en: to the netherworld I am descending! 
#tr.en: in ghostliness I am wandering around! 
#tr.en: Who might it be? Marduk spared me. 
#tr.en: to the body of the asakku I am counted; 
#tr.en: a corpse I am wandering around, yes! 
#tr.en: In a full mēsū have they purified me. 
#tr.en: the bathing ritual, the restoration of aged they repeatedly performed; 
#tr.en: he swore that in the supplication he heard ... 
#tr.en: for brick-of-nose and prayer, to esagil I went up, 
#tr.en: having come down and returned from the grave, through Bāb-erēb-Šamši I entered; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-ḫegalli abundance was given me, 
#tr.en: at Bāb-Lamassu my spirit approached me; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-šulmi well-being I saw; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-balāṭi life I received; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-ṣīt-Šamši among the living I was counted; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-tabrīti my signs became bright; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-paṭār-arni my penalty was cleared; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-dalīli they questioned my mouth; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-paṭār my distress was released; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-mê-ellīti with purification water I was sprinkled; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-šulmi Marduk I met; 
#tr.en: at Bāb-râši the foot of Ṣarpanītu I kissed; 
#tr.en: while entreaty and devotions before them I was offering, 
#tr.en: fragrant incense before them I burnt; 
#tr.en: I presented donations, gifts, presents laid against each other; 
#tr.en: I slaughtered a fat bull, I butchered high-quality sheep; 
#tr.en: I have repeatedly made libation of syrup beer (and) pure wine; 
#tr.en: (of) the šēdu (and) lamassu, the (divine) attendants, the brickwork of Esagil, 
#tr.en: with libation, their liver I made glow, 
#tr.en: with exceeding meal, I made their stomach rejoice; 
#tr.en: the door jamb, the bolt, the bar of the doors, 
#tr.en: I drenched (with) sesame oil, ghee, and abundance of grain; 
#tr.en: ... the experts? of the ordinance of the cult; 
#tr.en: beer of red grain I gave them to drink; 
#tr.en: I repeatedly sprinkled sweet cypress-oil on them ... 
#tr.en: The banquets, the Babylonian, ... 
#tr.en: “the house of his burial” they performed during the banquets; 
#tr.en: theye saw, the Babylonians, how they could revive his servant, 
#tr.en: all the districts proclaimed their greatness: 
#tr.en: “Who spoke of seeing his sun? 
#tr.en: In the stomach of whom arose, traversing the his street? 
#tr.en: Other than Marduk who his dead ones revived? 
#tr.en: For Ṣarpanītu which goddess expect granted his life? 
#tr.en: Marduk in the grabe can revive. 
#tr.en: Ṣarpanītu from annihilation to save sees. 
#tr.en: Wherever is laid the land and is stretched out the heaven, 
#tr.en: the sun shines and the fire is lit, 
#tr.en: water flows, blows the wind, 
#tr.en: those whose clay aruru pinched off, 
#tr.en: the living creatures that open the legs, 
#tr.en: the people, as many as exist, Marduk praise!” 
#tr.en: ... those that (by) the mouth are established; 
#tr.en: ... all the people may he rule; 
#tr.en: ... herding all the lands; 
#tr.en: ... the seasonal flood from the deep may come out; 
#tr.en: ... to the dais of the gods may he bring 
#tr.en: ... all over the heavens and earth 
#tr.en: ... aid and protection; 
#tr.en: their ... may they carry him; 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: ... luminary, may he ... 
#tr.en: ... and seas, ... 
#tr.en: ... 
#tr.en: may he establish long days of his reign ... 
#tr.en: living creatures may he ... of his, 
#tr.en: ... days ... life; 
#tr.en: of esagil ... into apsû may stretch (down) its roots(?); 
#tr.en: like the stars in the sky, may he spread the progeny; 
#tr.en: Nazi-murutaš ... and neglected(?); 
#tr.en: living creatures ..., 
#tr.en: ... entire, turned into his city; 
#tr.en: ... may the lord the people, the black-headed, rule; 
#tr.en: as before the mercy of Marduk; 
#tr.en: let me proclaim ... esagil(?) and Babylon, the proud royal light; 
#tr.en: ... may he command my goodness 
#tr.en: ... the joy of life may he enjoy; 
#tr.en: ... the heavenly care may he have; 
#tr.en: ... may he ease his wailing; 
#tr.en: ... over his subjects; 
#tr.en: ... Šubši-mešrâ-Šakkan 
#tr.en: ... king(?) of the land of Sumer and Akkad, who leads the land; 
#tr.en: once his painful behaviour he has seen, should be absolved his crime; 
#tr.en: ... his grief should be eased; 
#tr.en: may his god praise him, may his goddess honor him; 
#tr.en: ... may people become healthy; 
#tr.en: may his god praise him, may his goddess honor him; 
#tr.en: in happiness of flesh and joy of stomach, may he walk daily; 
#tr.en: ... a praise song ... Šubši-mešrâ-Šakkan 
#tr.en: extolled your glory, ... your praise is good! 
#tr.en: A bronze (jar) for pouring beer 
#tr.en: for Banaya-x-Enlila 
#tr.en: the gudu(-priest) of Ninlil, 
#tr.en: son of Ša-ili-banaya 
#tr.en: When on high the heaven had not been named, 
#tr.en: Firm ground below had not been called by name, 
#tr.en: When primordial Apsu, their begetter, 
#tr.en: And Mummu-Tiamat, she who bore them all, 
#tr.en: Their waters mingled as a single body, 
#tr.en: No reed hut had sprung forth, no marshland had appeared, 
#tr.en: None of the gods had been brought into being, 
#tr.en: And none bore a name, and no destinies determined-- 
#tr.en: Then it was that the gods were formed in the midst of heaven. 
#tr.en: Lahmu and Lahamu were brought forth, by name they were called. (10) 
#tr.en: Before they had grown in age and stature, 
#tr.en: Anshar and Kishar were formed, surpassing the others. 
#tr.en: Long were the days, then there came forth..... 
#tr.en: Anu was their heir, of his fathers the rival; 
#tr.en: Yes, Anshar’s first-born, Anu, was his equal. 
#tr.en: Anu begot in his image Nudimmud. 
#tr.en: This Nudimmud was of his fathers the master; 
#tr.en: Of broad wisdom, understanding, mighty in strength, 
#tr.en: Mightier by far than his grandfather, Anshar. 
#tr.en: He had no rival among the gods, his brothers. (20) 
#tr.en: Thus were established and were... the great gods. 
#tr.en: They disturbed Tiamat as they surged back and forth, 
#tr.en: Yes, they troubled the mood of Tiamat 
#tr.en: By their hilarity in the Abode of Heaven. 
#tr.en: Apsu could not lessen their clamor 
#tr.en: And Tiamat was speechless at their ways. 
#tr.en: Their doings were loathsome unto ... . 
#tr.en: Thier way was evil; they were overbearing. 
#tr.en: Then Apsu, the begetter of the great gods, 
#tr.en: Cried out, addressing Mummu, his minister: (30) 
#tr.en: “O Mummu, my vizier, who rejoices my spirit, 
#tr.en: Come here and let us go to Tiamat!” 
#tr.en: They went and sat down before Tiamat, 
#tr.en: Exchanging counsel about the gods, their first-born. 
#tr.en: Apsu, opening his mouth, 
#tr.en: Said to resplendent Tiamat: 
#tr.en: “Their ways are truly loathsome to me. 
#tr.en: By day I find no relief, nor repose by night. 
#tr.en: I will destroy, I will wreck their ways, 
#tr.en: That quiet may be restored. Let us have rest!” (40) 
#tr.en: As soon as Tiamat heard this, 
#tr.en: She was furious and called out to her husband. 
#tr.en: She cried out aggrieved, as she raged all alone, 
#tr.en: She uttered a curse, and unto Apsu she spoke: 
#tr.en: “What? Should we destroy that which we have built? 
#tr.en: Their ways indeed are most troublesome, but let us attend kindly!” 
#tr.en: Then Mummu answered, giving counsel to Apsu; 
#tr.en: Ill-wishing and ungracious was Mummu’s advice: 
#tr.en: “Do destroy, my father, the mutinous ways. 
#tr.en: Then you will have relief by day and rest by night!” (50) 
#tr.en: When Apsu heard this, his face grew radiant 
#tr.en: Because of the evil he planned against the gods, his sons. 
#tr.en: As for Mummu, he embraced him by the neck 
#tr.en: As that one sat down on his knees to kiss him. 
#tr.en: Now whatever they had plotted between them, 
#tr.en: Was repeated unto the gods, their first-born. 
#tr.en: When the gods heard this, they were astir, 
#tr.en: Then lapsed into silence and remained speechless. 
#tr.en: Surpassing in wisdom, accomplished, resourceful, 
#tr.en: Ea, the all-wise, saw through their scheme. (60) 
#tr.en: A master design against it he devised and set up, 
#tr.en: Made artful his spell against it, surpassing and holy. 
#tr.en: He recited it and made it subsist in the deep, 
#tr.en: As he poured sleep upon him. Sound asleep he lay. 
#tr.en: When he had made Apsu prone, drenched with sleep, 
#tr.en: Mummu, the adviser, was powerless to stir. 
#tr.en: He loosened his band, tore off his tiara, 
#tr.en: Removed his halo and put it on himself. 
#tr.en: Having fettered Apsu, he slew him. 
#tr.en: Mummu he bound and left behind lock. (70) 
#tr.en: Having thus established his dwelling upon Apsu, 
#tr.en: He laid hold of Mummu, holding him by the nose-rope. 
#tr.en: After Ea had vanquished and trodden down his foes, 
#tr.en: Had secured his triumph over his enemies, 
#tr.en: In his sacred chamber in profound peace had rested, 
#tr.en: He named it “Apsu,” for shrines he assigned it. 
#tr.en: In that same place his cult hut he founded. 
#tr.en: Ea and Damkina, his wife, dwelled there in splendor. 
#tr.en: The Birth of Marduk In the chamber of fates, the abode of destinies, 
#tr.en: A god was engendered, most able and wisest of gods. (80) 
#tr.en: In the heart of Apsu was Marduk created, 
#tr.en: In the heart of holy Apsu was Marduk created. 
#tr.en: He who begot him was Ea, his father; 
#tr.en: She who bore him was Damkina, his mother. 
#tr.en: The breast of goddesses he did suck. 
#tr.en: The nurse that nursed him filled him with awesomeness. 
#tr.en: Alluring was his figure, sparkling the lift of his eyes. 
#tr.en: Lordly was his gait, commanding from of old. 
#tr.en: When Ea saw him, the father who begot him, 
#tr.en: He exulted and glowed, his heart filled with gladness. (90) 
#tr.en: He rendered him perfect and endowed him with a double godhead. 
#tr.en: Greatly exalted was he above them, exceeding throughout. 
#tr.en: Perfect were his members beyond comprehension, 
#tr.en: Unsuited for understanding, difficult to perceive. 
#tr.en: Four were his eyes, four were his ears; 
#tr.en: When he moved his lips, fire blazed forth. 
#tr.en: Large were all four hearing organs, 
#tr.en: And the eyes, in like number, scanned all things. 
#tr.en: He was the loftiest of the gods, surpassing was his stature; 
#tr.en: His members were enormous, he was exceeding tall. (100) 
#tr.en: “My little son, my little son!” 
#tr.en: My son, the Sun! Sun of the heavens!” 
#tr.en: Clothed with the halo of ten gods, he was strong to the utmost, 
#tr.en: As their awesome flashes were heaped upon him. 
#tr.en: Anu brought forth and begot the fourfold wind 
#tr.en: Consigning to its power the leader of the host. 
#tr.en: He fashioned ..., stationed the whirlwind, 
#tr.en: He produced streams to roil Tiamat. 
#tr.en: Roiled was Tiamat, and day and night dulled. 
#tr.en: The gods, given no rest, suffer in the storm. 
#tr.en: Their hearts having plotted evil, (110) 
#tr.en: To Tiamat, their mother, said: 
#tr.en: “When they slew Apsu, your consort, 
#tr.en: You did not aid him but remained still. 
#tr.en: When he created the dread fourfold wind, 
#tr.en: Your vitals were diluted and so we can have no rest. 
#tr.en: Let Apsu, your consort, be in your mind 
#tr.en: And Mummu, who has been vanquished! You are left alone! 
#tr.en: ... you pace about distraught, 
#tr.en: ... without cease. You do not love us! 
#tr.en: ... our eyes are pinched, (120) 
#tr.en: ... without cease. Let us have rest! 
#tr.en: ... to battle. Avenge them! 
#tr.en: ... and render them as the wind!” 
#tr.en: When Tiamat heard these words, she was pleased: 
#tr.en: “... you have given. Let us make monsters, 
#tr.en: ... and the gods in the midst ... . 
#tr.en: ... let us do battle and against the gods ... !” 
#tr.en: They banded themselves together and marched at the side of Tiamat. 
#tr.en: Enraged, they plot without cease night and day, 
#tr.en: They are set for combat, growling, raging, (130) 
#tr.en: They form a council to prepare for the fight. 
#tr.en: Mother Hubur, she who fashions all things, 
#tr.en: Added matchless weapons, bore monster-serpents, 
#tr.en: Sharp of tooth, unsparing of fang. 
#tr.en: With venom for blood she has filled their bodies. 
#tr.en: Roaring dragons she has clothed with terror, 
#tr.en: Has crowned them with haloes, making them like gods, 
#tr.en: Whoever beheld them, terror overcame him, 
#tr.en: And that, with their bodies reared up, none might turn them back. 
#tr.en: She set up the Viper, the Dragon, and the monster Lahamu, (140) 
#tr.en: The Great-Lion, the Mad-Dog, and the Scorpion-Man, 
#tr.en: Mighty lion-demons, the Dragon-Fly, the Centaur-- 
#tr.en: Bearing weapons that do not spare, fearless in battle. 
#tr.en: Her decrees were firm, they were beyond resisting. 
#tr.en: All together eleven of this kind she brought forth. 
#tr.en: From among the gods, her first-born, who formed her Assembly, 
#tr.en: She elevated Kingu, made him chief among them. 
#tr.en: The leading of the ranks, command of the Assembly, 
#tr.en: The raising of weapons for the encounter, advancing to combat, 
#tr.en: To direct the battle, to control the fight, (150) 
#tr.en: These she entrusted to his hand as she seated him in the Council: 
#tr.en: “I have cast for you the spell, exalting you in the Assembly of the gods. 
#tr.en: To counsel all the gods I have given you full power. 
#tr.en: Truly, you are supreme, you are my only consort! 
#tr.en: Your utterance shall prevail over all the Anunnaki!” 
#tr.en: She gave him the Tablet of Destinies, fastened on his breast: 
#tr.en: “As for you, your command shall be unchangeable, your word shall endure!” 
#tr.en: As soon as Kingu was elevated, possessed of the rank of Anu, 
#tr.en: they decreed the fate for the gods, his sons: 
#tr.en: “Your word shall make the first subside, (160) 
#tr.en: Shall humble the ‘Power-Weapon,’ so potent in its sweep!” 
#tr.en: Ampiriš, king of Samatira, son of Dabalana.
#tr.en: Unsak, king of Samatira, son of Giuttiyaš.

#tr.en: If a man is bewitched: armannu-like turnip, salt . . . 
#tr.en: the kidney of a lamb that has not fed on grass up to now 
#tr.en: (and) . . ., you dry out, he eats it and then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man suffers from jaundice:
#tr.en: you soak liquorice root in milk, then
#tr.en: you leave it out overnight under the stars, then in filtered oil
#tr.en: you combine it, and you make him drink it, then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's teeth, worms: 
#tr.en: you crush sailor faeces in filtered oil, then
#tr.en: if the right side of his teeth hurt,
#tr.en: you pour it on the left side of his teeth; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If the left side of his teeth hurt:
#tr.en: you pour it on the right side of his teeth; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man is full of gergishu-disease: roughly-ground malt flour
#tr.en: in filtered oil, portion for portion,
#tr.en: you combine it, and you place it (on him); then he will recover.
#tr.en: If he doesn't recover: you put a warm iron (on him); then he will recover.
#tr.en: If he does not recover: you put warm dregs (on him), then he will recover.
#tr.en: If, as for a man, a scorpion stings him:
#tr.en: you put saliva from an ox (on him); then he will recover.
#tr.en: If both of a man's eyes are diseased: hartitu-flower
#tr.en: you squeeze out and put it (on him): then he will recover.

#tr.en: ashes, groats, mashtakal-plant,
#tr.en: old brick, in sesame oil
#tr.en: you combine, and . . . 
#tr.en: If a man . . .
#tr.en: If a man . . . 
#tr.en: fruit tree . . . you place (on him): then he will recover.

#tr.en: you put tamarisk seed (on him); then he will recover.

#tr.en: prevent the puppies from being engendered: 
#tr.en: mashtakal-plant, henbane in butter oil
#tr.en: you pulverize it, and he eats it; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's teeth (have) worms: scales of . . .
#tr.en: you dry it out and you put it (on him); then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's belly is bloated: black cumin
#tr.en: he drinks in top-quality oil: then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man is bewitched: asafoetida root,
#tr.en: he drinks in pure oil; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's anus is diseased: flesh of a living being
#tr.en: you dry it out, combine it in pure oil, and cool it: then he will recover.
#tr.en: If, after a blemish stings him, plucked wool, (branding) iron, . . .
#tr.en: you lift them up; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's feet . . . the ground:
#tr.en: you heat water in a cauldron and drench it (with it),
#tr.en: you cool the oil from . . .; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's head suffers from himit seti-disease:
#tr.en: you press his head down on a peg, and
#tr.en: you pour out oil; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If he is warm: you add oil; then he will recover.
#tr.en: If a man's belly is continually swollen:
#tr.en: he should drink ninu-plant in beer; then he will recover.
#tr.en: you crush . . . and rub it with oil and cedar oil 
#tr.en: you scatter it (on him) and recite an incantation

#tr.en: for asu-disease, you crush cumin and 
#tr.en: you mix it in one liter of fine-quality oil, 
#tr.en: recite an incantation, and make him drink it.

#tr.en: you crush, rub it with oil and cedar oil, and recite the incantation.

#tr.en: you strike and recite the incantation.

#tr.en: and colocynth, you crush, and with oil and cedar oil 
#tr.en: you rub it, scatter it (on him), and recite the incantation.

#tr.en: . . . you scatter it (on him) and recite the incantation. 
#tr.en: . . . there is death in a man's house. 
#tr.en: If scorpions butt each other in a man's house, there will be death in the man's house. 
#tr.en: If a scorpion strikes a man on the right side, that man will grumble. 
#tr.en: If a scorpion strikes a man on the left side, that man will have a victorious conquest. 
#tr.en: If a snake falls on a man's head, that man will experience difficulty. 
#tr.en: If a snake, from a rafter in a man's house, in between 
#tr.en: two men or two companions falls, 
#tr.en: one of them will die. 
#tr.en: If two snakes entwine with each other in a man's house 
#tr.en: this house will be scattered. 
#tr.en: If a mouse, in the house of a man, by a mongoose 
#tr.en: was put to flight (and) driven to the door, the person who entered will die. 
#tr.en: there will be a fever in the house of the man.

#tr.en: took the wick and 
#tr.en: brought it into its hole: 
#tr.en: death will appear in the man's house.

#tr.en: there will be death in the man's house.

#tr.en: month “Harvest,”

#tr.en: you wind it. 4 eye(-beads and) 4 beads of parû to his left hand
