#tr.en: The gakkul (vat), the gakkul (vat)! 
#tr.en: The gakkul (vat), the lamsare (vat)!  
#tr.en: The gakkul (vat), that puts us in a happy mood! 
#tr.en: The lamsare (vat), that makes the stomach rejoice! 
#tr.en: The ugurbala (jar), glory of the house! 
#tr.en: The šagub (jar), filling with beer! 
#tr.en: The amam (jar), that carries the beer from the lamsare (vat)! 
#tr.en: The troughs of bur (grass) and the pails for kneading the dough! 
#tr.en: All the beautiful vessels are ready on their pot stands!  
#tr.en: May the stomach of your god be well disposed towards you! 
#tr.en: Let the eye of the gakkul (vat) be our eye,  
#tr.en: and let the stomach of the gakkul (vat) be our heart! 
#tr.en: What makes your stomach feel wonderful in itself  
#tr.en: also makes our stomachs feel wonderful in themselves! 
#tr.en: We are in a happy mood, our stomachs are joyful! 
#tr.en: You have poured a libation over the brick of fate, 
#tr.en: and you have laid the foundations in peace and prosperity— 
#tr.en: now may Ninkasi dwell with you!  
#tr.en: She should transfer, one to the other, beer and wine for you!  
#tr.en: Let the pouring of the sweet liquor resound pleasantly for you! 
#tr.en: In the troughs of bur (grass), there is sweet beer.  
#tr.en: I will have the cupbearers, the boys and the brewers stand by. 
#tr.en: As I spin around the lake of drinks, 
#tr.en: while feeling wonderful, feeling wonderful, 
#tr.en: while drinking beer, in a blissful mood, 
#tr.en: while drinking alcohol and feeling exhilarated, 
#tr.en: with joy in the stomach and a contented liver— 
#tr.en: my stomach is a heart stomach with joy! 
#tr.en: I clothe my contented liver in a garment fit for a queen! 
#tr.en: The stomach of Inanna is happy once again; 
#tr.en: the stomach of Inanna is happy once again! 
#tr.en: A ... to Ninkasi. 
#tr.en: The seal (with) the inscription of Ur-dun, the merchant, has gone lost. 
#tr.en: (By) word of the assembly 
#tr.en: the herald in the streets sounded the trumpet. 
#tr.en: No one may hold him liable for anything. 
#tr.en: Lu-Suen, the general; 
#tr.en: Lugal-melam, the city-ruler; 
#tr.en: Zu-zu, the headmaster; 
#tr.en: Si-du, the scribe; 
#tr.en: Ad-lub, the steward; 
#tr.en: Bansage, the lamentation-priest (and) temple administrator; 
#tr.en: Mulli’a, the mayor; 
#tr.en: (and) the herald are the witnesses. 
#tr.en: To my lord, the bull with sparkling eyes, a beard of lapis-lazuli sporting, 
#tr.en: speak! 
#tr.en: To my golden statue on a favorable day born,
#tr.en: to my water buffalo in a holy fold reared, in the silver-stomach of Inanna chosen,
#tr.en: to my lord, the trusted one of Inanna, repeat! 
#tr.en: You are fashioned like the son of An, 
#tr.en: your utterances, like the words of a god, are irrevocable;
#tr.en: your utterances like rain pouring from the skies, are uncountable; 
#tr.en: this is what Ur-saga, your servant, says: 
#tr.en: My lord has taken care of me; I am a son of Ur. 
#tr.en: If my lord agrees
#tr.en: my father’s household let no one carry off, 
#tr.en: my father’s household let no one take away! 
#tr.en: May my lord know this! 
#tr.en: Messenger, messenger, to my mother 
#tr.en: say 
#tr.en: what monkey says: 
#tr.en: Ur is the city resplendent of Nanna. 
#tr.en:  In Eridu, the city abundant of Enki, 
#tr.en:  indeed I, behind the door of the house of the Chief Musician am sitting. 
#tr.en: Looks are feeding me. 
#tr.en: May I not die! 
#tr.en: There being no fresh bread, there being no fresh beer, 
#tr.en: have a courier send some to me! 
#tr.en: It’s a flood! 
#tr.en: “At his command your weapon struck me evilly. 
#tr.en: As I let the divine powers go out of my hand, these divine powers returned to the abzu. 
#tr.en: As I let the divine plan go out of my hand, this divine plan returned to the abzu. 
#tr.en: This tablet of destinies returned to the abzu. I was stripped of the divine powers.” 
#tr.en: Ninurta was stunned at these words of the Anzu-chick. 
#tr.en: Ninmena gave out a wail: 
#tr.en: “And what about me? These divine powers have not fallen into my hand. 
#tr.en: I shall not exercise their authority. I shall not live (?) like him in the shrine, in the abzu.” 
#tr.en: Father Enki in the abzu knew what had been said. 
#tr.en: The Anzu-chick took the hero Ninurta by his hand 
#tr.en: and drew near with him to Enki’s place, the abzu. 
#tr.en: The Anzu-chick returned Uta-ulu to the abzu. 
#tr.en: The lord was delighted with the hero, 
#tr.en: Father Enki was delighted with the hero Ninurta. 
#tr.en: Lord Nudimmud honored him duly: 
#tr.en: “Hero, no god among your brother gods could have acted so. 
#tr.en: As for the bird which your mighty weapon captured, 
#tr.en: from now to eternity you will keep your foot placed on its neck. 
#tr.en: May the great gods give your heroic strength its due. 
#tr.en: May your father Enlil do whatever you command. 
#tr.en: May Ninmena not fashion your equal (?). 
#tr.en: May no one be as revered as you and no god extend an upraised hand before you. 
#tr.en: Monthly may your house (?) regularly receive tributes in the shrine, in the abzu. 
#tr.en: May An (?) proclaim your name in the seat of honor.” 
#tr.en: The hero secretly was not happy with these promises. 
#tr.en: Where he stood, he darkened and yellowed like (?) a flood-storm (?). 
#tr.en: He contemplated great deeds and inwardly he was rebellious. 
#tr.en: He uttered a word which has no ... 
#tr.en: The hero Ninurta set his sights on the whole world. 
#tr.en: He told no one and inwardly did not ... 
#tr.en: The great lord Enki intuitively grasped the substance of the plan. 
#tr.en: In the shrine, in the abzu he stirred up a dark flood-storm. 
#tr.en: By the house the minister Isimud opposed Ninurta. 
#tr.en: The hero Ninurta refused to come out 
#tr.en: and raised his hand against the minister Isimud. 
#tr.en: (Against Ninurta,) Enki fashioned a turtle from the clay of the abzu. 
#tr.en: Against him he stationed the turtle at an opening, at the gate of the abzu. 
#tr.en: Enki talked to him near the place of the ambush 
#tr.en: and brought him to the place where the turtle was. 
#tr.en: The turtle was able to grab Ninurta's tendon from behind. 
#tr.en: The hero Ninurta managed to turn back its feet. 
#tr.en: Enki, as if perplexed, said, “What is this?!” 
#tr.en: He had the turtle scrape the ground with its claws, had it dig an evil pit. 
#tr.en: The hero Ninurta fell into it with the turtle. 
#tr.en: The hero did not know how to get out from ... 
#tr.en: The turtle kept on gnawing his feet with its claws (?). 
#tr.en: The great lord Enki said to him: 
#tr.en: “From ..., you who set your mind to kill me, 
#tr.en: ... who makes big claims— 
#tr.en: I cut down, I raise up. 
#tr.en: You who set your sights on me like this— 
#tr.en: what has your position seized for you, how ...? 
#tr.en: Where has your strength fled? Where is your heroism? 
#tr.en: In the great mountains you caused destruction, but how will you get out now?” 
#tr.en: Ninmena learned of this situation. 
#tr.en: She was ripping the clothes from her body, she ... . 
#tr.en: “My ug-plant-eater Enki, whom shall I send to you? 
#tr.en: Men will shake their heads in fear ..., whom shall I send to you? 
#tr.en: That name is not Enki. That name is Ugugu-that-does-not-pour (?). 
#tr.en: You who are death without mercy, whom shall I send to you?” 
#tr.en: In those remote days, when the fates were determined; 
#tr.en: in a year when An brought about abundance, 
#tr.en: and people broke through the earth like green plants -- 
#tr.en: then the lord of the abzu, King Enki, 
#tr.en: Enki, the lord who determines the fates, 
#tr.en: built up his temple entirely from silver and lapis lazuli. 
#tr.en: Its silver and lapis lazuli were the shining daylight. 
#tr.en: Into the shrine of the abzu he brought joy. 
#tr.en: An artfully made bright crenellation rising out from the abzu 
#tr.en: was erected for Lord Nudimmud. 
#tr.en: He built the temple from precious metal, decorated it with lapis lazuli, 
#tr.en: and covered it abundantly with gold. 
#tr.en: In Eridu, he built the house on the bank. 
#tr.en: Its brickwork makes utterances and gives advice. 
#tr.en: Its eaves roar like a bull; 
#tr.en: the temple of Enki bellows. 
#tr.en: During the night the temple praises its lord and offers its best for him. 
#tr.en: Before Lord Enki, Isimud the minister praises the temple; 
#tr.en: he goes to the temple and speaks to it. 
#tr.en: He goes to the brick building and addresses it: 
#tr.en: “Temple, built from precious metal and lapis lazuli; 
#tr.en: whose foundation pegs are driven into the abzu; 
#tr.en: which has been cared for by the prince in the abzu! 
#tr.en: Like the Tigris and the Euphrates, it is mighty and awe-inspiring (?). 
#tr.en: Joy has been brought into Enki's abzu. 
#tr.en: Your lock has no rival. 
#tr.en: Your bolt is a fearsome lion. 
#tr.en: Your roof beams are the bull of heaven, an artfully made bright headgear. 
#tr.en: Your reed-mats are like lapis lazuli, decorating the roof-beams. 
#tr.en: Your vault is a wild bull raising its horns. 
#tr.en: Your door is a lion who seizes a man. 
#tr.en: Your stairway is a lion coming down on a man. 
#tr.en: Abzu, pure place which fulfils its purpose! 
#tr.en: E-engura! Your lord has directed his steps towards you. 
#tr.en: Enki, lord of the abzu, 
#tr.en: has embellished your foundation pegs with cornelian. 
#tr.en: He has adorned you with ... and (?) lapis lazuli. 
#tr.en: The temple of Enki is provisioned with silver wax (?); 
#tr.en: it is a bull obedient to its master, 
#tr.en: roaring by itself and giving advice at the same time. 
#tr.en: E-engura, which Enki has surrounded with a silver reed fence! 
#tr.en: In your midst a lofty throne is erected, 
#tr.en: your door-jamb is the silver locking bar of heaven. 
#tr.en: Abzu, pure place, place where the fates are determined 
#tr.en: —the lord of wisdom, Lord Enki, 
#tr.en: Enki, the lord deciding fates— 
#tr.en: Nudimmud, the lord of Eridu, 
#tr.en: lets nobody look into its midst. 
#tr.en: Your abgal priests let their hair down their backs. 
#tr.en: Enki's beloved Eridu, 
#tr.en: E-engura whose inside is full of abundance! 
#tr.en: Abzu, life of the Land, beloved of Enki! 
#tr.en: Temple built on the edge, befitting the artful divine powers! 
#tr.en: Eridu, your shadow extends over the midst of the sea! 
#tr.en: Eridu, your shadow extends over the midst of the sea! Rising sea without a rival; 
#tr.en: mighty awe-inspiring river which terrifies the Land! 
#tr.en: E-engura, high citadel (?) standing firm on the earth! 
#tr.en: Temple at the edge of the engur, a lion in the midst of the abzu; 
#tr.en: lofty temple of Enki, which bestows wisdom on the Land; 
#tr.en: your cry, like that of a mighty rising river, 
#tr.en: reaches (?) King Enki. 
#tr.en: To his silver house its goodness he sets, 
#tr.en: the lyre, the algar instrument, the balag drum 
#tr.en: the ḫarḫar, the sabitum, and the …… miritum instruments offer their best for his silver temple. 
#tr.en: The ... with a sweet sound 
#tr.en: resounded by themselves. 
#tr.en: The silver algar instrument of Enki played for him on his own 
#tr.en: and seven tigi drums resounded. 
#tr.en: What Enki says is irrefutable; 
#tr.en: ... is well established (?).” 
#tr.en: This is what Isimud spoke to the brick building; 
#tr.en: he praised the E-engura with sweet songs 
#tr.en: As it has been built, as it has been built; 
#tr.en: as Enki has raised Eridu up, 
#tr.en: it is an artfully built mountain which floats on the water. 
#tr.en: His shrine (?) spreads (?) out into the reedbeds; 
#tr.en: In its green orchards laden with fruit 
#tr.en: birds brood. 
#tr.en: The suhur carp play among the honey-herbs, 
#tr.en: and the esztub carp dart among the small gizi reeds. 
#tr.en: When Enki rises, the fish rise before him like waves. 
#tr.en: He has the abzu stand as a marvel, 
#tr.en: as he brings joy into the engur. 
#tr.en: Like the sea, he is awe-inspiring; 
#tr.en: like a mighty river, he instils fear. 
#tr.en: The Euphrates rises before him as it does before the fierce south wind. 
#tr.en: His punting pole is Nirah 
#tr.en: his oars are the small reeds. 
#tr.en: When Enki embarks, the year will be full of abundance. 
#tr.en: The ship departs of its own accord, with tow rope held (?) by itself. 
#tr.en: As he leaves the temple of Eridu, 
#tr.en: the river gurgles (?) to its lord: 
#tr.en: its sound is a calf's mooing, the mooing of a good cow. 
#tr.en: Enki had oxen slaughtered, and had sheep offered there lavishly. 
#tr.en: Where there were no ala drums, he installed some in their places; 
#tr.en: where there were no bronze ub drums, he despatched some to their places. 
#tr.en: He directed his steps on his own to Nibru 
#tr.en: and entered the temple terrace, the shrine of Nibru. 
#tr.en: Enki reached for (?) the beer, he reached for (?) the liquor. 
#tr.en: He had liquor poured into big bronze containers, 
#tr.en: and had emmer-wheat beer pressed out (?). 
#tr.en: In kukuru containers which make the beer good he mixed beer-mash. 
#tr.en: By adding date-syrup to its taste (?), he made it strong. 
#tr.en: He ... its bran-mash. 
#tr.en: In the shrine of Nibru, Enki 
#tr.en: provided a meal for Enlil, his father. 
#tr.en: He seated An at the head of the table 
#tr.en: and seated Enlil next to An. 
#tr.en: He seated Nintur in the place of honour 
#tr.en: and seated the Anuna gods at the adjacent places (?). 
#tr.en: All of them were drinking and enjoying beer and liquor. 
#tr.en: They filled the bronze aga vessels to the brim 
#tr.en: and started a competition, drinking from the bronze vessels of Urasz. 
#tr.en: They made the tilimda vessels shine like silver barges. 
#tr.en: After beer and liquor had been libated and enjoyed, 
#tr.en: and after ... from the house, 
#tr.en: Enlil was made happy in Nibru. 
#tr.en: Enlil addressed the Anuna gods: 
#tr.en: “Great gods who are standing here! 
#tr.en: Anuna, who have lined up in the Ubszu-unkena! 
#tr.en: My son, King Enki has built up the temple! 
#tr.en: He has made Eridu rise up (?) from the ground like a mountain! 
#tr.en: He has built it in a pleasant place, 
#tr.en: in Eridu, the pure place, where no one is to enter 
#tr.en: —a temple built with silver and decorated with lapis lazuli, 
#tr.en: a house which tunes the seven tigi drums properly, and provides incantations; 
#tr.en: where silver songs make all of the house a lovely place 
#tr.en: —the shrine of the abzu, the good destiny of Enki, befitting the elaborate divine powers; 
#tr.en: the temple of Eridu, built with silver: for all this, 
#tr.en: Father Enki be praised!” 
#tr.en: To Anūnītum, 
#tr.en: his mistress, did Sargon 
#tr.en: for his life (this) dedicate. 
#tr.en: A’allimu 
#tr.en: son of Namḫani, 
#tr.en: gudu(-officiant) of Nin-ilduma. 
#tr.en: Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, provider 
#tr.en: of Esagila and Ezida, eldest son 
#tr.en: of Nabopolassar, king of Babylon.

#tr.en:  I survived to the next year; the appointed time passed. 
#tr.en:  1st tablet, ludlul bēl ... 
#tr.en: Keep her apart! Keep her apart! 
#tr.en: The daughters of Anum, (in) the rising of the sky, 
#tr.en: purified the day(?), 
#tr.en: and the heaven of Anum. 
#tr.en: Love was happening, upon the people it was caressing(?). 
#tr.en: May love caress(?) me! 
#tr.en: Let me cast (a spell), let me command, let me speak, let me love. 
#tr.en: Think of me as an ašnugallum-snake 
#tr.en: Let your face rejoice like a wild cow. 
#tr.en: May you not wait for your father's consent. 
#tr.en: May you not take your mother’s advice. 
#tr.en: If she is a q.-woman, may she ... her obligation to work. 
#tr.en: If she is an n.-woman, may she ... a marriage gift. 
#tr.en: If she is a prostitute, may she clean her tavern and upon me fall. 
#tr.en: The incantation is not mine, 
#tr.en: it is an incantation that of Ea and Ištar established. 
#tr.en: To Kurnugi’a, domain of Ereškigal, 
#tr.en: did Ištar, daughter of Sîn, her ear direct; 
#tr.en: indeed did direct the daughter of Sîn her ear 
#tr.en: to the house of darkness, the dwelling of Irkalla, 
#tr.en: to the house where those who enter are not such who exit, 
#tr.en: to the route whose path is one of he who does not return, 
#tr.en: to the house where those who enter are deprived of light, 
#tr.en: Where dust (satisfies) their hunger, their food is clay, 
#tr.en: (where) light they do not see, in darkness they sit 
#tr.en: (where) they are clothed like birds, in garments of feathers, 
#tr.en: over the door and lock, dust was settled, 
#tr.en: Ištar, at the gate of Kurnugi’a arriving, 
#tr.en: to the gatekeeper speaks: 
#tr.en: “Gatekeeper, open your gate for me; 
#tr.en: open your gate for me, that I, indeed I, may enter; 
#tr.en: if you do not open the gate for me, so that I, indeed I, cannot enter, 
#tr.en: I will strike the door, the lock I will break; 
#tr.en: I will strike the posts, I will push the doors aside, 
#tr.en: I will raise up the dead; they will devour the living, 
#tr.en: that the dead will outnumber the living.” 
#tr.en: The gatekeeper worked his mouth, saying, 
#tr.en: speaking to great Ištar: 
#tr.en: “Stand, my lady, do not knock it down, 
#tr.en: let me go and your words repeat to queen Ereškigal.” 
#tr.en: He entered, and the gatekeeper speaks to Ereškigal: 
#tr.en: “Here now, your sister Ištar is standing at your gate, 
#tr.en: she who holds the great hunting loops, who roils up the Apsu before king Ea.” 
#tr.en: Ereškigal, hearing this, 
#tr.en: like cut tamarisk went yellow her face, 
#tr.en: like the edge of a drinking reed went black her lips. 
#tr.en: “What brought her heart to me? What caused her liver to light up for me? 
#tr.en: Here now, shall I, even I, with the Anunnaki water drink? 
#tr.en: As if bread, shall I eat clay? As if beer, shall I drink murky water? 
#tr.en: Let me weep for the young men who leave behind wives? 
#tr.en: Let me weep weep for the maidens who from the lap of their spouses are torn? 
#tr.en: For the weak young one let me weep, who before his days was lead away? 
#tr.en: Go, gatekeeper, open for her your gate, 
#tr.en: treat her according to the ancient rules!” 
#tr.en: Off went the gatekeeper, and opened for her his gate. 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, let Kuthâ rejoice over you.” 
#tr.en: May the palace of Kurnugi’a be happy at your presence!” 
#tr.en: The 1st gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the great crown of her head. 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you take away the great crown of my head?” 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: The 2nd gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the earrings of her ears. 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you take away the earrings of my ears?” 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: The 3rd gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the beads of her neck. 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you take away the beads of my neck?” 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: The 4th gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the pectoral of her chest. 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you take away the pectoral of my chest?” 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: The 5th gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the belt of birthstones of her hips 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you take away belt of birthstones of my hips?” 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: The 6th gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the bracelets of her hand and her foot. 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you take away the bracelets of my hand and my foot?” 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: The 7th gate he let her enter, and he spread out and took away the garment of modesty of her body. 
#tr.en: “Why, gatekeeper, did you carry off the garment of modesty of my body? 
#tr.en: “Enter, my lady, of the lady of the netherworld thus are her rules.” 
#tr.en: away from there, Ishtar to Kurnugi’a descended. 
#tr.en: Ereshkigal saw her and in her presence began to shake. 
#tr.en: Ishtar did not reflect; above her she rose. 
#tr.en: Ereshkigal her mouth worked, speaking, 
#tr.en: to Namtar, her high minister, the words speaking: 
#tr.en: “Go, Namtar, ... in my palace, and 
#tr.en: send out against her, the sixty diseases against Ishtar: 
#tr.en: the disease of the eyes against her eyes, 
#tr.en: the disease of the side against her side, 
#tr.en: the disease of the feet against her feet, 
#tr.en: the disease of the stomach against her stomach, 
#tr.en: the disease of the head against her head, 
#tr.en: against her, all of her, against her body!” 
#tr.en: After lady Ištar to Kurnugi’a descended, 
#tr.en: the cow the bull does not mount, the donkey the jenny does not impregnate; 
#tr.en: the young woman in the street does not impregnate the young man; 
#tr.en: lay the young man in his chamber, 
#tr.en: lay the young woman on her side. 
#tr.en: Papsukkal, minister of the great gods: bent low was his nose, his face; 
#tr.en: in rags clad, unkempt hair bearing, ... 
#tr.en: he went, tired, before Sîn, his father, weeping, ... 
#tr.en: before Ea, the king, he was going, his tears ...: 
#tr.en: “Ištar to the underworld descended, but did not ascend; 
#tr.en: since Ištar to Kurnugi’a descended, 
#tr.en: the cow the bull does not mount, the donkey the jenny does not impregnate; 
#tr.en: the young woman in the street is not impregnated by the young man; 
#tr.en: lay the young man in his chamber, 
#tr.en: lay the young woman on her side; 
#tr.en: Ea, in the wisdom of his stomach, has created a man, 
#tr.en: and he created Aṣûšu-namir, a she-man, 
#tr.en: come, Aṣûšu-namir, in the gate of Kurnugi’a set you face! 
#tr.en: may the 7 gates of Kurnugi’a be opened in your face! 
#tr.en: May Ereškigal see you and in your face rejoice! 
#tr.en: when her stomach is calmed, her liver happy, 
#tr.en: make her utter the oath of the great gods! 
#tr.en: Raise your head, to the waterskin ear give! 
#tr.en: “O Lady, the waterskin let them give me, that water therefrom I may drink!” 
#tr.en: Ereškigal, hearing this, 
#tr.en: struck her thigh, bit her finger: 
#tr.en: “You made a request of me that is not to be requested! 
#tr.en: Come, Aṣûšu-namir, let me lay a great curse on you! 
#tr.en: May the breads of the plows of the city be your bread! 
#tr.en: May the drainpipes of the city be your drink, 
#tr.en: the shadows of the wall your stations, 
#tr.en: the threshold your residence! 
#tr.en: May drunks and parched strike your cheek!” 
#tr.en: Ereškigal worked her mouth, saying, 
#tr.en: to Namtar, her minister, words speaking: 
#tr.en: “Go, Namtar, strike Egalgina! 
#tr.en: The thresholds adorn in coral stone! 
#tr.en: The Anunna bring out and on thrones of gold seat them! 
#tr.en: Ištar with water of life sprinkle and take her into(?) my presence!” 
#tr.en: Off went Namtar and knocked at Egalgina; 
#tr.en: the thresholds he decorated with coral stone; 
#tr.en: the Anunna he brought out and on thrones of gold sat them; 
#tr.en: Ištar with water of life he sprinkled and took her into(?) her presence; 
#tr.en: out of the first gate he brought her and returned to her the loincloth of her body; 
#tr.en: out of the second gate he brought her and returned to her her bracelets and anklets; 
#tr.en: out of the third gate he brought her and returned to her the girdle of birth-stones around her waist; 
#tr.en: out of the fourth gate he brought her and returned to her her breast pins; 
#tr.en: out of the fifth gate he brought her and returned to her the beads around her neck; 
#tr.en: out of the sixth gate he brought her and returned to her the earrings on her ears; 
#tr.en: out of the seventh gate he brought her and returned to her the great tiara on her head.

#tr.en: from Ur-Ḫendursag, 
#tr.en: did Erra-bani 
#tr.en: receive; 
#tr.en: month “Festival-of-Baba.” 
#tr.en: Erra-bani, 
#tr.en: servant of Ur-Baba.

#tr.en: From the mountain descended. 
#tr.en: Samana. 
#tr.en: From the mountain gone. 
#tr.en: From the mountain descended. 
#tr.en: From the mountain, the pure place, goes.

#tr.en: On the young man’s neck fallen.

#tr.en: Just as on the ox’s wide arms falling. 
#tr.en: Incantation 
#tr.en: of Ningirim, 
#tr.en: lady of sweet city Šuruppak, of the 7. 
#tr.en: My incantation is the incantation 
#tr.en: of Asalluhi, 
#tr.en: son of Enki, 
#tr.en: in the Abzu, it cannot be undone. 
#tr.en: enuru: 
#tr.en: The snake from snake mountain indeed called. 
#tr.en: The lizard of heaven and of earth 
#tr.en: licked. 
#tr.en: The sons of the lizard, heaven and earth, are 7. 
#tr.en: The well like wind it made. 
#tr.en: Water like wind he poured out. 
#tr.en: Grass like wind its right encircled. 
#tr.en: Its grass, his left 
#tr.en: it tore out. 
#tr.en: Then his ... held firm. 
#tr.en: ... the (snake’s) fang may he bind. 
#tr.en: The incantations(?) of the Abzu of Eridu of Asalluhi, son of Eridu: 
#tr.en: may they not be undone. 
#tr.en: Nisaba, 
#tr.en: the righteous woman, 
#tr.en: the beautiful woman. 
#tr.en: Addakala, 
#tr.en: the scribe, 
#tr.en: wrote, 
#tr.en: (so that) in your eyes he indeed pleased. 
#tr.en: Good bala. 
#tr.en: If ever, 
#tr.en: a long time from now, 
#tr.en: in the far future, 
#tr.en: in days to come, 
#tr.en: this tomb 
#tr.en: one should see, 
#tr.en: he must not treat it disrespectfully. 
#tr.en: Let him return it to its former condition. 
#tr.en: That man 
#tr.en: who will see this, 
#tr.en: may he not neglect it. 
#tr.en: Thus he should say: 
#tr.en: This tomb 
#tr.en: let me return to its former condition. 
#tr.en: May the good deed he does 
#tr.en: be repaid to him. 
#tr.en: Up above may his name be in favor. 
#tr.en: Down below  
#tr.en: may his spirit pure water. 
#tr.en: drink. 
#tr.en: Indi-Limma, 
#tr.en: son of Šer-Damu(?), 
#tr.en: servant of Išḫara. 
#tr.en: games 
#tr.en: By the flowing water given birth ...,
#tr.en: by Ninḫursaĝa tenderly cared for!
#tr.en: Ninkasi, by the flowing water given birth
#tr.en: by Ninḫursaĝa tenderly cared for!
#tr.en: Having founded your town upon wax,
#tr.en: she completed its great walls for you.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, having founded your town upon wax,
#tr.en: she completed its great walls for you.
#tr.en: Your father is Enki, Lord Nudimmud,
#tr.en: and your mother is Ninti, the queen of the abzu.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, your father is Enki, Lord Nudimmud,
#tr.en: and your mother is Ninti, the queen of the abzu.
#tr.en: It is you who handle the ... and dough with a big shovel, mixing,
#tr.en: in a pit, the beerbread with sweet aromatics.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who handle the ... and dough with a big shovel, mixing,
#tr.en: in a pit, the beerbread with sweet aromatics.
#tr.en: It is you who bake the beerbread in the big oven,
#tr.en: and put in order the piles of hulled grain.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who bake the beerbread in the big oven,
#tr.en: and put in order the piles of hulled grain.
#tr.en: It is you who water the earth-covered malt;
#tr.en: the noble dogs guard it even from the potentates (?).
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who water the earth-covered malt;
#tr.en: the noble dogs guard it even from the potentates (?).
#tr.en: It is you who soak the malt in a jar;
#tr.en: the waves rise, the waves fall.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who soak the malt in a jar;
#tr.en: the waves rise, the waves fall.
#tr.en: It is you who spread the cooked mash on large reed mats;
#tr.en: coolness overcomes ...
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who spread the cooked mash on large reed mats;
#tr.en: coolness overcomes ...
#tr.en: It is you who hold with both hands the great sweetwort,
#tr.en: brewing it with honey and wine.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who hold with both hands the great sweetwort,
#tr.en: brewing it with honey and wine.
#tr.en: ...
#tr.en: You ...... the sweetwort to the vessel.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, ...
#tr.en: You ... the sweetwort to the vessel.
#tr.en: You place the fermenting vat, which makes a pleasant sound,
#tr.en: appropriately on top of a large collector vat.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, you place the fermenting vat, which makes a pleasant sound,
#tr.en: appropriately on top of a large collector vat.
#tr.en: It is you who pour out the filtered beer of the collector vat;
#tr.en: it is like the onrush of the Tigris and the Euphrates.
#tr.en: Ninkasi, it is you who pour out the filtered beer of the collector vat;
#tr.en: it is like the onrush of the Tigris and the Euphrates.

#tr.en: his mistress,  
#tr.en: for the life

#tr.en: did Ḫazi, the overseer(?),

#tr.en: dedicate (this).

#tr.en: Aššur, great lord, who sets straight all the gods, 
#tr.en: grantor of sceptre and crown, establisher of kingship, 
#tr.en: Enlil lord, king of all the Anunnaki, 
#tr.en: father of the gods, lord of the lands, 
#tr.en: Sin, wise one, lord of the lunar disk, 
#tr.en: elevated, barge; 
#tr.en: Shamash judge of the heavens and the earth, observer 
#tr.en: of the treachery of the enemy, exposer of the wicked; 
#tr.en: Adad, warrior, stormer of the regions of the enemy, 
#tr.en: the lands, the seas, 
#tr.en: Ninurta, hero, slaughtererof the evil and the enemy, 
#tr.en: satisfier of all of the stomach, 
#tr.en: Ištar, first of the gods, lady of chaos, 
#tr.en: adorner of battle. 
#tr.en: The great gods, the ones who administer heaven and earth, 
#tr.en: whose attacks are battle and combat, 
#tr.en: who make great the sovereignty of 
#tr.en: Tiglath-Pileser, the beloved prince, 
#tr.en: gift of your hearts, attentive shepherd, 
#tr.en: who in the firmness of your hearts you chose; 
#tr.en: the supreme crown you put on his head, for the sovereignty of 
#tr.en: the land of Enlil you greatly established him; 
#tr.en: leadership, supremacy, heroism 
#tr.en: you presented to him, the destiny of his rule 
#tr.en: for the exercise of power and the seed of his priesthood 
#tr.en: for the post of Eḫursagkurkura 
#tr.en: for eternity you pronounced. 
#tr.en: In the beginning of my reign 20,000 men 
#tr.en: of the land of Muškāya and their 5 kings 
#tr.en: who for 50 years the land of Alzi 
#tr.en: and the land of Purulumzi, bearers of tribute 
#tr.en: and tax of Aššur my lord, seized; 
#tr.en: Not one king in battle their breast 
#tr.en: subdued, in their strength 
#tr.en: they trusted, and they came down, the land of Katmuḫi 
#tr.en: seized; with the help of Aššur, my lord 
#tr.en: my chariots and troops I set straight, 
#tr.en: on the rear (guard) I did not wait, (but) the land of Kašiyara, 
#tr.en: difficult terrain, I crossed, 
#tr.en: with 20,000 of their troops of battle 
#tr.en: and their 5 kings in the land of Katmuḫi 
#tr.en: I opposed, their defeat 
#tr.en: I verily established; the corpses of their warriors 
#tr.en: in the destructive plain like a flood 
#tr.en: I piled up, their blood in the hollows 
#tr.en: and flatlands of mountain I verily caused to flow; 
#tr.en: their heads I verily cut off; next to 
#tr.en: their cities like grain-heaps I poured out; 
#tr.en: their plunder, their property, their possessions 
#tr.en: without number I sent out; 6,000 
#tr.en: of the remainder of their army that before 
#tr.en: my weapons flew, my feet 
#tr.en: seized; I took them, and 
#tr.en: to the people of my land counted. 
#tr.en: Tiglath-Pileser, heroic man, 
#tr.en: holder of the bow without rival, 
#tr.en: expert of the hunt of the steppe: 
#tr.en: Ninurta and Palil their weapons 
#tr.en: angry and their bow exalted 
#tr.en: to my lordly side they gave; 
#tr.en: by order of Ninurta who loves me, 
#tr.en: 4 wild virile bulls, strong exceeding, 
#tr.en: in the wilderness in the land of the Mitanu, 
#tr.en: and in the city Araziqu which is before 
#tr.en: the land Ḫattu with my strong bow, 
#tr.en: spear of iron and my arrows 
#tr.en: sharp, their lives I ended; 
#tr.en: their skins and their hides 
#tr.en: to my city Assur I brought. 
#tr.en: 10 elephant bulls, strong, 
#tr.en: in the land Ḫarrān and the region of the river Ḫabur 
#tr.en: I verily killed, four living elephants 
#tr.en: I seized. Their skins 
#tr.en: and their teeth with elephants 
#tr.en: living to my city of Aššur I brought. 
#tr.en: By order of Ninurta who loves me 
#tr.en: 120 lions in my wild heart 
#tr.en: in combat heroic, 
#tr.en: on foot I verily killed; 
#tr.en: and 800 lions in my chariot 
#tr.en: in the open I felled; 
#tr.en: all of the creatures of Šakkan and birds of the sky 
#tr.en: flying with the bite of my reeds 
#tr.en: I brought low.

#tr.en: Assur, great lord, king of all 
#tr.en: the great gods; Anu, king of the Igigu 
#tr.en: and Anunnaku, lord of the lands; Enlil, 
#tr.en: exalted one, father of the gods, creator 
#tr.en: of all; Ea, king of the apsu, who decrees destinies; 
#tr.en: Sîn, wise one, king of the lunar disk, lofty luminary; 
#tr.en: Adad, the exceptionally strong, lord of abundance; Samaš, 
#tr.en: judge of heaven and underworld, commander of all; 
#tr.en: Marduk, sage of the gods, lord of omens; Ninurta, warrior 
#tr.en: of the Igigu and Anunnaku; mighty god Nergal, 
#tr.en: perfect one, king of battle; Nusku, bearer of the holy sceptre, 
#tr.en: circumspect god; Ninlil, spouse of the Enlil, mother of the gods 
#tr.en: the great ones; Ištar, foremost in heaven and underworld, who is consummate in the canons of battle; 
#tr.en: great gods, who decree destinies, who aggrandize my sovereignty; 
#tr.en: Shalmaneser, king of all people, prince, vice-regent of Assur, strong king, 
#tr.en: king of all the four quarters, sun(god) of all people, ruler 
#tr.en: of all lands; son of Assurnasirpal (II), exalted priest, whose priesthood to the gods 
#tr.en: was pleasing and (who) subdued all lands at his feet, 
#tr.en: pure offspring of Tukulti-Ninurta (II), 
#tr.en: who slew all his enemies and 
#tr.en: annihilated (them) like a flood: 
#tr.en: At the beginning of my reign, after the throne 
#tr.en: of kingship I nobly ascended, my chariots 
#tr.en: (and) troops I mustered. The pass of the land Simesi 
#tr.en: I entered (and) the city Aridu, the fortified city 
#tr.en: of Ninnu I captured. In my 1st regnal year 
#tr.en: the Euphrates in flood I crossed (and) to the western sea 
#tr.en: marched. My weapons in the sea I washed (and) sacrifices 
#tr.en: to my gods made. Up the Amanus range I climbed 
#tr.en: (and) beams of cedar (and) juniper cut. Up 
#tr.en: Mount Lallar I climbed (and) therein my royal statue erected. 
#tr.en: In my 2nd regnal year the city Til-Barsip I approached, the cities 
#tr.en: of Ahunu, the man of BIt-Adini captured, (and) to his city confined him. The Euphrates 
#tr.en: in flood I crossed (and) the city Dabigu, fortress of the land Hatti, . 
#tr.en: together with cities in its environs I captured. In my 3rd regnal year Ahunu, 
#tr.en: the man of BIt-Adini, in the face of my mighty weapons became frightened and Tîl-Barsip, 
#tr.en: his royal city abandoned. The Euphrates he crossed. 
#tr.en: The city Ana-Asšur-utēr-asbat, which is on the other side 
#tr.en: of the Euphrates by the River Sagura, which the people 
#tr.en: of Hatti call the city Pitru, 
#tr.en: as my own I took. On my return 
#tr.en: the pass of Alzu I entered, the land Alzi, the land Suḫme, 
#tr.en: the land Dayēnu, the land Tummu, the city Arsaškun, the royal city 
#tr.en: of Aramu, the land of the Urartian, the land Gilzānu, (and) the land Hubuškia. 
#tr.en: In the eponymy of Dayyān-Assur, from Nineveh I moved out and the Euphrates 
#tr.en: in flood crossed in pursuit of Aḫunu, the man of Bīt-Adini. Šītamrat, 
#tr.en: a mountain peak on the bank of the Euphrates as his stronghold he had made. The peak 
#tr.en: of the mountain I besieged (and) captured. Ahunu, together with his gods, his chariots, 
#tr.en: his horses, his sons, his daughters, (and) his troops I uprooted (and) to my city Assur 
#tr.en: brought. In this same year Mount Kullar I crossed, to the land Zamua, 
#tr.en: the interior, I went down (and) the cities of Nikdêra, the city Idean, 
#tr.en: and Nikdēme captured. In my 5th regnal year Mount Kasiiari I ascended (and) cities, 
#tr.en: fortified, captured. Anḫitti, the Šubraean, to his city I confined (and) his tribute 
#tr.en: rich received. In my 6th regnal year, the cities on the banks of the River Baliḫ 
#tr.en: I approached. Giammu, their city ruler, they killed. 
#tr.en: Tll-turaḫi I entered. 
#tr.en: The Euphrates in flood I crossed (and) 
#tr.en: tribute from the kings of the land Hatti, 
#tr.en: all of them, received. At that time Adad-idri, 
#tr.en: the Damascene, Irḫulēnu, the Hamatite, together with the kings 
#tr.en: of the land Hatti and (other kings) on the shore of the sea, in their united forces 
#tr.en: trusting, to wage war and battle 
#tr.en: attacked me. By the command of Assur, the great lord, my lord, 
#tr.en: with them I fought (and) defeated them. 
#tr.en: Their chariotry, cavalry, (and) military equipment I captured from them 
#tr.en: (and) 20,500 of their fighting men put to the sword. 
#tr.en: In my 7th regnal year to the cities of Ḫabinu, the Tīl-abnīan, I marched. 
#tr.en: Tīl-abnī, his fortified city, together with the cities in its environs I captured. 
#tr.en: To the source of the Tigris, the place where the water comes out I marched. 
#tr.en: The weapon of Assur therein I washed, sacrifices to my gods made, (and) a joyful banquet 
#tr.en: put on. My colossal royal statue I created (and) praises of Assur, my lord, my deeds 
#tr.en: of heroism which I had accomplished in the lands I wrote thereon. I erected it therein. 
#tr.en: In my 8th regnal year (at the time of) Marduk-zākir-šumi (I), king of Karduniaš, 
#tr.en: Marduk-bēl-usate, his younger brother, against him rebelled 
#tr.en: (and) the land equally they divided. To avenge 
#tr.en: Marduk-zākir-šumi I marched out (and) the city Mê-turnat captured. 
#tr.en: In my 9th regnal year, for a second time, to the land Akkad I marched. 
#tr.en: The city Gannanāte I surrounded. Marduk-bēl-usâte the fearful 
#tr.en: splendour of Assur (and) Marduk overwhelmed (and) to save his life to 
#tr.en: a mountain he ascended. I pursued him (and) Marduk-bēl-usâte, and the soldiers, 
#tr.en: of treachery who were with him I put to the sword. To the cities 
#tr.en: great I marched (and) sacrifices in Babylon, Borsippa, (and) Cuthah made, 
#tr.en: (and) offerings to the great gods presented. To Chaldaea I went down (and) their cities captured. 
#tr.en: Tribute from the kings of Chaldaea I received. Awe of my weapons as far as (the sea) Marratu overwhelmed (them). 
#tr.en: In my 10th regnal year the Euphrates for the 8th time I crossed. The cities of Sangara, the Carchemishite I captured. 
#tr.en: The cities of Aramu I approached (and) Arne, his royal city, together with 1 hundred cities (in its environs) I captured. 
#tr.en: In my 11th regnal year the Euphrates for the 9th time I crossed. Cities without number I captured (and) to the cities 
#tr.en: of the land of the Hamatians I descended. 89 cities I captured . Adad-idri, the Damascene, (and) 12 kings of the land Hatti 
#tr.en: in united strength stood together. I defeated them. In my 12th regnal year for the 10th time the Euphrates I crossed, 
#tr.en: to the land Paqarahubunu marched, and plundered them (the people). In my 13th regnal year to Matiētu I went up 
#tr.en: (and) plundered it. In my 14th regnal year (the troops of my) land I mustered (and) the Euphrates crossed. 12 kings attacked me, 
#tr.en: <with them> I fought, (and) defeated them. In my 15th regnal year to the source of the Tigris (and) Euphrates I marched (and) my statue 
#tr.en: of kingship on mountain cliffs there erected. In my 16th regnal year the Zab I crossed (and) to the land Namri 
#tr.en: marched. Marduk-mudammiq, king of the land Namri, to save his life fled. His property, 
#tr.en: troops, (and) gods to Assyria I brought back. Yanzû, a man of Bīt-Hanban I appointed to the sovereignty over them. 
#tr.en: In my 17th regnal year the Euphrates I crossed (and) the Amanus range ascended. Tmbers 
#tr.en: of cedar I cut down. In my 18th regnal year for the 16th time the Euphrates I crossed . Hazael 
#tr.en: of Damascus to do battle attacked. 1,121 of his chariots (and) 470 of his cavalry, together . 
#tr.en: with his camp I captured from him. In my 19th regnal year for the 18th time the Euphrates I crossed (and) the Amanus range 
#tr.en: ascended. Timbers of cedar I cut down.In my 20th regnal year for the 20th time the Euphrates 
#tr.en: I crossed (and) to the land Que went down. Their cities I captured (and) plundered 
#tr.en: them. In my 21st regnal for the 21st time year the Euphrates I crossed (and) to the cities 
#tr.en: of Hazael of Damascus marched. 4 cities I captured (and) tribute from the land Tyre, 
#tr.en: the land Sidon, (and) the land Byblos received. In my 22nd regnal year for the 22nd time the Euphrates 
#tr.en: I crossed (and) to the land Tabal went down. At that time from 24 
#tr.en: kings of the land Tabal gifts I received. To Mount Tunni, 
#tr.en: the mountain of silver, (and) Mount Mulû, the mountain of alabaster, I marched. In my 23rd regnal year 
#tr.en: the Euphrates I crossed (and) Uetas, the fortified city 
#tr.en: of Lalla, the Melidite, I captured. The kings of the land Tabal 
#tr.en: came to me (and) their tribute I received. In my 24th regnal year the Zab 
#tr.en: Lower I crossed, Mount Hašimur traversed, (and) to the land Namri 
#tr.en: went down. Ianzû, king of the land Namri, in face 
#tr.en: of my mighty weapons took fright and to save his life 
#tr.en: fled. Siḫišalaḫ, BIt-Tamul, Bīt-Šakki, 
#tr.en: (and) Bīt-Šēdi, his fortified cities, I captured. I massacred them, 
#tr.en: plundered them, (those) cities razed, destroyed, (and) burned . 
#tr.en: The survivors up a mountain climbed. To the mountain peak 
#tr.en: I laid siege, captured (it), slaughtered them, plundered them, (and) their property 
#tr.en: brought down. From the land Namri moving on, tribute from 27 kings 
#tr.en: of the land Parsua I received. From the land Parsua moving on, to 
#tr.en: the land Mēsu, the land Media (Amadāiia), the land Araziaš, (and) the land Ḫarḫār I went down, 
#tr.en: (and) the city Kuakinda, the city Ḫazzanabi, the city Esamul, 
#tr.en: (and) the city Kinablila, together with the cities in their environs, I captured. I massacred them, . 
#tr.en: killed, plundered them, (and) (those) cities razed, destroyed, (and) burned. My statue of kingship 
#tr.en: In the city Ḫarḫār I erected. Ianzû, the man of Bītgaban, together with his rich property, 
#tr.en: his gods, his sons, his daughters, (and) his numerous soldiers I uprooted, (and) to Assyria brought. In my 25th regnal year 
#tr.en: the Euphrates in flood I crossed (and) tribute from all the kings of the land Hatti received. The Amanus range 
#tr.en: I crossed (and) to the cities of Katê, the Quean (Qau), went down. Timur, his fortified city, 
#tr.en: I besieged (and) captured. I massacred them (its inhabitants), plundered them, (and) cities without number razed, destroyed, 
#tr.en: (and) burned. Upon my return Mūru over as a fortress, the fortified city of Aramu, the man of Bīt-Agūsi 
#tr.en: for myself I took. Its gateways I rebuilt (and) therein a palace as my royal residence founded. 
#tr.en: In my 26th regnal year for the 7th time the Amanus range I crossed. For a 4th time to the cities of Katê, 
#tr.en: the Quean (Qau) I marched. Tanakun, the fortified city of Tullu, I surrounded. By fear 
#tr.en: of the radiance of Assur, my lord, overwhelmed, he came out (and) submitted to me. Hostages from him I took (and) silver, gold, 
#tr.en: iron, oxen, (and) sheep as tribute received from him. From the city Tanakun moving on, to Mount Lamena 
#tr.en: I marched. The people became frightened (and) took to a rugged mountain. To the mountain peak I laid siege 
#tr.en: (and) captured (it). I massacred them (and) plunder consisting of their oxen (and) sheep from the mountain brought down. 
#tr.en: Their cities I razed, destroyed, (and) burned. To the city Tarsus I marched. (The people) submitted to me (and) silver (and) gold 
#tr.en: as tribute I received from them. Kirrî, the brother of Katê, as sovereign over them 
#tr.en: I appointed. Upon my return the Amanus range I ascended,n cedar timbers cut dow, 
#tr.en: (and) to my city, Assur carried them back. In my 27th regnal year my chariots (and) troops I mustered. Dayyān-Assur, warriors. 
#tr.en: the field marshal, chief of my extensive army, to lead my army to Urartu I issued orders 
#tr.en: (and) sent. To Bīt-Zamāni he went down, the pass of the city Ammas entered, and the River Arsania crossed. 
#tr.en: When Sēdiri, the Urartian, heard (of this), on the might of his mighty army 
#tr.en: relying to wage war and battle he attacked me. I fought with him, 
#tr.en: defeated him, (and) with the corpses of his warriors the wide plain filled. In my 28th regnal year, 
#tr.en: while in Nimrud I was residing, a report was sent back to me that the people of the land Patinu 
#tr.en: Lubarna, their lord, had killed (and) Surri, a nonroyal person (lit. “a non-lord of a throne”), as sovereign over them appointed. 
#tr.en: Dayyān-Assur, the field marshal, chief of my extensive army, at the head of my army (and) camp 
#tr.en: I issued orders and sent out. The Euphrates in flood he crossed and at Kinalua, his royal city, 
#tr.en: pitched camp. Surri, a non-royal person, by fear of the radiance of Assur, my lord, 
#tr.en: overwhelmed, departed this life. The people of the land Patinu in face of the flash of my strong weapons 
#tr.en: took fright, and of the sons of Surri, together with the guilty soldiers, laying hold, they handed (them) over. 
#tr.en: Those soldiers on stakes I hung. Sāsi, a man of the land Kirissa, submitted to me (and) to sovereignty 
#tr.en: over them I appointed (him). Silver, gold, tin, bronze, iron, (and) elephant ivory without measure I received from them. 
#tr.en: My colossal royal statue I created (and) in Kinalua, his royal city, in the temple of his gods, erected. In my 29th 
#tr.en: regnal year, (my) army (and) camp I gave orders (and) sent out. To the land Habhu I went up, their cities razed, 
#tr.en: destroyed, (and) burned , (and) their land like a flood annihilated (thus) my radiant 
#tr.en: fearfulness over them I spread. In my 30th regnal year, while in Nimrud I was residing, Dayyān-Assur, 
#tr.en: the field marshal, chief of my extensive army, at the head of my army I gave orders (and) sent out. The River Zab 
#tr.en: he crossed, the cities belonging to the city Hubuskia he approached. tribute from Datana, 
#tr.en: the Hubuskaean, I received. From the cities belonging to the city Ḫubuškia 
#tr.en: I moved on and the cities of Magdubu, the Madaḫisaean, approached (and) tribute 
#tr.en: received. From the cities of the land Madaḫisaya he moved on, the cities of Udaku, 
#tr.en: the Mannaean, he approached. Udaku the Mannaean in the face of the flash of my weapons 
#tr.en: strong took fright and Zirtu, his royal city, abandoned (and) to save his life fled. 
#tr.en: After him I went (and) his oxen, sheep, (and) property without measure brought away. His cities 
#tr.en: I razed, destroyed, (and) burned. From the land Mannas he moved on, the cities of Šulusunu of the land Ḫarna 
#tr.en: he approached. Masasiri, his royal city, together with the cities in its environs I captured. Sulusunu, 
#tr.en: together with his sons, I spared (and) back to his land brought. A tax (and) tribute of horses 
#tr.en: harness-trained upon him I imposed. The city Paddira he approached (and) tribute from Artasari, 
#tr.en: the Paddiraean, I received. To the land Parsua I went down (and) tribute from the kings 
#tr.en: of the land Parsua received. Of the rest of the land Parsua, which was insubmissive to Assur, their cities 
#tr.en: I conquered (and) their captives (and) property to Assyria brought. In my 31st regnal year, (when) for a second time the die 
#tr.en: before Assur (and) Adad I threw: at that time, while in Nimrud I was residing, Dayyān-Assur, 
#tr.en: the field marshal, chief of my extensive army, at the head of my army (and) camp, I gave orders (and) sent out . 
#tr.en: The cities of Datâ, the Hubuškaean, he approached (and) tribute from him I received. 
#tr.en: To Zapparia, the fortified city of the land Muṣasir, I marched. Zapparia, together with 
#tr.en: 46 cities belonging to the people of Muṣasir, I captured. As far as the fortresses of the land of the Urartians 
#tr.en: I marched (and) 50 of their cities I razed, destroyed, (and) burned . To the land Gilzānu I went down (and) tribute 
#tr.en: from Upû, the Gilzānean, the Mannaeans, the city Gaburisu and of the land Ḫarrānia, 
#tr.en: the land Šašgānu, the land Andia, the land ...ru I: oxen, sheep, (and) horses 
#tr.en: harness-trained I received. To the cities of the land [...] I went down (and) the city Pirria 
#tr.en: (and) the city Sitiuaria, his fortified cities, together with 22 cities in the environs I razed, destroyed, 
#tr.en: (and) burned. My radiant fearfulness over [them] I spread. To the cities of the land Parsua he marched 
#tr.en: (and) the city Pustu, the city Šalaḫamānu, the city Kiniḫamānu, fortified cities, together with 23 cities 
#tr.en: in their environs I captured. I massacred them (and) plundered them. To the land Namri I went down. 
#tr.en: By fear of the radiance of Assur (and) Marduk overwhelmed, their cities they abandoned and to 
#tr.en: a rugged mountain ascended. 250 of their cities I razed, destroyed, (and) burned. 
#tr.en: Through the pass of Simesi before the land Ḫalman I went down.
